number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												This game is very near to perfect. If you like RPG, this will quite literally give you a galaxy's worth of role playing. I'll start with the things that don't matter hugely to an RPG, but add to it and bring it to perfection. Firstly, the graphics are beautiful. Individually, tree leaves may look a little pixelated, and close-up shots of weaponry and armour suffer the same effect. However, when the graphics are bought together as a whole the effect is simply profound. Vast cityscapes sprawl beneath the viewing deck on the Citadel's wards, amazing scenery from the Presidium. All the skyboxes are filled with amazing imagery; binary star systems, meteorite showers, even simply beautiful blue skies and white clouds. Tying it all together are the little graphic effects, such as the lifelike water, or whisps of smoke and steam. Detailing on the characters, aliens, and animals are all done excelently, making the alien species not only believable, but also emotionally telling even when blue or scaley. Add to this very effective use of lighting and colours, and the option to have a 'film grain' graphics setting, and you are left with a game that is just beautiful.Next, the music and sounds on this game are very well suited to the gameplay. As with most RPGs, the music seems to crescendo with each new adventure or battle, however at points in this game it also brings in much more somber and melancholly sounding music to reflect the emotions of the charecters and crew aboard the Normandy. In either case, the music always seems to reflect the fact that this is a game anbout space, and definitely adds to the other-worldly feel. The sound effects in the game are not necessarilly subtle, however when playing they become absorbed into the gameplay, something which personally I applaud. All to often I find myself turning down the sound effect volume on a game for it being to loud, or doing the complete opposite as it's too quiet to hear an enemy right behind you. With Mass Effect, all of the sounds effects are well designed so that they fit perfectly into context, and are never out of place. The voice acting in this game is spot on, all the characters are capable of so much emotion, and make the game so much more believable than counterparts with lesser vocals. Even alien races have voices to match, and a variety within the races at that, rather than the same voice actor for every member of a species (Skyrim, guards, what?). Gameplay moves fluidly, whith characters interacting very well with the environment. I don't think I ever found a character floating in mid air, or stuck inside a boulder or staircase, or limbs from a character on one side of a door potruding through to the other side. Charecters take cover when commanded, are able to peer and shoot around objects, and team commands work excelently when directed, and still work well when on automatic. Customisation of you and your team's loadout was most definitely confusing at first, however once grasped really gave the combat situations an extra tactical element, allowing choices between weapons and ammunition types for each new enemy encountered. Added to the game is a hacking minigame which allows you to unlock doors, crates and safes, and this increases with difficulty as it increases with reward, however it would have been nice for the developers to add other methods of hacking - I doubt all locks in the galaxy use the exact same system. Effectively the game has 3 levels of gameplay, the most important being on foot, secondly missions involving driving the mako, and lastly small elements from being in orbit. When in orbit you are free to walk around and interact with your spaceship, and have access to the galaxy map. From this map you can explore the galaxy through nebulas, star systems and down to an individual planetary level. This allows you to scan planets for resources, and choose to land on some of the planets to perform a mission. When on minor missions on other planets, usually you will be assigned to drive the mako, an armoured six wheeled heavy hitting tank of sorts. Equiped with some form of machine gun, a slower firing cannon, and the ability to fly for a very brief period of time, it is fun to use. The controls are a bit strange at first, with the turning not behaving quite as you'd expect, however once you've gotten used to it, the driving becomes a lot more fun.Finally, the part most people want from an RPG to be perfect is the story, the character interactions, quite simply, the role playing. This game SATISFIES. In playing this game you can either simply blast through the main missions and skip the dialogue, missing out the majority of the context and background, or you can take the time to talk to minor characters, pick up side missions, and simply use dialogue options to ask questions. All of these actions add a hugely deep and mixed background for the in-game galaxy, with complex interactions and repercussions of past actions echoed in the game you get to play, although possibly misunderstood or simply missed if the player choses to ignore them. If the interactions themselves didn't satisfy, the game has a 'codex', which is basically an encyclopedia which fills as you play and interact, meaning that if at any point you forget something you've picked up or simply want to learn more about an aspect of the game (with a large scope, from biology and cuture of alien races, to the weapons and armour used on the Normandy) you can delve into the codex and gain a better understanding. The storyline is believable, and multiple storylines can be followed through the use of paragon (hero) or renegade (badass) options. This allows for much greater depth and character development, and continues with your choices in the first game bridging over into the sequels. The paragon/renegade choice also shapes the way you interact with individual characters, bringing different methods of conflict resolution, persuading your way through tough situations, or even romance with the choice being left to the player. Character interactions are usually emotionally charged without being unreal, and these emotions build as you become closer to your crew, leading to some very hard decisions in the late game. Overall, this is one of my most favourite games I've ever played since I started on a Windows 95 at the age of 2. I fell in love on my first playthrough, and it definitely brings an amazing sense of gravitas with it. The game is deep, moving, and most importantly believable. Grapics, audio, and gameplay elements tie the whole package together in a beautiful way, and pull the player in deeper. I'd easilly give this a 9/10, and would recomend this to anyone with even a slight love of RPG. Simply put, buy this game, play it, and cherish it.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 3
												I had been pushing this game aside for years till Mass Effect 2 came along and I wanted to play this game to see what all the fuss was about. I am mainly a FPS gamer, I have steered clear of most RPG games since I knew that they were addictive and took a huge chunk of time to finish. What I didn’t realize back then was the man-hours and creativity that goes into making these games. So Mass Effect was my introduction to the world of RPGs. This was also the first BioWare game I’ve ever played and I’m glad I took the plunge. I played the Mass Effect Trilogy on my PS3 so this review is based on the PS3 version though I'm planning to play this trilogy again on PC now. Before that I wanted to write my first ever review for a game on Steam. I hope you'll like it.Who’ll love this game:Do you like feeling all powerful?Do you like to feel that your every decision will have overreaching and cascading effects through time and on other lives?Do you like to be a galactic hero who has a reputation for saving millions of lives?Do you like to fight an alien race that’s so old and powerful that they don’t even consider you worthy of attention like an insect?If the answer to any of these questions is yes, then you’ve picked the right game.The Story:The story is set in a Universe where we have a galactic government and humanity is among the newest species to be inducted into it. Spectres are among the elite who possess great power vested onto them by the government. They can take decisions independently and they even have a license to kill without fear of any repercussions. So as it happens one of these Spectres, Saren has just gone rogue and he is travelling the universe collecting Prothean artefacts which are extremely advanced for their time and these artifacts actually pave the way for the developed, modern technological era. Protheans are an ancient species that have long gone extinct centuries before our story even starts.The scope of this story is wide reaching and feels daunting at first and makes you realize how high the stakes are. The way the story twists and turns and reaches its shocking ending is brilliant. There’s always something interesting to do and your choices change the course of the story. As the game progresses you have to make harder choices with major consequences. Every decision feels personal and when you mess up it’s heartbreaking. That’s how strongly this story sucks you in.The Dialogue:The dialogues in this game are a little rigid and robotic. I think this is the only minor gripe I have in what is otherwise an excellent game. The conversations don’t sound natural. Probably this is the writer’s idea of how a space faring species speaks.The Characters:Captain Shepherd is the first human Spectre. You can either choose to play as the Male Shepherd or Fem Shepherd. You can even choose his backstory. He/She has a tragic backstroy but is a bonafide badass with a reputation that precedes him. Over the course of the game you meet your team members: Garrus Vakarian, Kaidan Alenko, Ashley Williams, Tali'Zorah nar Rayya, Liara T'Soni and Urdnot Wrex. They join your team for various reasons and each of them has a compelling reason to join your team. These are well rounded and memorable character. It’s fun to converse with them and get to know more about them between missions and you can also romance (have sex with) some of these team members. Incase you were wondering I did Liara T’Soni and Ashley on my two play-through sessions. I played a Fem Shepherd on both and Liara is a darling.Villains are aplenty in this game and there’s a lot of variety to the kind of villains that we get to face during the course of this game. Geth, Husks, Asari, Humans, Turians and Colossus Geth etc. Each one of these requires a different strategy to tackle if you want to get past them with minimal damage. After the final reveal we face an enemy that’s just phenomenal in scale.Weapons Inventory System:As a FPS gamer I am quite accustomed to “loadouts” but inventory management is something I seldom come across in FPS games and this was a steep learning curve for me as a starter on RPG. This game has a very deep inventory system where you get to choose which one of the weapons or abilities of the team members you’d like to improve. I think this was the most tedious part of the gameplay (besides Mako which I’ll get into later). I’d just say that I would prefer to spend much less time on inventory management and more time in actually playing the game. So sometimes it can be frustrating (they fixed it in Mass Effect 2). However, it should be remembered that this is a very important feature that helps in tackling stronger enemies as the game progresses.Vehicle Controls:Oh! Why? Why do I have to drive the Mako through so many terrains? Mako is a multi-terrain vehicle which is mostly helpful during some assignments on uncharted planets. Some of the levels with Mako are definitely worth playing over and over again however, my problem is with Mako itself. If you have played this game already you’d know that the controls for this thing are probably the biggest problem this game has. It seems like Mako has a mind of its own sometimes. Except for the Mako most of the controls are pretty solid in this game. Missions:You get to go on a boatload of assignments in this game. Apart from the story based missions you also get the secondary missions which may sometimes feel repetitive. However, playing these missions help in exploring some vital elements which are required to help you level up faster. In that way these are a necessary evil. I’d recommend playing all of these secondary missions.Soundtrack:Jack Wall delivers one of the most thoughtful soundtracks for a game. The soundtrack amplifies several scenes in this game and it feels like an integral part of these scenes. It sets the mood and atmsphere with the extensive synth use which feels futuristic even if it should like it belonged in the 80s. This is a great game and a game of this caliber deserved a great soundtrack and that’s just what it is. Conclusion:Mass Effect boasts of a great story that’s built around great characters and (for the most part) great gameplay. But by no means is this game easily conquered. You may have to spend atleast 40-50 hours in order to finish this game and that makes me think how hard it must have been for the game designers to create such an expansive world. The voice acting and visuals in this game deserve high praise and they actually account for the strongest visceral impact of this game. I’ve played this game twice in both Paragon and Renegade playstyles, so that’s about over 100 hours of game time and it was totally worth it. Even today there are few games out there that are this immersive. Every time I play this game, I feel like I’m really Captain Shepherd and that’s a testament to how strongly you get attached to this world and the characters. One thing is for certain, once you enter this world you'll never forget it.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
Rank: 8.5/10Recommendation(s): Player is a Sci-Fi lover, enjoys RPG games, and is willing to continue gameplay series by porting results in to the later games. If using 3D Vision, use Helix Mod.Major Theme: How to define "original" Bioware games.Bought at Price: $35 (for Mass Effect 1 and Mass Effect 2 Deluxe)Only a few games fit into the "must play" listing I keep. If you have any dreams or hopes in playing the other Mass Effect games, start here. You will thank me later!Bioware is the company to know for RPG titles. The lead writer (and then co-lead writer for Mass Effect 2) ensures you have a story filled with action and content. If you ever played Knights of the Old Republic (KotOR) I or II you will feel right at home. While feeling like KotOR in some ways, Mass Effect is a more "mature" version of it. You should be willing to deal with (and enjoy) the extra sex, gore, and innuendo that this title brings. Stories really need to have sex, gore, and humour to make them balanced, and that's what Mass Effect's plot brings.Using the Unreal Engine from 2007, graphics are decent and shouldn't have issues running on most systems. If you have a control panel for your graphics card, you can try to force better options. That being said, there's a hidden frame rate smoothing option (60 fps), when disabled, can allow any high refresh rate monitor to shine. This can also help 3D vision players.Game is rated 3D vision "excellent", only real issue being that enemy icons seem 2D. This can be resolved, and overall stereoscopic 3D performance increased, by using Helix Mod. Really, Helix makes Mass Effect a treat to play with and will greatly improve immersion.It should be assumed that you do not stop with Mass Effect. There's 2 more games to explore and enjoy in the series (besides the comics, books and such). This really just sets up the plot for the rest of the series. The biggest thing that the series should be known for is it's save porting, where you are able to plug the results of a previous title into the next and change the plot.The "romance mechanic" is simple, as noted in my Mass Effect 2 review. This has lead to the Mass Effect romance system being called a "getting laid simulator". Don't be expecting to see the same mechanic from Dragon Age: Origins here. You can see my review on that title as well, if you wish for a better explanation.Reading other bonus content, the biggest thing you will feel in the game is that there's still hidden old school RPG mechanics in play. While you think you are shooting a target, your shots can in fact miss. Another will be the inventory system, where you can only hold so many items. If you do not manage your inventory, you will be forced to either ditch items, or modify the hidden limit value. Just be aware this title hasn't fully transitioned out of those older mechanics.While not in the special elite class of 90+ on the metascore, still worthwhile. I'm sick of seeing COD like games, reskined platform runners, and super simple games. I've played enough out of my Valve titles, so this game was a breath of fresh air and worked out well.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												I really enjoyed this gamePros--The story is well crafted and you can tell alot of effort was put into it. It has lots of twists, turns, and reveals that are pretty good. Not mind blowing, but still, its one of the highlights of the game. Theres alot there if you want to dig giving players a choice in how far they want to go into the lore of the worle. -Interactions with your squad members are memorable and personal. Each has distinct personalities and underlying motives that are there if you spend the time to get to know them all-The branching diolauge paths are great. Give some depth and a player's touch into the game. Not super deep and many diolauges still lead to the exact same result but thats ok.-The settings were pretty good. It was really neat to go explore all these planets and choose in what order you were to do it in. The aliens and universe created here are also interesting and thought out.-Runs well on my crap PC and also has a widespread texture mod for those who seek higher fidelity. Cons-Elevators. There are alot of them. Most I assume are disgusing loading screens and it really gets old fast especially when in some situations you go through one elevator, get out, walk a bit, then go up another. -Combat. While it is good I wouldnt call it great. I played on the hardest difficulty with AI actions turned off for my squad mates and one of two things would happen in combat situations: my main character could just wipe out all the enemies without the help of my squadmates so I have no reason to even have them do anything, or when I do need them they are HORRIBLE at staying alive. Even when you direct them towards cover they very often come out for no reason and die. Somtimes you plan a combo of abilities on a enemy all at once but one squad member decides that its just not happening today. It got annoying. Also I didnt like that you had to pick your squadmates from the begining of the mission when you have no idea whats in store. They all have different abilities but only a few combos cover everything so it locks you out of doing certain combos of characters you may like. Overall it is an ok combat system, that with some tweaks could be really really good.-Driving sections - controls are kind of slippery and every driving section all game has the same 3 or 4 enemies making them really easy and really boring-Enemies. There are only about 10 enemys in the whole game if you dont count reskins. Kind of a a let down. -Final Boss- Ended up just being the main bad guy with the abilities of one of the enemy types you have fought all game with a stupid amount of health and rocket launchers added on. I get that the combat doesnt really lend itself to grandiose boss battles but still. Boss battles in general were usually just waves of common enemies. -Save points, This is the grandaddy of my annoyances with this game. Probably 5-10 times thoughout the main game you will have boss battles or very difficult encounters that have loooong cutscenes or elevators right before them. These cannot be skipped and its awful. Every time you die you have to walk through the same diolauge for 2 minutes before you fight. It gets old really fast espeicailly if you are having a real tough time with the boss. I get not skipping on the first time but there is no reason you shouldnt be able to skip on subsequent viewings.Overall I did really enjoy this game. This is a game that is greater than the sum of its parts. It keep me wanting to play to figure out what would happen next which cant be said for too many games I play. If you like a good space story and third person tactical shooters, I would grab this game. 7.5/10

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												Rating 8/10OverviewThird Person Shooter Role Playing Game  - Impressive game with serious flawsThe Good:+ The game provides a variety of different classes that suit individual play styles. Each class comes with its own unique set of advantages and disadvantages. Certain classes can only use certain types of weapons and abilities.  The game also gives you the option of solving missions by being good(paragon) or a bit more ruthless (renegade) Depending on your choice, leads to more dialogue options in the future. +Combat is a huge part of the game. Each gun type feels good, along with the different abilities. You can issue commands to your party members however for the most part they do fine if you leave them be.  Certain battles can be very engaging requiring you to make full use of the environments and equipment. +The overall plot is excellent and keeps the game interesting. Although it touches upon a lot of different sci fi tropes the game presents all of these ideas in a manner that makes the game interesting and fun to play+ The writing/dialogue and the voice acting are all fantastic making every interaction engaging to listen to.+In typical Bioware fashion, the companions and villains are interesting and for the most part, the best characters in the game. Talking to each companion and listening to their history adds a level of depth to the game. +Character design is excellent, each race has a unique look and feel to them adding to the believability. + The main missions are varied and fun to play, each mission involves driving a vehicle which helps break up the shooting segments and keeps things from getting stale. +The lead up to the final confrontation and ultimately the conclusion is epic. It really feels satisfying, and is a fitting end to the game. I would argue this game has a better build up to the end than the other games in the series. +The overall scope of this game is impressive for what its trying to accomplish. The game has a variety of different planets to explore in your vehicle, side missions, story missions, talking to your companions, learning the history of the different races, planets, technologies etc. If you are a gamer who loves being absorbed into a universe Bioware did a fantastic job of detailing every possible aspect of the game. +Graphically the game still holds up very well, though textures seem blurry. + Music and soundThe Bad:- The user interface is abysmal for what this game is trying to accomplish. Buying/Selling or even equipping items in your inventory seems much harder than it needs to be. The UI does not convey information in a presentable fashion. There are options missing that would makes things so much easier, i.e organizing  inventory lists based on damage/accuracy etc.-Side missions are incredibly repetitive for all the wrong reasons. The game recycles three or 4 level designs over and over again taking the fun out of playing these missions. In addition most side quest missions are completed the same way- Kill lots of enemies, reach the end of the level, talk to somebody and resolve it by being good or bad. If you played one of them, you pretty much played them all. -The idea of exploring different planets, discovering lost ruins, and missions certainly sounds awesome but something was lost in the execution. Going down to a planet is amazing the first time but quickly wears off its appeal the third, fourth or fifth time. Every planet although very different in look and feel, plays out all the same. Driving around in barren landscapes is only fun for so long. This is the only way to get and complete side quests. -Bugs, glitches are present. I got stuck in a wall more than a few occasions. -No official controller support. I know mods exists to correct this issue but it is not fully implemented. You can't properly use the controller in menus nor can you use it when issuing commands to your party members. ConclusionThere is plenty to love with this game and I certainly loved my time with it, however the glaring flaws holds it back from what should be a true classic.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												What can be said about Mass Effect that hasn't already been said?Mechanically, it's a third-person shooter/RPG hybrid with interactive, choice-driven cinematics interspersed regularly.There are certainly problems with that. The conversations and cinematics wind up taking up, quite literally, most of your time--except of course the endless backtracking on the Normandy and Mako portions--and making the game feel more like a visual novel than a Western action-RPG at times. It feels more like a story and less like a game, some of the time. Most of the time, really.The RPG leveling is good, but nowhere near as good as, say, Skyrim's, or the original Deus Ex's. (I say the original because I have yet to play Human Revolution, not because I object to it in any way.) The levels you wind up focusing on are Charm and Intimidate, whose primary impact involves, you guessed it, the cinematic conversations. There's the electronics and decryption skill trees, sure (although they're more just lines than trees--for a game centered around choice-based narrative, there's not much choice-based gameplay) which allow you to access increasingly more advanced resources, but if you just bring one of your three tech-savvy squadmates and fully spec them to those trees, you can deal with any of those unlicks from about three hours in, which kind of renders the piont moot. That's good, though, because the alternative is yet more Mako scenes as you backtrack to planets you've already seen once you can access the resources on them.The shooter portion, which is the part you actually play, has fewer concrete issues. You point and shoot. It's just lackluster. The sniper rifles are unsteady in a rather blatant nod to Deus Ex--they get better as you level them. Pistols are pretty much slightly slower assault rifles. Shotguns are bizzarely effective over long ranges. Assault Rifles, which only Soldier-class characters can train, are actually quite viable for non-soldier characters, to the point where on higher difficulties the game is almost impossible if you  forget about them.The biggest issues I have are with certain enemies and level design. The Geth units which jump around the area are almost impossible to hit, especially if you haven't got a controller mod installed. There is the occasional open level where sniper rifles are viable, but a lot of the game is played at close-quarters to the enemy, which renders snipers useless. Annoying, since I like the Infiltrator class's tech abilities combines with combat proficiency, since biotics are very hard to use in this first game.But in spite of all that, Mass Effect works, mechanically speaking. Nothing is broken. I wouldn't come back to it for the gameplay, but it's not painful to play--unless you're in the Mako and trying to 100% every planet, in which case, you have my sympathies.Where Mass Effect--and Bioware in general--shine is in narrative. Mass Effect--the first game, not the trilogy--does a fantastic job of creating a setting and telling a story in it. It's a bit bland compared to its two sequels, I'll be honest. It doesn't have the thematic subtext those games do. Mass Effect 1 is nothing more than it claims to be: a story which provides you a template--Shepard--and lets you play with him or her how you choose. But that much it does incredibly well.There are few scenes in a video game that have aged as well as the first meeting with Sovereign on Virmire or the conversation with Vigil on Ilos. Despite the ridiculous texture glitch on Garrus' face, we start to get a real feel for one of the best characters in gaming in this game, and he is fun, especially when in an elevator with Tali or Wrex so they can yell at each other.The less said about elevators, the better, of course.The romances are a bit dull, I will admit. Your choices are Kaidan, Ashley, and Liara. Kaidan is bland, Ashley is xenophobic, and Liara never uses contractions because at this point Bioware still thought that was a cool way to make a character mysterious. I guess Liara's the best choice, but it's a bit like deciding which cheap shoe looks least cheap.Wow, I'm really bashing the game aren't I? Yeah, it's flawed. Really flawed. But it works. The first playthrough can be incredibly immersive. Saren is a great villain, most of the time, and a good one overall. Sovereign is truly chilling. You feel like something is at stake, by the end of the game, although it never quite reaches the emotional peaks at the last levels of Mass Effect 2 and 3.All in all, it's not a masterpiece, but it's a fun game, and one well worth a purchase, even when it's not on sale. When it is on sale, you'd be a fool not to get it.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2015
												The intentions of Mass Effect as the beginning of a series are apparent in damn near every aspect of the experience.  In a word: foundation.  It feels like it was designed to be built up upon, because what is here is aesthetically light, but structurally phenomenal.What's immediately striking about Mass Effect given it's nature as an RPG is how well it plays as an action game.  Combat feels polished and dynamic, featuring an automatic cover system that works in tandem with largely artifical environments designed around boxes/wall/etc that leave no doubt as to what can and cannot be used for cover.   The shooting mechanics feel impactful and effective and the overall design accomodates both tactical and run-gun-hav'n-fun forms of play.  Battles can be as dynamic or degenerate strategy as you want them to be and not feel like either is more viable than the other.But as an RPG, it's remarkable how many aspects of the game have been given this effectively tactile sense of physicality.  The ability to select responses through a conversation wheel with a mouse click creates a remarkably natural sense of rhythm to talking with NPCs that closely emulate real life.  There's no artificial time limit to responses either, this all happens as a natural consequence of the design of the system.  The physicality runs even to the more minor tasks such as hacking and navigation, extending the life of what would normally be sloggishly repetative tasks.  Again, as an RPG, it's rather startling just how good this game FEELS to play.So what's not to love?  Well...yeah, we'll get to that, but first things first:You are Commander Shepard, a human who's being eyed at by the Leaders of the Free Galaxy for the prestigious title of Spectre: an Intergalatic Man/Woman of Mystery with a License to Kill.  Things go♥♥♥♥♥♥up due a Spectre Whose Gone Rogue that leaves you with Information Vital to Saving the Galaxy and you are eventually tasked with Taking Him Down only to find that Behind His Power is A Much Greater Power that Threatens to Destroy the Galaxy!  If that all sounds cliche and routine well, that's cause it is.  Again, it feels like a foundation.  It's in the details - the subtleties and nuances they paint upon that very broad canvas - that makes the game's world so rewarding to experience.  The sheer amount of content they put into world building is astounding, but the restraint in not overloading the player with it if they don't want while still having it inform the situations the game creates is certainly worthy of note.The thing to note upon a first run is how deceptively large the game is.  Playing the main quest takes you to only five planets before the endgame.  Some feature hub sections with a few sidequests, but taken as a whole, you could easily breeze through the entire game in only a few hours.  The bulk of the game's content is side quests that have you running willy nilly through dozens of systems in various clusters throughout the galaxy, usually touching upon some various world building content or minor character moments.  They can vary from a simple one-click scan of a planet for resources, to full on multi-planet hopping quests featuring both surface exploration, combat and tense negotiations...and there's SCORES of them!So now...the price that's payed for all this polish and content: The game doesn't look very good.Oh it's technically proficient.  Textures, faces and all are quite up to snuff.  But the design of the game is bare bones.  Any environment not devoted to the main quest is entirely pre-fab and not even randomly generated.  There's only some half dozen variations on them and since they do not change, it get's immediately repetative.  Even the main quest planets feel overly artificial and lifeless.  Mulitple quests end abruplty with nothing more than a pop-up window delivering silent flavor text and while the planet exploration goes a long way towards delivering on the scale the game, the actual landscapes were clearly randomly generated hieghtmaps ripped straight out of a late '90's 3d software program.  And yes, the way the game handles inventory is one of the worst I've seen anywhere ever.  Ya happy?So that's Mass Effect.  A game where all the polish was put into the systems and design rather than the aesthetics, leading to a massive new world for players to explore that felt large, felt good to roleplay and simply play in...all so long as you ignored it'd been filled with blatantly copy/pasted environments.  Playing the game, the intent is very clear that this was to be the building blocks for a more fully realized world to build around their solid mechancis, design and world building.  Ah well...

content:
Posted: October 26, 2013
												The Mass Effect trilogy is with out a doubt my favourite, as few games have captivated me in such a scale as these ones. This particular game is the first in the trilogy(obviously) and in many ways what got me into the rpg-genre of gaming. I wasn't a fan of this genre beforehand and for me to get my hands on this game was actually a happy mistake. I got to randomly try out the demo and have never looked back since. The greatest strengts of this game is its grand, epic and interesting story, both ingame and lorewise. Bioware(developer) is also known to craft some of the finest characters/companions around, which makes the whole experience that more awesome. You care about them and want to get to know them better for their great diversity, flaws or stengths. Some of the gameplay may be a bit rusty (It came out in 2007) but if you're in for the story and lore you will not get dissapointed. The sequels will greatly expand on the gameplay, as will your choices. Remember, the Mass Effect saga is currently over 3 games and choices made in the first game will haunt you in the second or third installment.

content:
Posted: February 1
I keep revisiting Chora's Den to watch the women in latex.No, seriously.The game's amazing.If you play this right after playing Counter Strike, you might get a little frustrated, what with all the character's skill tree and all those decisions and side quests.But that's what makes the game a great RPG.I came here straight from Dragon Age: Origins, and while this game is nothing like that, it's definitely worth buying when not on sale.I mean, think.For a few bucks you could have had a game with stunning visuals(for it's time) hi-tech weapory, space exploration, plenty of decisions that actually affect the game and a spaceship of your own.Did I mention that you have your very own monster truck?The dialogue and storyline's amazing.And there are funny moments, like where a thug argues with an AI, and even goes as far as to threaten it.You obviously have multiple squad members, whom you can change if you wish.I keep Ashley cause she's hot. :PI'm 10 hours in, and I'm nowhere near the end of the game because I'm doing 100% of the side quests and exploration.I'd advise you to do the same.Oh, and Mass Effect 2 is free for a while on Origin, if you're interested!Cheers.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
												This game is just so fantastic. If you like star wars, its also a must buy. In Mass Effect, you decide how your character reacts to things, you decide on what orders to issue to your squad, but most of all, you decide the fate of the entire galaxy. Exploration and learning is good fun. Cover and heat sytems work well and smoothly. The Mako vehicle drives alright up until the last mission you use it, then its just a mess. Atmosphere is great. Finding that gun that has one more roman numeral than yours has a great feeling swapping them out realizing your Shepard made a noticable improvement. The few spread out boss battles are a nice challenge. Your going to need to quick save a lot as the actual saves are quite distant. Its an interesting take on the universe as humanity is just being introduced to an already well established galactic democracy. It's also been awhile since ive been so excited for such a great and fitting cinematic end.

Posted: July 20, 2014
												The early parts of the game can be a bit slow (action-wise), and the learning curve for the non-soldier classes can be a little steep. However, the story is gripping (especially the first time through), and the voice acting is excellent.The combat is not as polished as other shooters, but is still fun, and only a component of the total experience. There is potential for replay value, too, with different classes to play, and different decisions to make.Overall, it is an excellent game. It is especially worth playing if you want to play the entire trilogy, because you can transfer your character from game to game.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2012
												One of the best RPGs of our generation, Mass Effect is a wonderful and engaging experience that you can play for hundreds of hours. There are many options that you can pick in numerous situations presented to you throughout the storyline. Some gamers complain that there are only three options: Good, Neutral, and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, but I found that the the way the decision making process and character development progressed was one of the best features of this game.  Every situation had multiple ways to go about resolving it, each with their own advantages and disadvantages - including the "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥" decision tree.  The choices you've made in your story also move forward into ME2, making you want to play the game, and series, over and over again.Pros:Fun CombatDecision-based, Bioware StorytellingGreat setting, characters, and narrative styleCons:The Mako controls are very tediousItemization isn't done quite rightWonderful RPG any fan of Bioware of Sci-Fi should play.  Also, play the female Shep, Jennifer Hale gives a knock-out performance. A+

												A tear comes to my eye as I think about how best to express the pure joy this game brings. That sense of joy can come from climbing to the top of a mountain on a world at furthest reaches of the galaxy and witnessing an alien sunrise, the stunning and original story line, and even looking down at your feet as you board a cargo ship and see the entire universe below you. content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												I have tried a few times to play this game. Last time hard drive broke so I thought I might try again as I was enjoying it.Its really good, a great sci fi game. Really good story a good start to series and still stands up well as an older game.For me its not the most indepth game character wise from Bioware. I did really like the characters and story but it just didnt feel as indepth as Dragon Age.  Its still a really good game well worth playing and Mass Effect 2 is supposed to be amazing. It feels a little slower paced which I dont mind. The side missions some just seem dull and pointless but some of the rewards are pretty cool and do make it worth your while. The character missions I always like to do as I like to get to know the characters but all in all I just wanted to get on with the story which is a shame because theres a galaxy to explore.The characters were cool but it seemed most of it was set up to make you have a relationship with someone. I mean it didnt seem to matter what i said to one of the characters something was gonna happen lol.Still a cool game though.

content:
Posted: January 31
												A nice mix of RPG and 3rd person shooter set in an awesome scifi world.  Humans are becoming something more and discover the galaxy and you get to be part of it. You control a team that you need to build in the most effective way possible. Each crew mate that you meet get's stronger through the xp gained during missions. They each have different classes and get different powers which you must use in combination with other powers from other crew members. Optimise squad choixe and evolution then optimise firepower and different powers while adapting to enemy particularities. This 3 part saga (soon to be 4 part)  will let you meet lots of aliens with their specific fighting techniques and specific personalities. An awesome saga to remember at an awesome price.One of these games you would like to forget to replay and rediscover again.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
												This game was what got me into the Mass Effect franchise, and I'm happy for that, however the combat style and the way some of the AI works makes it terrable as far as gameplay is concerned (An example being the Rogue VI mission on the moon, where the drones would just rush you with no where to hide). Also if you want to get all the side quests done, you'll spend a lot of time running around the Citadel doing quests more fitting to a MMORPG then a single player game. And the thing I hated most, the conversation tree, don't get me wrong, I'm a Roleplayer, but if two options result in the exact same dialogue, then why bother having both? this often made me feel like I had no influence in the conversation, even though that's one of the core features. But dispite all that, it's a great story, and as I said, it got me into the franchise, so it's still recommended in my books.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												This game is absolutely brilliant. I didn't realize how much better the first game is ME2 and ME3, until i started replaying ME1 the other day. Grand nostalgia started kicking in and the epicness of this game is on a scale unmatched by any other space game. The level-up system is fleshed out, the characters are fleshed out, decisions have big impacts and the combat is tactical, difficult and awesome. Also, the inventory I happen to like quite a bit, when most people hate it. But thanks to so many people hating it, BioWare completely got rid of it and stripped the game of it's other most important RPG elements for ME2 and ME3. Mass Effect 1 is to ME2 and ME3 what Dragon Age Origins is to Dragon Age 2. The first game of both series' were epic beyond the likes of any other game in it's genre and had so much content it kept you wide-eyed and fully entrapped by it's charm. While the sequels were just stripped down of the best features they once had. Though I have to say that ME2 is still a pretty entertaining and fun game, but didn't do justice to the original.To say the least, if you enjoy space games or RPGs, then this game is a must and you'll probably love it. Admittedly it does take a few hours to really get into the game and the tactical combat takes some getting used to, but it's great fun once you learn. That's all good in my opinion. I enjoy having to learn a  game rather than being thrown into it and it being the same as every other game in it's genre. This game will take you on one of the most memorable journeys you've ever been on in gaming and it will captivate you the entire way through, from the grand music, to the tactical combat, to the storytelling, etc.On a side not, a lot of people also didn't like exploring planets with the Mako, but I think that's one of the best parts. It's fun discovering materials/items and uncovering the secrets of some planets and completing quests on others. Again, if you like space, this game is definitely for you.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												Game:  Mass Effect 1Genre:  RPG/FPSDeveloper:  Bioware/EASystem:   Steam (PC)Total Score: 93/100Value Score: 9.3/10• Story:  10/10• Characters: 9/10• GamePlay:  9/10	• Graphics:  8/10• Sound: 10/10• Music:  8/10• Length: 9/10• Replay Value: 10/10• Player Value: 10/10Pros+Great Dynamic story that keeps changing depending on what role, what decisions and actions you make in the game. +Multiple Scenarios, Paths and Endings which leads to multiple playthroughs and thus replay value+Class based gameplay system which allows you to have a different experience each time you play as a different class.+Character customization lets you create your own character in their own appearance, etc+A great mixture of RPG and FPS elements packaged into one game+Fantastic voice acting and a lot of voice over scenes+A great morality system that also plays in what bonuses you would get (i.e. discounts, certain decision options)+Leveling system has quite a depth that ranges from learning unique class abilities to weapon mastery+Save files are interchangeable between Steam and Origin.Cons-Some minor glitches could occur such as falling into the floor or certain scenes not being playable from time to time but nothing game breaking and does not happen often or repeatedly-Some of the visual designs look a bit outdated and last gen style (PS2/GCN/Xbox era)-Some of the side missions lead you to similar to same looking areas and structures-Some of the planets are so barren and empty with nothing but fetch quests or extra grinding for weapons and money.-Pinnacle Station DLC is not available for standalone purchases of Mass Effect 1. Only available for Trilogy purchasers.-Bring Down the Sky DLC has to be downloaded separately and installed unlike the description in the store page where it says its available already.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												Mass Effect 3 was my first Mass Effect game to play when it came out a while back; however, I decided to give the whole triolgy a new start after I bought the first two as a bundle during some Steam sale. I didn't quite remember all the details from ME3, which was good, but I knew enough about the Mass Effect world to where I wasn't completely lost. With that said, finally figuring out all the backstory and references made in ME3 was amazing. Story-wise, the Mass Effect universe is on par with Star Wars and Star Trek. The charaters are developed extremely well, with well thought out insight in each different species. The dialogue and choices are superb. At the end of the day, when you finally save and exit the game, you feel as if you were part of the action. Part of Commander Shepard's odyssey. Going back to reality was always a bummer. Combat-wise the controls were a little loose. Then again, this game is about 7 years old at this point. You get use to the controls, but do not expect very responsive actions and features that most games have today. Most of the side quests (assignments) felt like chores at the end, but I still wanted to get them all done to explore the awesome ME universe. Customization is also not as well-developed as the sequels are. Many times I get stuck with a Shepard wearing a ridiculous looking armour but the stats on it are amazing so I couldn't argue. The decision making (Paragon/Renegade) also provides unique story, meticulous and sometimes stressful choices, and good replayability, even if much of the story is progressively linear. In the end, I can understand why Mass Effect is so popular. The universe draws you in and the gripping story, dialogue, and action make you want to play this game until you have played it 3+ times, exhausting all the different dialogue choices, actions, and play styles you can make in the game. Worth the money. Worth the time. You will regret nothing besides some of the grueling choices you have to make along the way to save the galaxy. But that's what makes this game, this series, perfect.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
												This game is just so fantastic. If you like star wars, its also a must buy. In Mass Effect, you decide how your character reacts to things, you decide on what orders to issue to your squad, but most of all, you decide the fate of the entire galaxy. Exploration and learning is good fun. Cover and heat sytems work well and smoothly. The Mako vehicle drives alright up until the last mission you use it, then its just a mess. Atmosphere is great. Finding that gun that has one more roman numeral than yours has a great feeling swapping them out realizing your Shepard made a noticable improvement. The few spread out boss battles are a nice challenge. Your going to need to quick save a lot as the actual saves are quite distant. Its an interesting take on the universe as humanity is just being introduced to an already well established galactic democracy. It's also been awhile since ive been so excited for such a great and fitting cinematic end.

												Wow! I was a bit late to the Mass Effect game, and I had allways heard about it, so cyber monday of 2016 I bought it. It was worth every cent I paid, and more. The storyline was incredible, with alot of suprises and plot twists, that I didn't see coming. I love the large amounts of chat dialogs you have for each converstation, and how each choice effects the game later down the road. The Combat system was great, my only con was that when facing bioitcs, you can sometimes get thrown into a wall or other place to get stuck, but thats an easy fix. I have never been so impressed with a game and the storyline. Looking forward to finish all of the side quests, and importing my game to Mass Effect 2, to continue the story!! I highly recommed this game to anyone who likes a good story game!!!!

content:
Posted: November 8, 2012
												A fantastic space rpg with a very interesting universe and story. The game gives you a good deal of customization and has great character interaction. However, the combat is pretty mediocre third person shooter combat for the most part. The vehicle sections can also be quite awkward especially when you are playing the game for the first time. Despite these issues, the shooting is still somewhat satisfying and the game gives you a variety of abilities and weapon addons that make the combat much more interesting. You can get cryo ammo to freeze your enemy, or biotic power that allow you to through your enemies. You also have a good deal of control over you squad which adds a bit more depth to the combat.8/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												It's pretty good. I like it. Pros: +Overall, characters are well-written, well-rounded characters you come to love and love to hate. +Mark Meer and Jennifer Hale both do an excellent job voicing Shepard. +High degree of character customization.+Can be anyone from Space Jesus to Genocidal Maniac.+Has a sense of humor without becoming a borderline parody of itself like certain later Bioware games.Cons:-Glitch makes PC textures permanently low res. Unless you mod the game, it looks like your monitor threw up.-Can't ♥♥♥♥ Tali or Garrus until ME2. -I hate the Asari and so should you. -Your human squadmates are a bit bland and kind of♥♥♥♥♥♥ Garrus gives off more of a "relatable everyman best friend" vibe than they do and he's a birdman from space. -Ain't nobody gonna play any class but Soldier. Seriously. All the weapons, all the health, all the armor. IIRC, they ran the stats and over 80% of people picked Soldier. That's not what you call indicitive of good class balance.-Vehicle controls are♥♥♥♥♥ -Explicitly labeling your choices "Paragon" and "Renegade" (ie: Goody-two shoes and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥) robs game of moral nuance. -Planetary exploration handled in a fairly dull manner.Overall, I would say this game has mediocre gameplay, a pretty decent, albiet somewhat generic plot and very well written characters. In terms of mechanics, it is a C+ RPG and a C+ third person shooter bolted together. However, as a work of interactive fiction, it is well worth playing. I would recommend this game to anyone who would enjoy a good old fashioned space opera romp first and foremost. I would not recommend this game to people who were considering buying this game because they thought it would be either a good dedicated sci-fi shooter like Gears of War or Halo or an old-school Bioware RPG like Baldur's Gate or Dragon Age: Origins.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												While perhaps not worth the hype the series has generated over the years, this game is still very good. I really enjoyed the story, and the way it progressed really impressed me. The supporting cast aren't that great (something they improved in Mass Effect 2, sadly with the loss of the great story) but the fact that Shepard develops how you want him to while still remaining an interesting character is no mean feat.It is quite annoying that some conversations that give you options just ignore your choices and just go straight into what the game wants, and I guess it would be tough to make a game which allowed all that but then making games is tough. So I would've liked more freedom to do what I wanted rather than just what the game dictated. Nobody likes a game pretending you have a choice and then just ignoring it. That's just not cool.The combat is perfectly acceptable. I heartily recommend going with the combat-biotic fusion character as then you get the most fun out of your character while still remaining a heavy hitter with weapons. The squad-part of combat is really not at all important, as your squad is not all that effective and they can just about handle themselves. I'm quite glad that they did that though, as I prefer having a squad that does their own thing. They could have made them slightly more clever however. Overall, a very good game with a few drawbacks. Not a brilliant game, but a very good game nonetheless.

												Mass Effect is one of the first games I've played with multiple different branching storylines... which are actually followed up across future franchise editions. Many games with multiple endings, with a sequel, just assume a given ending. With Mass Effect, the choices you make... matter.Mass Effect 1 is good for a rich storyline. It has some flaws, as in the Mako missions where you have to drive up the side of a hill almost sideways, and gravity is very unrealistic. But, for the most part... it is a fun enough game to play. Most games average around 50-60 hours (as in Final Fantasy)... I spent a little over 120 hours on Mass Effect 1 playing the "Paragon" male version and "Renegade" female version.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												One of the great RPGs of our time. Mass Effect excells in storytelling and characterization in ways that no other game has. This particular title is most memorable (for me personally) because of the way it introduces and develops the characters in such a fashion that the player truly cares about their fate and building relationships with each and every one.Mass Effect also has solid shooter mechanics. I actually prefer the overheating weapons over the thermal clips from the later games. I also enjoy the combat storm and the way it is incorporated into the strengths and weaknesses of any particular character build. The abilites and leveling are also extremely well executed. I personally found it so rewarding and satisfying that I achieved level 60, but regardless the leveling system successfully helps to add reward during a playthrough.Again, however, what makes Mass Effect such an amazing game is its characters and story progression. To avoid spoilers, I will just say that by the time I was nearing the end of the main story for the first time, I was deeply invested in each individual character's story and that is something that I cannot say about almost any other game experience.Mass Effect exemplifies the great strengths of BioWare in its prime and will forever be a gold standard to which I will compare future titles to.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												You know it, you love it, it's Mass Effect!  Have you ever wanted to be immersed in a believable, complex, engrossing science fiction tale that brings humanity into a galactic forum of sentient species from across the galaxy as they attempt to tackle an unknown nefarious threat?Well? Have you? Of course you have!  What are you waiting for!   This game is...less polished than it could've been.  But if you get past the somewhat...lackluster FPS aspects, and focus more on the RPG-like progression of powerful abilities and the story driven aspects...there's nothing not to love.Also, Jennifer Hale's voice acting as Femme-Shep is exquisitely charged with passion and verve!  Strong female protagonist, if you choose for Shepherd to be female.   I, frankly, found the male voice actor to be neutral in his emotions too often.  I don't believe he threw himself into the role as much.Jennifer Hale sounds like she's the hero who held off a Batarian raid of a human colony single-handedly and against all odds.Anyway, I digress.  If you have the money to burn, and want a good story, this is one of the best in sci-fi. (Mass Effect 3's ending being the only highly-contested part of that statement.)The Normandy isn't going to command itself...

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												I actually spent 20 hours in this game in the last 4 days in Steam offline mode, so ignore Steam playtime.Mass Effect was a pleasant surprise for me, because of two reasons: I'm not a fan of space opera and sci-fi, and I couldn't get into one of Bioware's well known title - Dragon Age: Origins. But screw them, let's talk about Mass Effect. The game has messy inventory system, clunky animations, pretty straightforward weapon upgrades and doesn't allow progressing after finishing the main story, aaaaaaand... that's it, that's all my criticism for ME. What can I say more about it? Mass Effect is a well-crafted game from head to toe, with nearly all aspects perfected.First, I freaking love the narrative. In the first 30 minutes, I thought it was some typical pretentious sci-fi piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥that overcomplicates everything, but nope, the story really hooked me in, even it was just a standard good-vs-evil story filled with cliches. I can't tell exactly what I love about ME's story, but it gave me a sense of real progression, and pushed me forward through each events in the game. Sometime intense, sometime emotional and sometime even silly (especially in romance subplots), and of course it doesn't lack "epicness" for a sci-fi saga.Next, the dialogues. There's no such thing as illusive choices. In ME, every choice matters, and not all decisions lead to a good end.  I still feel bad because I accidentally shot Wrax on Virmire, had to replay that section. Tip: Spend your points in Charisma or Intimidate, they're very important, don't ignore them.Teammates. Uhuh, this is not your standard companions, your squad mates are TRUE human (or alien) beings with their own unique personality. You know what? I found it more interesting to wandering around the Normandy, talking to my squad mates, rather than exploring the galaxy. And I've never, ever, felt so much difficult in deciding between 2 squad mates' fates. There was no game that made me care so much about my team mates like Mass Effect. Why? Because ♥♥♥♥ you Bioware, you created some of the most memorable and well-developed side characters in any game I've ever played. If I don't see Garrus, Wrex, Liara or Tali in the sequels, many tables will be flipped.Gunplay hasn't aged well, but it's certainly enjoyable. Tons of weapons, upgrades and special biotic abilities. You don't need to be a strategist to play the game, but it certainly helps if you can order your squad mates to assist you on the battlefield.Aargh. why, why did I spend the last 7 years without giving a damn about Mass Effect? Why didn't I know about it sooner? Why did I pass on this masterpiece? And why does Garrus's face look low-textured? Anyway, Mass Effect, 10 ♥♥♥♥ing out of 10, heavily recommended. If you are a fan of RPG or sci-fi, play it already. If you don't give a crap about RPG or sci-fi, then still give it a try, because you might like it as much as I do.

content:
Posted: January 3
												Mass Effect Throwback Review	Mass Effect. What else can be said about a game that is already so highly thought of. A game where almost everything has been talked about and or said. Mass Effect is the first game in the Mass Effect series and the first game in the original Mass Effect series. You play as Commander Shepard, a human part of the Systems Alliance N7, what does that equate to? The galaxy special forces baby. At the start of the game you are given the choice to decide Commander Shepard's background. Where he or she grew up, military background, and prior service. You then get to choose what your Shepard looks like. Hair, face, eyes. All the basic RPG character design options are there, however the options are rather limited here, I felt like my male Shepard always looked almost the same no matter what I picked. After you've made your character you are thrown into your first mission on Eden Prime. 	Of course things go wrong on Eden Prime. Here we get our first taste of combat and the BioWare storytelling we've come to know. You get to chose your dialogue options and the way your character reacts to NPC statements. With each character fully voiced and modeled you get to see an interaction between your Shepard and whoever you are talking to. The options are limited to a wheel and I always felt like the option I wanted to pick was there, the option me as a person would've chosen. However, you don't always get to see a deep interaction. The conversations I had with NPCs and members of my party didn't go too deep. You get to learn about each person and a little bit of their history, how they feel about certain situations and such, but it never has a serious affect on how the character perceives you. You can say and do some nasty things, but if they are a permanent member of your ship or party they won't leave you or behave differently. You get your renegade or paragon points to align your Commander, much like Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic's dark side/light side alignment, but it won't really change much. I played as a soldier class, the most basic character you can choose. You can choose to play as other classes, some skilled in electronics, biotics (magic) etc. as you go on you get to level your character with new abilities and skills, however it doesn't feel like you make an impact on how powerful you become. I found myself depending on new weapons I found, while pumping XP points into health and armor, while auto leveling up my party members. You can't make a right or wrong choice when it comes to leveling up your character.  	The combat in Mass Effect is functional at best. You get a few basic abilities from the start, depending on what class you chose when creating your character. When it comes to shooting weapons the enemies take a lot of bullets and weapons overheat quickly. Later on you can level up your character to be more proficient in certain weapon classes and upgrade weapons to reduce overheating and make them more accurate but it still feels sloppy. The sound during these encounters is rather nice, with biotic abilities going off futuristic weapons being shot around you, you get a sense that these battles mean something, the sound plays a part in making it feel tense. There is also a cover mechanic in the game, where you can walk toward a wall and just snap behind it, but it doesn't change anything about the combat. You can pop out and shoot, but cover is pretty much useless in this game.	The reason this game is great though isn't the combat. It's the story, and the world that BioWare creates. As Commander Shepard you are given the job of taking down Saren. A Turian Spectre gone rouge after Eden Prime. After coming in contact with an ancient beacon Shepard has a vision of the Reapers and Protheans. From then on your main quest is to take down Saren and along the way find out what your vision means. Who are the Protheans and what happened to the extinct race? 	After you are given Spectre status you are free to roam the galaxy and find Saren. Throughout your travels you will come across different alien species, planets, creatures, and technology which will have a codex entry you can listen to or read to tell you a bit of info about it. Each planet you reach will have flavor text and a different characteristic to it. It's size, temperature, etc. will be listed for you to see. It really makes the galaxy you are in feel alive and full of exploration. You are learning about everything and it makes you feel invested in the world they so carefully and passionately created. Every environment you come across feels new, the buildings and structures you enter feel relative to their size and have space to explore, however you won't find too many secrets or hidden areas. It's rather cut and dry where you can and cannot go. It is nice these areas are closed off because it keeps you on the path you need to be on in an already expansive world. Even looking at a map of the galaxy while the gentle music, with its twinkling notes and trance like beats, leaves you with a sense of wonder makes you feel like anything is possible.	Traversing these worlds though can be a pain. You are given a Mako on some worlds to drive around on. The Mako is a 6 wheeled vehicle with a machine gun, cannon and, thrusters to sort of jump on the planet surfaces. Driving this tank is a task. The camera is independent from the controls so going where you want to go is confusing and sometimes a chore, especially on bumpy surfaces. On the planet surfaces you will encounter enemies or different debris to collect. It's not much in variety, including the mini-game you play to collect or hack things. It's a sort of Frogger mini-game where you try to get to the center, while dodging red squares around a rotating circle. It's pretty much the same whether you are hacking or surveying minerals. It's on these planet surfaces where you can find side quests, which are either collectible missions or one-off side missions where you might rescue someone. They don't side track you too much which is very welcoming for side missions which, in other games, can sometimes take longer than you would like to complete.	Mass Effect is a well made game. This game still looks great 10 years after it came out. I played it on PC with Ultra-High graphics turned on. The frame rate held up for the most part with only a few drops either coming in or out of a cut scene. Even when there were multiple enemies on screen with particles and explosions going on the game never seemed to chug or slow down. The controls are pretty intuitive and are easy to get a grasp on. Controller support would've been a welcome sight in this game. I played this game on Steam with mouse and keyboard, which works but it was definitely built for controllers. On Steam the overlay and chat windows do not work. It is an EA game on Steam, which is also a rare sight to see. I played Mass Effect when it came out on Xbox 360 back in 2007. At first glimpse I didn't think much of it, but when I rented it for the first time, it was a game that literally made me rethink games. The storytelling, design, and world building BioWare put into this game made it one of my favorite games. It's not a game without it's faults, it definitely has those. But this is a game where you feel like your Shepard is important, without you, the entire galaxy could be flipped on it's head. It's a game where it makes the player feel like they have a purpose. Even though some of the interactions with NPCs fall flat and feel like no matter what you chose the outcome will be the same, they still make you feel like humanities last hope.	This game still holds a special place in my gaming history and in all video game history. Being the bookend of a trilogy and continuing story arc, Mass Effect does a great job as a launching point. It's a game that most people will appreciate and enjoy. I will always enjoy Mass Effect, I just hope that reporter I punch

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												I Should Go......Are the words that I occasionally see on the faces of people whom I introduce Mass Effect to. Naturally, it's a given response, since this game is a far cry from what many are used to on both the RPG and Shooting front. I remember almost throwing this game into the recycling bin while I had the PS3 version, since I couldn't figure out how to zoom out on the galaxy map (my fault entirely for forgetting that the circle button exists).Sure, the game does present a few faults here and there, such as the awkward shooting/cover mechanics, absurdly long cooldown times for powers, optional yet completely barren side missions, limited auto-save points, [some] overpowered enemy biotics as well as a few other caveats that I won't go into detail here, which can completely cripple someone's interest in Mass Effect. A sad thing, since the feeling of carrying over your complete save to Mass Effect 2 is unparalleled on so many levels. Bioware has always been a dominant forefront for the story driven rpg market, and Mass Effect is no exception. Thus, enjoyment as a whole can be severely limited if the player refrains from making a personal investment in the overall lore, story and characters. And yes, Mass Effect goes above and beyond in providing all three, while also establishing an atmosphere of its own, which makes it stand out heavily among all the other space games on the market. Top-tier Canadian science fiction everybody!Many of the choices you make in this game will impact you later, especially when carrying over your saves to the next two games. Who you save, what you say, when you choose to do missions, which path you follow, undoubtedly adds a lot of "Mass" to the "Effect" of your decisions, and definitely adds weight to what happens later in the first game alone. Plus, the PC port is outstanding, enabling you to use most, if not all of your powers during combat in real time, rather than always opening the power wheel on the console versions. Equipment management and gun modding is also much more direct/less in your face due to the redesigned menu system. The new hacking minigames are also a nice touch as well. It's almost as if PC was Bioware's most prioritized platform from the get-go. Definitely better than the delayed PS3 version, which encountered many lip-sync errors, missing textures and frame rate issues. Also didn't help that it always took 12 seconds to save, where the PC port only requires half a second, with the addition of a very handy quick save button.You'll need to install a few mods and edit the .ini files though if you wish to remove some small hitches, but that can be accomplished easily through the many worthwhile guides for this game (I'd recommend uncapping the game's framerate and installing MEUITM, which allows you to run the game higher than 720p and upscales a lot of old textures). It's not necessary, but the experience is undoubtedly more rewarding with those fixes.I won't go into detail on any of the main story points and characters, since I wish for anyone reading this review who doesn't own the game yet to find out for themselves. Sure, Mass Effect isn't for everybody, and it might seem underwhelming at first for many Star Wars/Doctor Who enthusiasts out there, but the series as a whole quickly makes a name for itself if you give it time, especially if you make it to the third game, and the eventual fourth if you love the series that much : )

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												This game is great fun. I couldn't recommended it more. The graphics are good, the gameplay is engaging and the voice acting is good. Jenifer Hale does a great job voicing fem shep, (don't play the male shep line because it is that good). The great thing about the choices you make in this game is that they carry over into the next two games. There is strong support for this game from the community which is super useful if your suck.Some things (which aren't necessarily bad just noteable):somepeople may find it unusual playing this game without the jump feature (particularly if you havent played a game without it)the game is getting on now and you may need to put it into compatiability mode or give admin rights, and some people may want to tweak a few settings (there are heaps of tweak guides out there)you want to save, lots. even just to save yourself if a very rare glitch happens but its very easy to get sucked into this game and forget to save, and then to lose all your progress. But there are relatively frequent autosaves. It has serious replayabilty too, which is an added bonus. Also, there are dlc for this game one free and one you can pay for both adds to the game but not necessary there is loads of content. i hope you have as much fun playing this game as i have.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Not quite the full kilo MASS EFFECT is a mixed bag of a game: everything about it is good in some ways but not in others. The most notable achievement perhaps is the rich storyline and detailed universe created by the developers (there is plenty to read here -- I started by reading every word but confess to scanning some texts as the game progressed). The graphics are good in parts but not in others (I know this game came out in 2007 but then so did Crysis). The voice acting is overall pretty good and there are plenty of branches to the dialogue trees. And this is where MASS EFFECT’s strengths lie: in the role playing aspects of the game. You’re given the opportunity to be the good guy or the not so good guy, depending on how you wish to play. Less successful is the combat, which, for the most part, failed to engage. Also the side missions are very repetitive and dull. The vehicle you get to drive on numerous occasions bounces around like a drunken bouncy thing, and there are endless elevators that take too long to ascend or descend. Oh, and the UI for selecting skills, weapons etc. is needlessly complex. Overall MASS EFFECT is worth playing but the whole experience is oddly detached and vaguely unsatisfying. I have MASS EFFECT 2 also. I understand it’s much improved on the first.3/5

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												Mass Effect is quite simply my favourite game series. It all started with this first installment which introduces us to an immersive open galaxy where the decisions we make through gameplay and dialogue options shape our journey along throughout our time in the game. You play as a Commander of your own ship and are tasked with bringing a rogue Spectre to justice. Along the way you visit numerous planets and environments with a squad of team mates you recruit along the way. The character interactions between you and your squad truly shape your experience playing the game as you begin to learn about their backgrounds and understand their motivations for fighting alongside you.The plot is straightforward with an engaging villain (the rogue Spectre Saren) and develpos at a steady pace with many more options for side quests that help build and shape the world building, or galaxy building I should say.  Playing as Commander Shepard you have the option to play nicely (paragon) or rather roughly (renegade) while dealing with your dialogue wheel options, allowing to to shape your character's personality. I personally prefer the paragon route.Any downsides I would mention are the somewhat clunky mechanics during fire fights and the difficulty there can sometimes be when you try and fail to take cover. The graphics have aged compared to the more recent installments but  can still be considered decent. I highly reccommend giving the Mass Effect game series a go. It will change your perception of sci-fi RPGs for the better, and not to mention there are two jaw-dropping sequels to sink your teeth into after this one.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												Outstanding Western Rpg from Bioware, Mass Effect has it all, a compelling story, great gameplay and likeable characters that grow on you more and more. Story wise, Mass Effect isn't the best from the Bioware catalogue as I would consider Knights of the Old Republic to be the King there, however that doesn't undermine the fact that Bioware has crafted an original plot without straying too close to Star Wars.  I preferred the gameplay in Mass Effect over KOTOR as the blend of the third person shooter mixed with the rpg elements was a nice touch and I feel Mass Effect is more replayable as a result. There are many ways to build a character in Mass Effect and this felt streamlined and it felt like a nod to classic Rpg's with the typical classes you would find but adding a modern, science fiction twist.  I would thoroughly reccomend Mass Effect to any rpg fan and it proves that Western Rpgs can be just as good if not better than the Japanese counterparts and Bioware truly leads in example of how to create a  masterpiece Rpg with a Western touch.
