number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												Mass Effect is a role-playing shooter in a beautifully realized sci-fi world. It was the second-to-last game made by the – legendary – game studio Bioware, before the inevitable quality decline set in, that occurs when a studio is incorporated into the EA roster.Even though Mass Effect was originally an Xbox 360 exclusive, Bioware did not let the limited hardware hinder the game's potential. The game was a visual masterpiece, and the tight movement and combat naturally inherited from the Unreal Engine played wonderfully into the game's core shooting mechanics. The intense firefights with lasers, explosions, and kinetic powers, kept you at the edge of your seat – but it was the expansive universe, and heavy story elements, that kept you from leaving it.If I were to make a parallel between another much beloved piece of media, I'd say that Mass Effect followed the Matrix formula to a T. Much akin to the Matrix trilogy, the first part of the Mass Effect trilogy is an independent piece that stands on its own, it builds up a mysterious and interesting world, and let's you take it in however much you like – but just like the Matrix trilogy, the second and third parts thoroughly disappoint.Why The Matrix trilogy went the way it did is a mystery only the Wachowskis can answer for, but as for Mass Effect, we can clearly point our fingers at EA and say: “They did it!”. Mass Effect, along with Dragon Age: Origins, were Bioware's final games that showed the brilliance of the studio. The games that followed are little more than fan-service on top of bad writing. Let's not even start with The Old Republic.As for Mass Effect, it's one of the most fleshed out worlds ever created. The game hooks you from the start, and won't let go – even when the credits roll. You're gonna wanna go back, and it's recommended, as the game has twists and turns that will only reveal themselves on second or third playthroughs. I recommend this game to anyone and everyone.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												I've finally got around to beginning the Mass Effect series, and numero uno was a blast. An incredibly immersive, well crafted and believable universe, I found myself happily getting lost in the cultural depth and history created here, of the Geth, Krogan, Turian, Rachni and more. Mass Effect features a wide range of well written, memorable characters (Liara, Wrex, Garrus, Saren, Anderson, Sovereign, could go on), some great clever dialogue and many funny moments, as well as more painful ones as the consequences of your actions play out through the story. One of the best aspects of the game as you progress is simply getting to know your crewmates that you're choosing to work with mission by mission. The music is fantastic, and acts beautifully to create atmosphere and in binding all the various parts of the game together (Vigil, Galaxy Map theme i'm looking at you). For a title released in 2007/2008 the graphics seem to have endured really well, and again fit perfectly with the overall feel of the game. While you're exploring planets be sure to stop and take a few seconds at the summit of a mountain and look out at the vista before you, it's pretty damn gorgeous. Gameplay wise, combat is fun and pretty well balanced, if a little on the easy side. I found biotic abilities particularly enjoyable, there's also a lot of room to customise gear and weapons as you see fit, especially later in the game. Movement is kept varied in space or on land, between exploring new worlds/buildings on foot or by roaming and driving up sheer cliffs in the Mako, hopping around the interior of the Normandy and navigating the Galaxy Map, there is a real and epic sense of scale here (Moon landing included), and the freedom to seek it out.The only slight cons I can think of are somewhat repetitive sidequests; with a bouncy tin tank that has some infamous clunky manoeuvring, and slowpoke elevators (which excellent dialogue and hilarious music almost make up for). The inventory can become a bit tricky to manage. Worlds explored outside of main quests could also be more detailed and fleshed out in terms of content beyond markers on the map. Summary: A brilliant and deeply satisfying narrative experience overall, and I will be coming back for more playthroughs after visiting the next installments of Mass Effect. Just play it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 18, 2013
												I honestly wasn't expecting that this game was going to be as good as it really is. I believe I spent more time going through the codex and every single dialogue option other than the actual combat itself. The story in Mass Effect might feel to some the usual "bad aliens killing everyone in the galaxy" story but, in my opinion there's alot more to it. For me it was like reading a book, the soundtrack along with the cinematics really imerse you into the game. Of course that if you played Mass Effect before the second one and the third one came out, right after getting the ending you knew there will be a sequel. Now, about the combat, it might look and feel like a normal third person run 'n cover shooter but once you get a few hours into the game you'll find a very well polished and easy to use combat system along with squad commands. Some games fail to introduce "psychic" abilities in a way that it doesn't feel "paranormal", that's another thing I really liked about Mass Effect, the way they introduced biotics into the storyline feels "kinda authentic". The roleplaying aspect is really good, from the loot drops (which I believe these aren't random), to the skill "tree" that affects your abilities along the abilities of your fellow ones. The last roleplaying aspect that I really liked was that I think they really managed to pull off some really good "side effects" or more like consequences on the storyline depending on the dialogue options you choose, but my favourite one was with no doubt the one in which you had to decide to save Kaidan or Ashley on Virmire but there's also of course the one about going to bed either with Ashley or Liara. Also, I have to mention that there's TONS of side quests you might come across either when travelling in space or when wandering around the Citadel. The space exploration is kinda 'meh', it basicly is you going from star system to star system and just clicking on planets and scanning them for resources ocasionally finding some asteroids on the background. On the other hand I really liked the planet exploration when you drop on your Mako, going around the mountains and going to key locations, it's something out of the extraordinary but it was fun for me. There's also a "hack" mini-game that happens when you wish to unlock some crates or even recover some artifacts which is kinda appealing, it reminded me of Super Hexagon. I really regret not playing this earlier but I'm really glad I did buy it and finished it, an amazing mix of RPG with third person shooting that excels in pretty much any way if you ask me, I can safely say it is amongst the most engaging game worlds I've ever experienced, give it a try.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
Pros:-Massive galaxy to explore-Immersive roleplaying game experience-Complete skillful voice acting-Intuitive character growth and skills-Fun plot-Original universe with original history and subplots to explore and learn-Entertaining, memorable party members-Two sequels that get even better-Solid standalone game-Comes with the DLC includedCons:-The MAKO-You have to actually endure elevator rides every time.  Bring companions.  Their elevator-only conversations make it less awful.  But it's still frustrating after about the fiftieth time.-Good/evil choices with no middle ground-Mass Effect 3 is not on SteamOverall: This is one of the best roleplaying games in recent history, made even better by the fact that when you finish this one (which takes at least 40 hours), there are two more waiting for you on the other side.  Mass Effect 1 has the most problems technically speaking - particularly when it comes to using the MAKO to explore planetary surfaces.  This becomes tedious and aggravating very quickly.  And, like many roleplaying games, you can be good or evil, but not a mix without sacrificing some of the benefits that are only available to pure good or pure evil characters.That said, the plot is great.  The game runs smoothly with few bugs or glitches, and the character cast is fantastic.  Voice acting is done wonderfully, and you'll recognize the voices of your party characters whenever you hear them in other games just because of how fun they are to listen to.  Wrex is my favorite, but Garrus, Tali, really everybody is fantastic.  The character growth and creation systems are easy and fun to use, and make sense intuitively.  It's a game that welcomes new players and is easy to get immersed in.  One unfortunate problem is that the final game in the trilogy is not currently available on Steam, only on Origin.  This may change at some point, but be aware of this fact before you commit to buying the game here.Not a game to start the week before finals.Bottom Line: Absolute recommend

												I played Mass Effect twice, once with a female engineer Shepard and once with a male vanguard Shepard. But even if you're not familiar with it, this game is a lot of fun for everyone I would say.The character development and the decisions (good/evil) make things interesting and all the different companions really add to the storyline. The vehicle (Mako) is an absolute nightmare but you kinda get used to it and I even spoke of it fondly by the end of the game.The planets and views in this game are absolutely stunning, even if you don't have the best graphics (like me). I started Mass Effect 2 now because I loved this game so much.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
												This is the start of something special. Three games and 100 hours later I sat back and thought "wow - that was a hell of a ride". A superior game in terms of story telling and character development, combat is a second consideration in my opinion, far outpaced by getting to known the Mass Effect galaxy. If you want an RPG adventure that takes you to some amazing locations with a detailed and intriguing story full of consequences for your actions and a good dosage of humour and sorrow, start your journey here and I don't hink you'll regret it. Be warned that this is not a heavily action packed game - there are long periods of dialogue and some people won't want to be burdened with that. This game *might* not be for the action hungry.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												The game that started one of the biggest sci-fi adventures in gaming history. It's got everything required to make it a classic; interesting and fun characters with unique cultures,  philospohical questions and moral dilemmas, all wrapped around a well-paced and intriguing story (in my opinion the best in the series). It is a wonderful universe that is really easy to get into, though there are a couple of hurdles that really need to be overcome to get a truly great experience out of this. Throughout a lot of the game, characters will spend a LOT of time explaining things to you, like how cultures work and such.  The story, as I mentioned earlier is great, but the gameplay is not. Combat is fairly clunky, cover system is awkward, every gun feels the same, a lot of enemies are braindead and just run up to you with no regard for their own personal safety. Not exactly the highlight of the game, to put it mildly. The Mako, the vehicle which you use for explo-ration as well as a lot of missions, isn't much better either. It's awkward, handles very poorly and is very boring in use for combat, it's generally used for padding outgame length. Still, it is all in all an amazing game, and gets a 9.1/10 from me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
												For any gamer out there, Mass Effect is a must play.  This game is a third-person, role playing, story-driven shooter and it successfully accomplishes all it sets out to be.  The main storyline clocks in at around 13 hours but the game is packed with other missions and planets to explore on your own time.  Throughout the exploration and firefights, you will surely become attached to certain characters, so decisions you'll have to make later will put you in a cold sweat.  Shooting mechanics in this game are solid, but sometimes feel lacking.  As for the leveling system, not all the skill points you earn feel as if they've gone to any use since there is such a large array of skills and plenty of point slots necessary to fill so as to reach the next power.  All in all, this game is highly recommended to anyone looking for a fantastic single player game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												I was struggled for a very long time if I should buy this game or not.I regret that I didn't buy it sooner.It is one of the Top 10 best games I have played. The gameplay might be a bit monotonus, but rewarding items, the story and your possible decisions make up for it.When I first played it I was AMAZED by how well every detail is described. Why the machines and weapons work and what they do. What every alien species backstory is and why they behave like they behave.It's a whole new universe to discover. I haven't seen any game before that cared so much about filling every logical hole and describing so much details, expanding the story to such great amounts. Awesome!Also, if you're a fan of astronomy, you'll love it so much more. Enjoy the most epic views of standing on a planets moon, being on a planet of a binary star system, or watch thousands of meteors raining down from the sky.As a fan of science, you might notice some physical details which aren't correct as they are. Like planets temperature described as going below the point of absolute zero (-273,18°C is not possible), our local sun shining yellow in space, or other little details. Nothing what would involve gameplay or bother you in some way.All in all, great game. I love it, I am a fan of the Mass Effect Universe now.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14
												I picked this up during the X-mas sale and only recently installed it. I generally don't play shooters, but Mass Effect has a healthy dose of searching and exploring and story. I've always played "lurkers" in games, rather kill from the shadows. }:>I chose the Infiltrator class (I know, my friends are totally shocked) even though I read from several sources that the sniper rifle was a pain to master. It is a pain, but I can live with that. Took me more than a few occasions to unlearn that the spacebar does not make you jump... probable the only thing that bothers me so far. Because when I explore I like to jump and climb on things. I'm enjoying it very much so far at least I would hope so considering that I logged 6.6 hours on my first night of playing. :)So yeah, I'd recommend it.PS: sinewav put up a nice beginner's guide that explains the classes pretty well and what he considers their strengths and weaknesses, recommendations on how difficult newbs might find each class, on the crew you should pair up with them to fill in the holes. And I think he did a good job of it without filling it with spoilers. You can find it here: 


Guide for New Mass Effect Players 
A Guide for Mass Effect
By: sinewav

			This guide will provide tips and first hand experience on how to have the best experience playing Mass Effect 1. I will also address how to best mold your character for ME2 and ME3 without providing any spoilers.		


EDIT:  Since I have a relatively new machine, ME wouldn't even launch on first attempt, a quick search will reveal 2 things that can solve this: Set the .exe to run in Admin mode and to download a legacy Nvidia driver. The first one worked for me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												I'm recamending this game because of all the Sci-Fi adventure games this one is at the top; it really captures the feeling of Star Trek, a feeling utterly missed by every Star Trek game. But with that said, this game is far from perfect, mostly because it is faced with some massive annoyances: -Unskippable and unpausable cut scenes -A terrible autosave system -Boss's that are just enemies with a massive health bar  -Broken Quick Save SystemThese may not sound like little problems, but lets look at what they all cause. OK lets say you die, not that rare, there are a lot of enemies that can 1 to 2 hit you if you can't see them, this means you are relying on the last save point, but since the environments are so big that means the last auto save could be 30mins ago. ALSO, if there are any cutscenes that occur your going to have to go through them again because unlike 99% of all other games that would autosave your progress after a cutscene, in this game thats not the case. BUT wait there is quick saving right? Wellllll, quick saving only works if there are no enemies, so if there is a string of enemies a long a 30 min trek you are♥♥♥♥♥♥out of luck my friend. The game should keep track of 3 quick saves and allow you to quick save at any point that, that way i don't need to repeat the same 45 mins of my life over again like some lamer version of Groundhogs Day and if I quick save a death by accident I could use the previous quick save. Also, the last boss is a measure of your patients as he is health bar Mcgee, not hard, just repetative and boring.Overall Its a good game, I just wise it didn't make me feel like I was getting in the way of it's story all the time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
												For any gamer out there, Mass Effect is a must play.  This game is a third-person, role playing, story-driven shooter and it successfully accomplishes all it sets out to be.  The main storyline clocks in at around 13 hours but the game is packed with other missions and planets to explore on your own time.  Throughout the exploration and firefights, you will surely become attached to certain characters, so decisions you'll have to make later will put you in a cold sweat.  Shooting mechanics in this game are solid, but sometimes feel lacking.  As for the leveling system, not all the skill points you earn feel as if they've gone to any use since there is such a large array of skills and plenty of point slots necessary to fill so as to reach the next power.  All in all, this game is highly recommended to anyone looking for a fantastic single player game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												Very good Sci-fi RPG.You choose a class and level your characters like any other RPG game, but the combat is a real-time 3rd person shooter. Building and strengthing your character is just as important as your ability to dodge enemy fire, use cover, and score headshots for critical damage. The game also has different difficulties settings to choose from in case you need to lower it. You also have 2 teammates with you at any given time.Aside from combat; you can literally spend hours at a time just going around exploring, talking to people, and reading codexes you come across (bits of information about certain guns or whatever). Some people love this stuff, others hate it, so its purely preference if you'll like it or not. The main highlight of this game though is the option to choose your own path/dialogue. You can pretty much apologize to someone, agree to disagree, or sometimes just straight up punch them in their face. Then the next time you meet this person down the road, IF you meet them again, they'll remember how the previous conversation went and it affects the feel of the game. It might even open or close off certain things. The overall core storyline of the game is the same though, you can't change that. It's also a trilogy. Certain decisions you make can span from game 1 game into the next if you transfer save files.It's a well-made game for its genre (and an even better trilogy). So if you're not into these type of games (Sci-fi / shooter / Action RPG / deep storytelling with alot of decisions and information/lore) then you simply won't like it.Cons: A few times playing this game I had to load an older save file due to some weird glitches happening. Maybe 3 times in 50+ hours of playing. (only lost a total of 10 minutes of playtime or so). Other than that the game ran fine for me.

												Mass Effect is an space adventure RPG like no other, one that will stand the test of time long after people forget about the ME 3 endings. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												In my opinion this game is the best of the Series, because it's the least streamlined one with the most choices and freedom of play and with the least amount of completely linear nerfhearding tunnelmaps. The combat in ME3 is better, but the cost is too high. Pro:+ Lots of different guns and armor with a ton of different mods. Lots of useless ones too. + Lots of dialogue and very few cutscenes. + Pretty funny dialogue choices at times, especially the Renegade options can be pretty funny and abusive. + Big square planet maps & the Mako. The only game in the ME series with a tactical choice. + Experience points for Kills. Time to go hunting for Thresher Maws & Geth! + Unlimited ammo, but with overheating and recoil. Nice diversity of guns and mechanics. + Import of previous 'veteran' characters.. Practically no level limit..  + Lots of skills. Cons:- The dialogue choices doesn't quite reflect what's being said. Quite often far from it. It's a gamble. How's that RPG?- Quite often different dialogue options leads to the same result or none at all. Just for show. - Once you are overloaded you can't sort through your entire inventory to scrap the least useful ones in favor of the last additions, which often happens to be a lot better than anything else you've got.. (Bleh, Of course). - No three-some!! Just like any other BioWare game it enforce ancient and unnatural monogamous relationships.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												I highly recommend this game for anyone who is interested in a FPS game with a rich story.You can explore the milky way galaxy with many solar systems, all having their own planets. The main storyline is engaging and fun, and the side quests are meaningful and often change the dialogue you can exchange with other characters. The romantic subplots are also very interesting and allow insight into the background of your characters. The option to play as a Paragon or a Renegade based on the qualities of your actions is also a nice dynamic allowing moral feedback for your character. All in all, one of the best games I have ever played and definitely has a high replay value.

												I bought Mass Effect recently for my run through of the entire series, and I have to say, I am impressed. I expected a really bad game that I would play "for the story." I was wrong. This was an absolutely great experience. There are a few things that were frustrating, such as the repetative land rover missions, and the way the Citidel was laid out. The Citidel is your center hub of trade and activity, for people that don't know much about the Mass Effect universe. The story was fantastic, the characters so belivable, however the combat was a bit rough due to the sheer age of the game. It doesn't take long to get used to the outdated combat and graphics, and once that is aside, everything is so much fun. One of the best RPGs of it's kind.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												Good game, not as good as its sequals in my opinion but it sets off the story nicely. It is very satisfying to be able to use the same character you have created through all three games and to have a story that continues in Mass Effect 2 and 3. This game has action, interesting enemies, weapons and NPC's as well as a very interesting, and sometimes hilarious, relationship build-up with a member of your team. Just one of the reasons to do a second runthrough of the game is to hook up with another NPC than the first time.The only negative I can think of is that there is no guide to how to move around or use combat. A training instruction before the real action starts would have helped me from constantly dying early on. Something I appreciated to Mass Effect 2 were the "Combat Training" videos that guided you to understanding how to fight.

content:
Posted: February 14
												I picked this up during the X-mas sale and only recently installed it. I generally don't play shooters, but Mass Effect has a healthy dose of searching and exploring and story. I've always played "lurkers" in games, rather kill from the shadows. }:>I chose the Infiltrator class (I know, my friends are totally shocked) even though I read from several sources that the sniper rifle was a pain to master. It is a pain, but I can live with that. Took me more than a few occasions to unlearn that the spacebar does not make you jump... probable the only thing that bothers me so far. Because when I explore I like to jump and climb on things. I'm enjoying it very much so far at least I would hope so considering that I logged 6.6 hours on my first night of playing. :)So yeah, I'd recommend it.PS: sinewav put up a nice beginner's guide that explains the classes pretty well and what he considers their strengths and weaknesses, recommendations on how difficult newbs might find each class, on the crew you should pair up with them to fill in the holes. And I think he did a good job of it without filling it with spoilers. You can find it here: 


YouTube™ Video: Mass Effect - Ending Song 

			Views: 2,620,314		

			Jack Wall and Sam Hulick -M4 Part 2 (Faunts)		

EDIT:  Since I have a relatively new machine, ME wouldn't even launch on first attempt, a quick search will reveal 2 things that can solve this: Set the .exe to run in Admin mode and to download a legacy Nvidia driver. The first one worked for me.

content:
Posted: January 5
												This one had the best gameplay in the series in my opinion. Probably going to get lynched for saying that but it's true. This is the only Mass Effect that is actually an RPG. They managed to make a super awesome shooter RPG with 6 different classes and an adequately complex levelling system and inventory management. And for Mass Effect 2 they threw all of that out the window, removed the whole inventory thing completely and made the levelling system the simplest any RPG has ever had, which is why I hesitate to call Mass Effect 2 or 3 an RPG.This one also has the best story, and so it's pretty much better than Mass Effect 2 and 3 in every way, except for graphics. 10/10 best Mass Effect game to date, fingers crossed for Andromeda.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3
												Mass Effect, released in 2007, was one of the "essential games" for the Xbox 360 early on, just like Oblivion and Halo 3. And it shows, in a good way, of course. Mass Effect is a Bioware RPG set in the Milky Way where humans are a "new species" on the galactic stage and they have to prove themselves. Also, there's a bunch of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ flashlight robots named "Geth" that are doing NEFARIOUS DEEDS and you gotta stop them. It's alright.This game pioneered the cancerous "dialogue wheel" in games, where you're only give a vague idea of what your character is actually going to say. Sometimes it'll be wildly different in tone and phrasing than the vague description implies, too. It's seriously one of the worst things to ever plague RPGs. However, even though I despise dialogue wheels, it's... not as bad as say, Fallout 4's, as the different choices actually say different things. Anyways, the characters you're talking to are actually quite interesting. Except for Ashley.Combat plays like a class-based third-person shooter with unlimited ammo (which they removed in the second game like total dip♥♥♥♥♥) and with squad tactics. It's pretty good, and there's a lot of ways to approach a combat situation. Whether you're lifting someone up with telekinetic powers and launching him into a wall, removing someone's shields with tech powers and shooting him with a pistol, or just spraying and praying, it's plenty of fun. Personally, my favorite classes are usually anything but Soldier. I played Sentinel a lot, back when I had this game on the XBAWX and in my most recent run.The story isn't god-tier, but it's not bad. I'd say it's better than your average game's story, although that's not really saying much. You can see the twists and turns coming if you pay a little attention, which isn't hard to do considering how blatant some things are.The morality system is somewhat unique compared to your average sliding scale. Heroic and merciful actions raise your "Paragon" meter, a representation of how "good" you are. Selfish, brutal, or generally dickish actions raise your "Renegade" meter, a reprentation of how "bad" you are. The meters are separate, though, so a few brutal actions won't exactly tarnish the reputation of a stand-up hero, and a few kind words won't make everyone think you're a holy man if you, say, genocided and entire race and shot an innocent man. Personally, I think the game is a bit broad on defining Paragon and Renegade, because Renegade actions can sometimes be easily morally justifiable and intelligent, rather than just wanton slaughter. For example, say A killed a bunch of B one time. A says it was a misunderstanding and they totally won't do it again if you let them go. People from B say it would be a bad idea and A is lying. The Paragon action would be to let A go, and the Renegade action would be to kill A. Logically, killing A wouldn't be a "bad" thing due to them murdering a bunch of B at one point. But I digress.I give Mass Effect a Great/5.also I didn't proofread this lol

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												What can I say about this game that already hasn't been said?I'll try and do this game justice with what I'm about to write.The story is brilliant and sets up the rest of the following games very well. Your choices matter and will affect the end result further down the line.Character development is strong. With Garrus being my favourite team member. Seriously, that Turian is awesome. Male Shepard and Garrus are the best bromance I've ever seen in a game.The RPG elements are in depth and gives you the opportunity to mould your character in any way you want.The combat is slightly lacklustre, but it can be forgiven and doesn't detract from the core game.One main negative that a lot of people didn't like was the Mako. Sure it was ungainly and could almost climb near vertical cliffs. But I rather enjoyed the exploration it opened up for you.You could travel to a planet, land on it and search locations noted on your map. Most of these locations didn't add anything to the main story line, but for me it brought me into the world more, it added lore and detail to the world.Mass Effect is starting to look slightly outdated these days, though that is a given considering that it's over 8 years old from its first release date.Buy this game, just for the fact that it'll suck you in and prepare you for the awesome ride that is Mass Effect 2 and most of 3. (I won't go into the details of 3 here, but I'm sure most people know of what I'm on about).

content:
Posted: February 28, 2012
												Mass Effect is a game that is synonymous with quality. A role playing game set in a future of interstellar space travel, Mass Effect makes effective use of player choices and a lawful/chaotic alignment system all balanced with a class-based third person shooter combat system.The storytelling in the game is top notch  with memorable characters and many instances where player choice has a huge effect on the story's outcome. Many of these choice are also carried over into the sequel Mass Effect 2 as well as Mass Effect 3. It's rare that a game is conceived as a trilogy and even rarer when it turns out to be a masterpiece. If you've not played this game yet, you owe it to yourself to do so!

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												A really good action/RPG game in every aspect. The story, voice acting, graphics, sound, music and gameplay are all good.The game seems like a fusion of Dragon Age, KOToR and Neverwinter Nights all wrapped up together in a wonderful package. If you liked any of those games, you will undoubtedly like this!You follow the path of Shepard (male or female depending on your preference) in a desperate attempt to save the galaxy from the ominous Reapers. Along the way you recruit companions, fall in love and make tough decisions. It also allows for a little exploration in form of the many sidequests. You get to select from a multitude of different classes and level-up and outfit the characters however you want. It also features a squad ordering system (although basic) to position your squad tactically. The combat is in the form of an over-the-shoulder third person, cover-based shooter. It works well here when combined with your squads various strengths and weaknesses.All-in-all, a very good game that I would recommend to everyone interested in the format.Jimbo Rating: 8/10

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												+Female Shepard, voiced by Jennifer Hale+Storyline & writing by Drew Karpshyn+Decision-making with real consequences - completed save file can be imported into the sequels+Atmosphere, environments, artwork+RPG systems+Biotic powers+Voice acting+Depth-Vehicle exploration - terrible physics and controls make navigation a constant pain-Inventory is a chore to manage-Wonky shooting mechanics-60-second elevator rides-Copy+pasted side quest maps-Useless collectibles-Bad achievements (minimum 3 playthroughs, discourages varying teammates)Bottom line: Mass Effect 2 and 3 are some of the very best games of the generation. Although the original lacks the polish and overall fun factor of its sequels, it is absolutely worth investing in this world, its characters, and your own personal Commander Shepard from the very beginning.7.5/10

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												As someone who's more of a FPS player, I occasionaly like playing RPG's because of the immersive experience they deliver. I only played Fallout 3 and New Vegas aside from Mass Effect so I don't have much experience in these type of games but here goes. The number one reason I kept playing through Mass Effect was the story. The game really let's you control how the story develops while being very interesting at the same time. It was very hard to get in to (haha..) and can be overwhelming for someone who has never played an RPG before, but when you get the hang of the skills, guns and inventory it will be pretty fun. Although I have to say I don't like the combat apart from the usable skills. Yes, you have a plethora of options for your guns, but the guns themselves stay the same through out the game: pistol, shottie, rifle and sniper + grenades. Maybe because I liked the skills more I didn't like the gunplay that much. If you like modding your gun (attachments+ammo type) you probably would like this game but I liked the Fallout 3 weapon system more. The story blows you away and that's what counted the most for me. I liked doing side missions a lot more than combat, but that's me. TL;DR: Want a great story +♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of upgrade options + items (although they're pretty much the same items with better stats)? Buy this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Totally needed to re-write this review.Mass Effect, the first installment in what was to become Bioware's crown jewel and redefine the gaming communities understanding of dynamic decision making. Personally ME1 is my least favorite of the series but without a doubt it is still a wonderful experience that left me with fond memories and stuck with me throughout my gaming life. I am going to write this review as if describing it's pros and cons to somebody who has never heard of or played Mass Effect, so bear with me:The first part of what makes Mass Effect so perfectly immersive to the player is that they all but become Commander Shepard himself/herself, choosing their name, gender, appearance, history, combat style and how they react to their environment, in this the game has not only a very high immersion factor but an even higher replay factor as well, playing the game again and making different choices only to see how the world and it's characters react and how it will impact the story in the future sequels thanks to a very well-versed save transfer system.The gameplay is a third-person perspective utilizing a cover system for combat, and while this cover system is merely a pioneer for the much tightened cover mechanics in Mass Effect 2+3 it was still rather unique at the time and generally unexpected for an RPG title. By pressing "space" (I don't remember what the default key is, so I'm just assuming it's space) the player can take cover in the environment to reduce incoming fire. I found it to be a unique aspect at the time and I was more than a bit disappointed that it wasn't utilized further, but as I said ME1's cover system was a "beta" for lack of a better word and paved the way for the perfected combat systems in the sequels.Mass Effect's story is compelling, made even more so by the fact that you yourself are the famous Commander Shepard and it is up to YOU, not some pre-determined protagonist, but YOU to proceed through the invasive forces of rogue synthetic drones to chase down a defected Spectre and put a cork in the bunghole of his plans all the while accompanied by a cast of lovable, memorable and very well-rounded allies.Some aspects of gameplay however were not all that good and I felt were a blemish on what could have been an otherwise perfect game. And this flaw has a name, the Mako. The Mako is your supposedly "trusty" all-terrain vehicle that you utilize in every single mission to reach your objective before you and your chosen squadmates proceed on foot. To quit dancing around the issue: the Mako is a clumsy and thorough mess. It controls like an old shoe and it has a horrible habit of overreacting to the terrain, spiraling out of control and more often than it should flies into environmental hazards. For this reason I was ever so thankful that vehicle sequences have never been looked into again for the Mass Effect series.A secondary flaw was inventory management: Scarcely a single RPG game can exist without armor and weapons that you pick up in your travels, and of course Mass Effect has this function as well. But managing the inventory and all your loot feels like an afterthought on the developers end, with no filters to sort your items through it ends up being a tedious waste of time to decide what to keep, what to equip on who and what to convert to omni-gel (which is some magical lotion you rub on electronic locks to open doors and containers to find even MORE crap). Without the nightmarish inventory management and the over-glorified brick known as the Mako I would say that Mass Effect is a near-perfect game despite it's smaller flaws.So in conclusion: Mass Effect, while personally I feel being the least enjoyable of the trilogy, is a brilliant game put together by ingenious writers and programmers, and remains to this day the opening chapter of one of the most industry-changing and cultrally influential series' on todays market. If you haven't played Mass Effect yet I sincerely recommend giving it a go, and I can personally guarantee that you will not leave disappointed.

content:
Posted: April 3
												Of all the Mass Effect games, this is only one which can be considered a true RPG with all the standard RPG fare intact.While the other entries in the series do a good job of personifying the Good (ME2), the Bad (ME3) and the Ugly (Andromeda), the original Mass Effect is the most distinct of the series - focusing less on the combat and more on traditional RPG mechanics and exploration of the galaxy.Graphically the game still looks good, albeit for a game which came out in 2007, although the combat feels dated unless you are of the Biotic God persuasion - although it does have elements which were sad losses from subsequent games in the form of greater squadmate controls and using lots of powers.Most importantly for a Mass Effect game, the writing of Mass Effect 1 is in another plane of existance compared to the later offerings, although Mass Effect 2 is still well written, and the depth of world building and genuine diversity (OF PERSONALITY) and memorability of the squadmates is excellent.If you want a sci-fi RPG that's well written, with a universe that you can, and will, get sucked into and fall in love with then Mass Effect is for you. However, this is debatably the high point for the franchise and rather than loving you tenderly and settling down happily ever after, the series will sour later on and leave you with a nasty taste in the mouth if you follow it through to the conclusion.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												(Keep in mind that I have over 100 hours on Origin and another 100 hours on Xbox, with a total of 9 full playthroughs across all three games with plenty more playthroughs on the other games.)I have tons of games in my library and love most of them, I've been holding off reviewing a game until I really felt I understood every aspect of the game and done all there is to do. Mass Effect is my absolute favorite series and will be until my death, it is an amazing game and has a beautifully crafted storyline. In this review I will go into detail on most aspects of the game and will explain both the good parts of the game as well as the shortcomings of it. I will keep this review as spoiler free as possible as well.Storyline:Right from the beginning of the game, even in the character creation, you feel like you are really in this universe. It really immerses you into the world and lore of the game. As you play through the game the storyline may seem to slow a bit as you’re doing your side quests and exploration but it will always feel like you’re doing something to help advance personal storylines of people that will play some role in Shepard’s mission. As you play through the other games in this series these storylines arc out more and more and intertwine in ways that you wouldn’t imagine. It is truly the single best part of the game and completely makes the game.Gameplay:The gameplay can be sort of clunky at times, especially during fights. The cover mechanic is a nice feature and is prevalent in all three games but can be glitch and you can end up doing something that’ll get you killed on accident. Perhaps the single worst part of this game is the driving and exploring in the M35 Mako which is the car you’ll find yourself in very frequently. It is the only thing that makes me dread another playthrough. The control scheme for it is very clunky and takes a LOT of practice to eventually get down. Other than that, the questing and interaction with NPC’s feels very natural and seamless. Everything that happens is there for a reason and nothing really feels out of place.Graphics:For a late 2007 game the graphics are pretty much on par and there isn’t too much to praise or criticize. Personally I don’t pay much attention to graphics and care a lot more about storyline and gameplay. Even though the textures and graphics aren’t that good the lore and storyline more than make up for the lack of amazing graphics.Lore:The lore of this game is completely amazing and in-depth. There is so much to the lore in this game that even I, someone who has read three of the four books and read the codex multiple times, still doesn’t know everything there is to know. Everything that has happened in the game has some amount of information behind it. I could go on for hours about all the technology and alien races in the game but I intend to keep this review somewhat short. I honestly can’t explain everything there is, the only way to truly experience is to play it for yourself.Rating: 9.5/10

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												My hour count may be low on steam, but on 360 I've played 7 full playthroughs with and all achievements unlockedThis game is a modern classic. It was 7th gen's KotOR.Remarkeable voice acting, atmosphere and story.The universe is on par with stories like Star Trek and even Star Wars with clear inspiration from those universes. This is easily one of the best, if not THE best scifi RPG out there. Its a great series, if you exclude ME3.I'll sum up what makes this masterpiece great in a simple list fornPROS:-Great voice acting-Great characters and villains-Although the Reapers are somwhat generic "ancient evils" they're still very interesting-The fully voiced protagonist with two genders shows how much work they put into the dialogue and making it as emersive as possible.-leads into a great trilogy (excluding the second half of ME3)-all races are interesting with lore behind them-different planets and have their own culture and feel. Lower-Citadel is a robust cyberpunk-like underworld where anything goes while Noveria feels like the Hoth we never got to explore (until SWTOR came along)-the atmosphere throughout the game is strong. You really do feel like the captain of a spaceship, exploring the universe and learning new thingsCONS:-meh gameplay. Significantly improved in ME2-graphical glitches present in this version and vary between person to person (judging by community posts)-Kaiden is almost as bad as Alistair-A lot of your choices don't really matter. The game gives you the illusion of choice. It make impact ME2 somewhat, but the choices you make in ME1 and 2 make no difference whatsoever in 3-Male Shepherd in this game has a very wooden voice actor. Femshep does a much better job. Mark Meer improves his acting in ME2-Shepherd overall isn't a very interesting character after the 10 minute intro. You can choose his/her origin story which is great but it's only loosely referenced in the game and it doesn't make as much an impact as your origin does in Dragon Age: Origins (another great RPG by BioWare)-most of the time, you're only fighting Geth which is a shame since the galaxy is booming with much more life. It gets stale seeing the same model fall over and over when you could be fighting a limitless amount of different species. Some planets let you fight rachni and krogan but these moments are few and far between. It feels like wasted potential. Again, ME2 improves on this.To sum it all up, it's a flawed masterpiece. The atmosphere, story, and characters are fantastic but the ho-hum gameplay and wooden protagonist leave a lot to be desired. ME2 is an overall better game but this game remains my favorite in the series because it gives you a sense of curiosity and wonder that only few games manage to give me.8.5/10

content:
Posted: April 8, 2014
												Mass Effect is quite simply an awesome game. It holds up well over time because of its story, though for a circa 2006-2007 title it still looks all right. There is quite a bit of detail, and the character models are distinctive if stiff by next-gen standards. But the story. As Commander Shepherd (there's a metaphor for you), you suspect an elite inter-galactic covert operative named Saren has gone rogue and is in league with - something - in some kind of nefrarious activity against the galaxy. Signs of this activity are indicated by the growing presence of the militaristic Geth civilization, an AI-driven robotic organization (more will be discovered about them as the game progresses). Shepherd is tasked with investigating Saren. Along the way, you'll uncover secret military bases, testing labs, strange alien creatures (not all of them hostile!) corrupted intergalactic politicians, and allies of the most unexpected sort. The game starts slowly. If you are hoping to get some shooting action right away, you do (The Prologue - Eden Prime). But once the Prologue is finished, the action devolves into a snooze-fest of non-combat missions on the Citadel. You'll want to do most if not all of them, as they are an easy way to level-up early in the game, but could leave some who are hoping for more action disappointed. If you can make it past the Citadel missions, you'll get your own ship and commence on the real adventures. There is the scripted main story, which involves visiting three or four systems (some only appear later in the game). There are what I'll call the Character side missions: if you talk to the crew on your ship, they'll share parts of their past with you, some of which will provide the option for additional missions. And there is the option to simply explore the galaxy. There are a large number of star 'clusters', each with multiple planetary 'systems' that hide many different artifacts and resources; the discovery of either gives you money or points toward leveling up or both. In each system there is at least one planet that can be landed on and explored using the armored Mako Rover. The pattern is quite similar for each landing: land, explore, fight (usually), then leave. Fortunately the terrain and environments vary between planets varies quite a bit, even if the older graphics don't allow much terrain detail. There are ice planets, desert planets, lush earth-like planets. Even thoug hyou are wearing an environmental bio-suit, not every planet is safe to explore on foot. There are some planets that are level 1 or level 2 hazards: stay out of the Mako too long, and you'll risk dying as hazard intensifies. Picking your squad is actually one of the tougher challenges of the game. For each mission - combat or exploration - you are allowed to bring two crew members with you to make up your squad. At its peak, you will have six crew members to choose from, each with a different skill set. Who you need depends on your mission. For planetary exploration, you'll want to take someone good in Electronics and Hacking to opening any encrypted containers you might find is easy, as well as someone good in combat in case you run into any trouble. Facing alien life-forms? Taking along one of the biotics experts along might be a good idea. They are not as good in a firefight as somebody with a better combat rating, so evaluate your risks carefully.While there are a wide variety of weapons available, they will all look different but every genre feels the same as you fire  -i.e. all assault rifles fire the same, sniper rifles fire the same, etc. The difference is in the amount of damage they cause, how large the recoil is, how long it takes for the weapon to over-heat. The weapon specification system is actually quite deep, with the ability to option and upgrade weapons with a variety of in-game add-ons that enhance some of the weapon's abilities for a trade-off (choose tungsten rounds for high damage, for instance, but the weapon will overheat sooner).Combat is quite simple, being of the point-and-shoot variety, with (on PC) right-clicking to aim. There is a 'snap to cover' that involves no hotkeys. Simply move toward cover, and your character will snap into cover. Right-clicking from cover allows you to aim and shoot from cover. Most of the time this works well - not brilliant, but well. There are the inevitable times that you will be running to avoid getting hit with toxic puke or something similar and you will snap to cover when you really don't want to - and you will die in the process. Save often.In the process of getting to know your crew, there will be options in conversation for meaningful exploration of feelings and events happening around you in the game. In two cases (perhaps more) there is an option to 'romance' the other character. Any kind of result here is only obtained after painstaking going through a large number of coversations and giving 'correct' answers to questions and issues. So if you're hoping for some quick R-rated video-game 'action', look elsewhere. Who you choose is entirely up to you.Which leads to one of the most important elements of Mass Effect's conversation game-play, and the key to its high replay value: choice. There are about a dozen places in the game where you are required to make a choice that will impact how the game progresses. While the core ending involving the fate of the galaxy may remain the same, how you get there has many circuitous routes. Who do you save? Who do you spare? Who do you kill? Do you engage in conflict, or try to talk your way out? Choice and consequence is felt through-out the game, and ever-present in the final third of the game - even after the final fight / battle is over, there is yet another choice to be made. Put all of this together effectively, which Mass Effect does, and you have an amazing Role Playing Game that will take you on an immersive cinematic ride that many games have trouble simulating, let alone achieveing at this level. Mass Effect is a Massive Achievement for RPG's that continues to hold its place in the RPG Hall of Fame, despite its age. Postscript on bugs: There have been reports of a variety of bugs with the PC port of this game. My game would crash upon loading save files; deleting the Shader Cache in the MassEffectConfig application fixed that (had to do it every time I loaded the game, but it was worth it). I also had the famous black-pixelated-block player textures on certain missions that only seems to afflict users with AMD processors. Fortunately there is an easy workaround. If you are having a problem with this game, search the internet. Chances are, you are not alone!

content:
Posted: April 3
												Of all the Mass Effect games, this is only one which can be considered a true RPG with all the standard RPG fare intact.While the other entries in the series do a good job of personifying the Good (ME2), the Bad (ME3) and the Ugly (Andromeda), the original Mass Effect is the most distinct of the series - focusing less on the combat and more on traditional RPG mechanics and exploration of the galaxy.Graphically the game still looks good, albeit for a game which came out in 2007, although the combat feels dated unless you are of the Biotic God persuasion - although it does have elements which were sad losses from subsequent games in the form of greater squadmate controls and using lots of powers.Most importantly for a Mass Effect game, the writing of Mass Effect 1 is in another plane of existance compared to the later offerings, although Mass Effect 2 is still well written, and the depth of world building and genuine diversity (OF PERSONALITY) and memorability of the squadmates is excellent.If you want a sci-fi RPG that's well written, with a universe that you can, and will, get sucked into and fall in love with then Mass Effect is for you. However, this is debatably the high point for the franchise and rather than loving you tenderly and settling down happily ever after, the series will sour later on and leave you with a nasty taste in the mouth if you follow it through to the conclusion.

In this well balanced RPG game, you call the shots as you lead a crack team of warriors on a mission to save the galaxy. And while you're at it, you might as well get Mass Effect 2, cuz you WILL be buying it after you get hooked on ME1. So save yourself the trouble and do it now. xD

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Mass Effect is an incredible game, and the beginning to one of my favorite games of all time. This game has some of the most interesting characters in any game, and even after playing all three games in the series I still feel a connection to my squadmates. The replay value of this game is incredible as well, as you find yourself wanting to make different choices to see the effect on the outcome.That being said, there are issues with the game. Specifically, the combat in the first Mass Effect is less than stellar. It isnt terrible, but the second and third games improve on it so heavily that it is hard to come back and play the first. Plus, the RPG elements of the game can get overwhelming (picking up hundreds of different types of armor, a lot of which you cant use) and managing your inventory can be a chore. The other big issue I have with this game (specifically for the Steam version) is the lack of controller support. This game originally came out on Xbox 360, yet the Steam version only allows keyboard and mouse. There are mods you can do to hack in support for controllers, but they are buggy and not even close to the polish of the Xbox 360 version. The Mouse+Keyboard controls are fine, but it bothers me that I can't use my input form of choice.Overall though, this game is amazing. Highly recommend.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
rating: worth buying at full pricescore: 7.5/10 - goodsimilar games: Deus Ex Human Revolution, Dragon Age Origins, Spec Ops The Linetags: RPG, character development, story-driven, relationships, dull gameplayI finally got the motivation to play Mass Effect. After so many years of praise for this franchise I just said to myself that I HAVE to at least play it for a fair amount of time. I tried playing this game some years ago but the extremely dull gameplay immediately turned me off and male Shephard isn't really interesting as a character. This playthrough I started as female Shephard (suggested by many people) and that really made the game more interesting, but before I talk about the good things I want to talk about the dull gameplay.I keep saying the word dull because that's the most fair way to describe it I think, because its not really "bad", but you have no decisions to do as a player, you don't have to use your brain, you just keep shooting. That does not mean that it cant be fun though, but for me it wasn't. Sometimes it was really annoying, sometimes it had its moments, sometimes is was just consuming my time. The game would really benefit if they would reduce the combat and focus on characters instead, but I guess you have to please the mass market. The problems with the combat are the following: Enemies are bullet sponges, sound design is bad, AI is terrible, you have no interesting abilities, only your squad has, and weapons are unsatisfying to use due to ugly recoil and bad hit feedback. Its not terrible, considering the age of the game, but it really drags the game down.Another bad thing are the side-missions which are nothing but filler, completely meaningless and a waste of time. Most of them are the same recycled levels with other objectives, but even the objectives themselves are just go from A to B, kill everything on your way and press the action button at the end. There were some side-missions where you interact with characters, but those are very rare and those interactions only go for a very short duration. I recommend skipping every side-mission, except the ones you do for your crew-members (not all of them have missions for you).The main missions were really fun though, you get to an area which could be a planet, a station, something which works as a hub area. There you meet characters and things happen and you get like mini side-missions from some people which are okay since they don't take much time and the character interaction is what makes this game fun.What I like about the main missions is that you stay at one big hub area for a long time and have to do different objectives to achieve something and get to different places. That reminded me a lot of Deus Ex, and it works almost as good as in Deus Ex. Exploring these places and meeting characters from different races is interesting and fun. Only thing which breaks this a little bit are the extremely annoying elevators, which probably are just there to cover loading screens. The thing is if they would just put a loading screen there it would probably load in seconds, cause today we have better PCs, but this game was mainly developed for consoles, so they didn't think about that. Still there are some PC specific things, for example you have extra keys assigned to each weapon and keys assigned to things like inventory and journal.The graphics are very dated, but character models still look fine, and overall the game still looks good thanks to very creative weapon and alien design. Animations are sometimes really bad, in most cutscenes the character are just standing in front of each other and moving their lips a little, but that's fine, because it still works. To the end of the game you can see that they put much more effort to the presentation and cutscenes and the story also gets really tense later, but expect a slow start and don't kill your motivation by doing filler side-missions. Also after every main missions you should talk to every squad member, you get interesting and fun dialouges and build relationships.I think this is a good game, but a little bit overhyped. People praise it for its story, for good reason, but forget the gameplay, or they just don't care about it, I do however. That's why I can't give it a very good score, but a 7.5 is still good in my book and definitely worth playing if you can handle dull gameplay.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												A long long time ago in a galaxy far away...It was 2007, and Bioware launched their flagship title to the franchise we now know as Mass Effect.Was it worthy of praise and sequels? Does it hold up today?Yes, and yes.First of all, the universe is immense, with detailed lore written and performed via audio journals.(The games also spawned novelizations, merchandise, and a script for a movie has been in development since 2010)The game was among the first exploring morality, choice, and consequences can lead you down different paths.Aaaand here's where I lose some of you because of my opinion: I like the Mass Effect universe more than Star Wars universe, in fact, I am not much of a fan at all of Star Wars, not even the original trilogy. There, I said it.Did Star Wars inspire Mass Effect?Duh.I also like Doctor Who, Farscape, and other sci-fi worlds, and just take into consideration that a review is just an opinion.Ok anyone still with me?Why is Ashley Williams armor pink and white? It makes not one ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ bit of sense. She's a marine, not a sex robot. Sure, you can buy Ashley some upgraded armor and retire the pink-and-white "whywouldanyonewearthisinabattlefieldwhiteisimpossibletokeepcleannottomentionitsjustplainsexistatthispoint"peice of armor to rest....BUT WHY??!?!?!So apart from a few minor gripes, the game still crafts its story well and creates interesting choices for Shepard to face (even though "Renegade" Shepard is kind of a psychotic♥♥♥♥♥♥for no reason)Final Verdict:7.5/10 - Definitely worth putting in your collection, with ME2. Pity we'll never get ME3, but just go watch it on Youtube because ♥♥♥♥ EA.And if any of you make a sci-fi space epic, don't put the girls in "powderpuff" fashion armor.10/10 girls prefer not being shot thanks to some sexist ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in the armory.

content:
Posted: January 15
												True masterpiece , 9.6/10.     (100+ hours of game time but not on steam)     This game man... When Mass Effect 1 first came out I was really young and at that time I didn't really liked Star Wars and I thought they are the same thing (kinda). I was a bit prejudiced about it. One of my friends came to me and said "Hey there is a game called Mass Effect it rocks". I watched my friend playing it , I didn't really liked it. After some time I realized that many of my friends are playing it. I was like hey let's try it and bought the game. That might be the best decision of my entire life.       Many people doesn't like the first game they prefer second or third but personally I actually love them all equal but the thing is ME2 and ME3 are really simular while this one have different atmosphere , gameplay and more RPG elements actually. Every weapon you have is customizable , many different skills , tough combats. Almost every interaction with NPC's have different outcome which give you paragon and renegade( other games contain it too but lesser and many of them are quick time paragon / renegade events).Anyway this is ME 1 review not 2 or 3 so let's talk about it a little bit.  Graphics : Most of the time graphics look good but when you are talking to someone and camera focused to characters well characters faces are like kinda mud but it's not annoying or bad it's just aged a little but not a big problem.    Story / Music / Atmosphere / Characters: It's Bioware a game dude. Magnificent story maybe one of the best to start a trilogy like that.Unique , interesting NPCs with many dialogues and romances. Perfect osts and atmosphere I don't thing I can explain it with enough detail in this short review you have to play it to understand how strong osts and atmosphere combine with each other. 10 / 10    Gameplay: First of all I want to start with WEAPONS SYSTEM maybe the worst part of the game is weapon heat. With wrong upgrades your sniper can burn instantly and you have to wait a few seconds to cool it down and it's pretty annoying.Some enemies make your weapon heat stable at some point so you can't use those and if you are not soldier class you have few weapons to shoot so it just becomes pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ The skill system is perfect in my opinion. You have to use it at the right time if you are playing at harder difficulties and singularity at the right time may turn freaky combat to shoot em all game. It's not perfect but it's not that annoying.(they fixed it in the other mass effect games but game became more action based)      Mako: Maybe the most criticized thing in the game. The game is leaving you with galaxy you can explore and most of the time your best friend on those planets is MAKO. Your beloved machine of destruction.Let's say hmm Mako's physics are not working well , shooting can be annoying and controls are hard. I can't say much but I never hated it. Mako feels like overpowered sometimes but hey you are Commander Shepard.    Well here it is. The first game of the epic trilogy. Just before the Mass Effect Andromeda. I strongly suggest that you guyz buy and play this game. I can't express my feelings about this game in the review during that trilogy I cried , laughed damn I feel pity for video game characters. If you ask me it's a must have and don't worry about Mass Effect 3's ending. It's better with extended cut and trust me even without an ending this game is one of the best series I've ever played.           I hope Andromeda will surpass my expectations. Buy this game!           Shepard out.

Posted: May 29, 2016
												I've waited so long to play this game, but I'm happy I did. Properly moded, at smooth framerate, Mass Effect took me on a fantastic journey like no other title has ever done. You'll feel proud to be human and inspired by the amazing and imaginative masterpiece BioWare crafted here. With almost 40 hours clocked in, I've completed almost all the side quests and finished the main story (and what a fantastic story it is). If you ever wanted to explore space, interact with alien races, discover uncharted worlds and fall in love with a living/breathing universe with rich lore; this is it. Mass Effect will deliver all of that and more. The only downside for me is that this is probably the last ME game I'll ever play on Steam, since the full experience and content is only found on Origins. Regardless, I'm looking forward to it.If you haven't played this game yet, and Sci Fi is you thing, do it. I believe you'll enjoy it.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												Mass Effect is the first in a series of games where you play as Commander Shepard, the first first mate of the USS Normandy, who is given command of the Normandy after a devestating attack on the human colony of Eden Prime. Your mission is to investigate the alien race behind the attack and save the Galaxy. Without going into anymore detail, as I wouldn't want to ruin it for you. Mass Effect is one of my all time favorite video game series, as the story just draws you in. The characters give you some back story, and you can explore the homeworlds of several council races, as well as explore the galaxy in general with your ship. Choices you make effect the gameplay overall and can be carried from the First Mass Effect into 2 and 3. The game is played in third-person mode, has a magnificent story and is visually pleasing to play. The only criticism I have for this does not come against the game itself, but against Steam for not having Mass Effect 3. Due to a deal Bioware made, Steam will never have the rights to Mass Effect 3, which means you won't be able to get the full experience of the series on Steam. With that aside, this game is worth playing if you are a fan of video games.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8
												Back in June of 2008 I completed my first game of Mass Effect for the PC. I thought it was very enjoyable and extremely well done. With Mass Effect Adromedia on the horizon, I wanted to go back and relive the story.The graphics were great (at that time - they have aged), the story immersive and the action gripping. Your companions in the game - these are extremely well done. BioWare truely shines when creating memoriable, believable personalities. Friends, enemies, co-workers... even lovers. You will rememeber these characters long after the game is over. That is what beings you back, even years later, to play it again.You will LOVE driving the Mako! What a great vehicle! It is a blast to zoom across alien worlds ans obliterate your enemies with the cannon in top.The game was very stable, I only experienced a few hang-ups, but there were a couple of times when the physics model of the game hiccupped. (I got blown off a platform in battle and my character was stuck because he couldn't jump 3') I am currently playing the game on Windows 10 with no issues.On the negative side, there was an entire galaxy of stuff to do and explore, but I felt too rushed to try and follow the linear plot line and never felt free to follow the side quests.I had hoped for more diverse items and equipment, but I kept seeming to find the same weapons, armor and upgrades, just slightly different.Shame on EA for not allowing un to get the Bring down the Sky or Pinnicale Station DLCs.The character design and advancement system was a bit drab and boring. The system employed in other RPGs such as Knights of the Old Republic was much better.The starship that you use, the Normandy was very cool, but you don't get to lead it into any combat that you have any control over - even from a strategic stand point.These criticisms are really just minor grievances. Overall, I very much enjoyed the game. I am looking forward to going back and trying it again. It has a great blend of science fiction from a broad range of inspirations: Star Trek, Star Wars, Battlestar Galactica and others.This is a game for mature players - it does contain material of adult content.At $6 a complete steal for the adventure that you get to enjoy!

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Mass Effect is one of the most innovative games I have ever played! It's desision making system allows for missions and dialogue to play out your specific way without breaking immersion.Gameplay : Mass effect is not always desision making. There are parts of the game where third person gunplay is involved. The combat system is fine, but not the best. There is no specific key to take cover against obstacles, so you'll have to lean up against walls a lot to attempt to get into cover. Guns have unlimited ammo, but they do overheat. While this is fine by be, I feel that the game would be much more fun and exciting if the guns used actual ammo reserves, like its sequel. THe enimies where not very challenging, and at times can be annoying to have to fight.There is a massive amount of exploration in this game! But at a lot of times, it is easy to get lost. With no specific objective markers in game or on your map, you have to look for yourself for what to do next and and how to do it. I spent lots of time walking in circles trying to find an objective!Graphics: Graphics in this game are "weak" compared to modern graphics, but understandable due to the game being released in 2006-2007. The textures in the world are nice to look at, but when it comes to the character models, they look very poor. Even if you max out the graphical settings (which I did for the entirety of the game) they are flat, and lack any kind of smoothing/anti-alising.  Even though these flaws were present, it did not take away from the experience.Story: The story follows a military commander, named Shepard. You can customize your character, it's gender, and first name (although the first name does not really impact the game)  The game's story length is around 9-10 hours, if you are relitivelty fast at completing games. Although, if you take your time, and complete the side missions, I do believe that you'll go well over 16+ hours. This game also has a lot of replayability due to the many diffrent dialogue options, and paragon and renagade story paths.My Conclusion : Mass Effect is a game worthy of its critical acclaim. It tells an amazing story that most other games on the market can't accomplsih. While this game may not be worth 19.99 in the store, it is a must that you pick it up during a steam sale.7.8/10
