content:
Posted: April 13
 Mass Effect lemme start with this preface. I am not reviewing this game from my first or even second playthrough, This was in fact my fourth (My game time is only from PC i played this first on Xbox 360) now from that i am assuming that you maybe able to tell that i liked this game alot. Ps. finished the whole trilogy and to this day ,in my opinion, the best damn series of games to ever come out   (screw andromeda dosen't count). Ps. This review may contain spoilers for people you meet in the main story (Only main characters) Gameplay: This game has its ups and downs with its combat system. it is really clunky by today's smooth standards but back in 2007 (Xbox 360) or 2008 (PC) it was about standard for the time. The leveling system in ME 1 was by far the best in my opinion, the better array of abilities available for you to spec into felt better than it was in later installments of the trilogy. overall for a game of its time it feels polished enough to be really enjoyable but just a little far out from preference (Your milage may vary on this opinion)Characters: Mass Effect has probably my favorite cast of characters in anything. period. all of the main cast of characters are all memorable and they all have a certain place in my heart. From Commander Shepard, Your player made character to the preaching Elcor on the Citadel*, seriously i have never seen a community react to characters the way the Mass Effect community does. to put it into one word it's mesmerizing.Story: for all that's it's worth the story in this only needs a short piece. It started a trilogy, then a spin off, And ALL of the thousands of hours that the community have put into making their own stories in this incredible universe that BioWare created. But for actual reviews sake: The story has its ups and downs, these being the fact that everything on the citadel is amazing story with some pretty good writing and i would say that 90% is excellent but it's just Feros that gets me, i can't explain it. it just feels like the planet had nothing going for it and it was just a helpless 'go here and help people' quest. but apart from one mission it's incredible.Overall: In conclusion the adventures of you and your crew in the Mass Effect Universe will most likely be one of the best you'll ever Experience in your life (Virtually, of course), and with all of the points that I have talked about above this game is a must buy for Gamers and perhaps people who are willing to try something new to enjoy why people say that Games aren't just shoot 'em ups. *This Elcor can be called and I quote 'A big stupid jellyfish' its pretty funny.Ps. i guess that i need to mention what Mass Effect may be known for. This being the romance options, dont buy this for them. Look them up if needs be just not worth it just for them. they are just there if you want.  Edit: Grammar

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
												Best ♥♥♥♥-in sci-fi game ever, Best Mass Effect game. Unlike the other two games it actually felt like a sci-fi rather than a coated James Bond movie. Shame that Bioware ended up in EA's bed, because what could have followed this game could have been 10x better than what got produced.If you're wondering why this game is better? Play it. I'll give you some hints1. It's actually an RPG - Something Bioware forgot in its sequels is giving the player choices that actually matter, in this you can truly feel like you're choosing your own path rather than having it forced on you2. The Reapers - At this point, we didn't know much about the reapers, but that's why they were such a great plot point: because they were mysterious. Perhaps it would have been better that way, keeping the player in the dark about them while fighting them. Mass Effect 2 kind of lost the feeling that the Reapers generated and by Mass Effect 3 they pretty much took a back seat the ♥♥♥♥ing Cerberus3. It gives you a villain to rally around - We all hated Saren, not because he was a bad character but because he was a bad guy, and he did that so well. Harbinger just assumed control of people, we had very little interaction with him. 4. Feels like an actual epic sci fi - What the sequels tried to do and failed is to keep the story epic while making it also feel like a summer thriller... bad move. Mass Effect throws environments at you that are really alien, combined with its freaky techno music that haunts you to the core. Sure, you often get the generic mountain planets, but I think they managed to make it work somewhat, and on that note5. Exploration - I get it, this isn't the U.S.S. Enterprise, you're hunting a criminal, but that doesn't mean you can't have a look around while you're out and about. You get to read up on strange planets, (the galaxy map usage in this is better too), explore them in a hilariously buggy tank, and do whatever you want. They are empty, for the most part, but it still feels fun. ME2 kind of continued it, but the lack of vehicular exploratation (sans the hammer) really didn't give the same vibe. Don't get me started on resource hunting in ME3There's a bunch of other stuff I didn't touch on. Is it perfect? Hell no, it definitely has flaws, but I rather would have seen them get fixed instead of axed in the second game. It's really quite sad.♥♥♥♥ you EA

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												(Recommended for the epicness and Asari love)Mass Effect would have to be one of most visionary and consistant RPG series made in recent years. Testament to the depth and intricacy of the game and its world, I have beaten this game and its sequels several times. Each time, I have made different choices and experienced different events and even different outcomes. With the benefit of hindsight, choices made in Mass Effect drive events found in its sequels.If comparing this first game to the rest of the games, it is reasonable to say that it is clunkier for sure, and it isn't the best version of the game out there. But problems can be persevered with. TextMOD can fix the textures of a certain Turian character, at least; and an INI edit can do the rest, particularly enabling 5.1 sound. However, once this is done, Mass Effect is perhaps the most memorable of the series for the wonder it inspires as an introduction to this rich universe and inspiring characters.Bear in mind, however, that if you wish to use a game-pad, you will require an external mapping program, and there are some irritating quirks with mapping mouse movements to the stick. In Xpadder, I had to add a middle mouse click to all directions. See my guide and downloadable profile. ;)Mass Effect was a revelation when it came out, and even know, though so much of its gloss has faded, it is mostly due to the rest ofthe trilogy being so fantastic in comparison. This entry to the story is mesmerising in its depth and clarity of execution. There has never been a more complete science fiction world ever invented for a video game.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												I know I'm like 6 years late with this review, but what the hell...Takes a while to get into, but if you're a fan of Bioware RPGs you'll know what you're in for. Solid RPG system with a plethora of side quests, weapon customisation and combinations, and a levelling system with more skills than you know what to do with.The storyline is good, although I would have preferred the main story missions to have taken place across more than 4 worlds. When the galaxy map has so many systems to explore, it can get a bit tedious without breaking it up with a story progressing mission.The one thing it took me a while to realise was that to get the most out of the game, you have to do your research. In other words, looking up the mission and conversation choice outcomes before actually doing them. This isn't ideal, as you end up basically reading the game in chunks and then playing them through. The most obvious example of this is choosing your starting character. After going with the default, I then did some reading around, discovered that femshep has superior voice acting, and that there were other backstories that I found more interesting. Luckily I discovered this only 3 hours in...The biotic powers are cool, I chose vanguard and do not regret a thing. The combo of pistol for long range, and shotgun with the biotic assault powers at close range was really enjoyable. I chose a backstory of a ruthless colonist, and unfortunately the game makes it hard to play as renegade without coming across as a complete ♥♥♥♥♥/jackass. I ended up with only slightly more renegade that paragon by the end, as some of the renegade decisions would result in missed opportunities in this game and the sequels.Oh and you can have sexytimes with an alien.8/10

												This game is not only stunningly made but is rich with interesting characters, plot twists and harrowing choices.If you're looking for an FPS RPG open-world game this is the one for you - you can explore many planets, do hundreds of side-quests or just simply follow the main plot-line.The only downfall is the Mako, which caused me many frustrations during the play-through (also those really annoying Geth Stalkers) but it is beautiful.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Mass Effect is one of the most innovative games I have ever played! It's desision making system allows for missions and dialogue to play out your specific way without breaking immersion.Gameplay : Mass effect is not always desision making. There are parts of the game where third person gunplay is involved. The combat system is fine, but not the best. There is no specific key to take cover against obstacles, so you'll have to lean up against walls a lot to attempt to get into cover. Guns have unlimited ammo, but they do overheat. While this is fine by be, I feel that the game would be much more fun and exciting if the guns used actual ammo reserves, like its sequel. THe enimies where not very challenging, and at times can be annoying to have to fight.There is a massive amount of exploration in this game! But at a lot of times, it is easy to get lost. With no specific objective markers in game or on your map, you have to look for yourself for what to do next and and how to do it. I spent lots of time walking in circles trying to find an objective!Graphics: Graphics in this game are "weak" compared to modern graphics, but understandable due to the game being released in 2006-2007. The textures in the world are nice to look at, but when it comes to the character models, they look very poor. Even if you max out the graphical settings (which I did for the entirety of the game) they are flat, and lack any kind of smoothing/anti-alising.  Even though these flaws were present, it did not take away from the experience.Story: The story follows a military commander, named Shepard. You can customize your character, it's gender, and first name (although the first name does not really impact the game)  The game's story length is around 9-10 hours, if you are relitivelty fast at completing games. Although, if you take your time, and complete the side missions, I do believe that you'll go well over 16+ hours. This game also has a lot of replayability due to the many diffrent dialogue options, and paragon and renagade story paths.My Conclusion : Mass Effect is a game worthy of its critical acclaim. It tells an amazing story that most other games on the market can't accomplsih. While this game may not be worth 19.99 in the store, it is a must that you pick it up during a steam sale.7.8/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												So I hadn't ever finished Mass Effect until just a few days ago but in those few hours that it took me to play the game through I thoroughly enjoyed it. The combat is fun, the story engaging, the graphics were fine and, overall, it felt like I WAS Shepard. The biggest compliment I can give this game is the story. It draws you in and absorbs you as you talk to all of these strange and fascinating characters and learn more about them and the worlds around them.I do have some problems with it though. One of those problems stemming from the fact that, when I first started playing this game, I had no idea where I was supposed to go. The game doesn't always present a clear direction and, while I do appreciate the fact that the map lets you set your own waypoints, it just doesn't direct you the way you would like.My biggest gripe with this game however comes in the form of combat. I do enjoy the combat of Mass Effect and it does keep you engaged but the controls are just not quite up to par. Mashing your face into the wall to take cover is not a good way of getting into cover. The later games in the series do this in a better way by mapping it to a button but here I often found myself just running against the nearest rock to get to cover and if that didn't work I would just run to the next one and so on and so forth.That being said this game is still excellent. The story is intriguing and the characters just enhance that. I recommend playing this if just for the story and nothing else. In fact, this game is worth a playthrough just for Garrus Vakarian alone. He is the man.

content:
Posted: April 13
 Mass Effect lemme start with this preface. I am not reviewing this game from my first or even second playthrough, This was in fact my fourth (My game time is only from PC i played this first on Xbox 360) now from that i am assuming that you maybe able to tell that i liked this game alot. Ps. finished the whole trilogy and to this day ,in my opinion, the best damn series of games to ever come out   (screw andromeda dosen't count). Ps. This review may contain spoilers for people you meet in the main story (Only main characters) Gameplay: This game has its ups and downs with its combat system. it is really clunky by today's smooth standards but back in 2007 (Xbox 360) or 2008 (PC) it was about standard for the time. The leveling system in ME 1 was by far the best in my opinion, the better array of abilities available for you to spec into felt better than it was in later installments of the trilogy. overall for a game of its time it feels polished enough to be really enjoyable but just a little far out from preference (Your milage may vary on this opinion)Characters: Mass Effect has probably my favorite cast of characters in anything. period. all of the main cast of characters are all memorable and they all have a certain place in my heart. From Commander Shepard, Your player made character to the preaching Elcor on the Citadel*, seriously i have never seen a community react to characters the way the Mass Effect community does. to put it into one word it's mesmerizing.Story: for all that's it's worth the story in this only needs a short piece. It started a trilogy, then a spin off, And ALL of the thousands of hours that the community have put into making their own stories in this incredible universe that BioWare created. But for actual reviews sake: The story has its ups and downs, these being the fact that everything on the citadel is amazing story with some pretty good writing and i would say that 90% is excellent but it's just Feros that gets me, i can't explain it. it just feels like the planet had nothing going for it and it was just a helpless 'go here and help people' quest. but apart from one mission it's incredible.Overall: In conclusion the adventures of you and your crew in the Mass Effect Universe will most likely be one of the best you'll ever Experience in your life (Virtually, of course), and with all of the points that I have talked about above this game is a must buy for Gamers and perhaps people who are willing to try something new to enjoy why people say that Games aren't just shoot 'em ups. *This Elcor can be called and I quote 'A big stupid jellyfish' its pretty funny.Ps. i guess that i need to mention what Mass Effect may be known for. This being the romance options, dont buy this for them. Look them up if needs be just not worth it just for them. they are just there if you want.  Edit: Grammar

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
												Best ♥♥♥♥-in sci-fi game ever, Best Mass Effect game. Unlike the other two games it actually felt like a sci-fi rather than a coated James Bond movie. Shame that Bioware ended up in EA's bed, because what could have followed this game could have been 10x better than what got produced.If you're wondering why this game is better? Play it. I'll give you some hints1. It's actually an RPG - Something Bioware forgot in its sequels is giving the player choices that actually matter, in this you can truly feel like you're choosing your own path rather than having it forced on you2. The Reapers - At this point, we didn't know much about the reapers, but that's why they were such a great plot point: because they were mysterious. Perhaps it would have been better that way, keeping the player in the dark about them while fighting them. Mass Effect 2 kind of lost the feeling that the Reapers generated and by Mass Effect 3 they pretty much took a back seat the ♥♥♥♥ing Cerberus3. It gives you a villain to rally around - We all hated Saren, not because he was a bad character but because he was a bad guy, and he did that so well. Harbinger just assumed control of people, we had very little interaction with him. 4. Feels like an actual epic sci fi - What the sequels tried to do and failed is to keep the story epic while making it also feel like a summer thriller... bad move. Mass Effect throws environments at you that are really alien, combined with its freaky techno music that haunts you to the core. Sure, you often get the generic mountain planets, but I think they managed to make it work somewhat, and on that note5. Exploration - I get it, this isn't the U.S.S. Enterprise, you're hunting a criminal, but that doesn't mean you can't have a look around while you're out and about. You get to read up on strange planets, (the galaxy map usage in this is better too), explore them in a hilariously buggy tank, and do whatever you want. They are empty, for the most part, but it still feels fun. ME2 kind of continued it, but the lack of vehicular exploratation (sans the hammer) really didn't give the same vibe. Don't get me started on resource hunting in ME3There's a bunch of other stuff I didn't touch on. Is it perfect? Hell no, it definitely has flaws, but I rather would have seen them get fixed instead of axed in the second game. It's really quite sad.♥♥♥♥ you EA

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												(Recommended for the epicness and Asari love)Mass Effect would have to be one of most visionary and consistant RPG series made in recent years. Testament to the depth and intricacy of the game and its world, I have beaten this game and its sequels several times. Each time, I have made different choices and experienced different events and even different outcomes. With the benefit of hindsight, choices made in Mass Effect drive events found in its sequels.If comparing this first game to the rest of the games, it is reasonable to say that it is clunkier for sure, and it isn't the best version of the game out there. But problems can be persevered with. TextMOD can fix the textures of a certain Turian character, at least; and an INI edit can do the rest, particularly enabling 5.1 sound. However, once this is done, Mass Effect is perhaps the most memorable of the series for the wonder it inspires as an introduction to this rich universe and inspiring characters.Bear in mind, however, that if you wish to use a game-pad, you will require an external mapping program, and there are some irritating quirks with mapping mouse movements to the stick. In Xpadder, I had to add a middle mouse click to all directions. See my guide and downloadable profile. ;)Mass Effect was a revelation when it came out, and even know, though so much of its gloss has faded, it is mostly due to the rest ofthe trilogy being so fantastic in comparison. This entry to the story is mesmerising in its depth and clarity of execution. There has never been a more complete science fiction world ever invented for a video game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
 Originally posted on June 28, 2010 Mass Effect is essentially the cross-breed result of mating Bioware's RPG formula with Gears of War's combat system.The game is a console title first and foremost, which makes many of its flaws all the more apparent on the PC, however the art design, and story telling are top notch, and the roleplaying elements (through not as deep as the game would like you to think) are interesting enoughGraphics- The game features dated graphics technically speaking, even for the original release date. Incredibly low poly models, low res textures, and mediocre effect (particles) make this game less than awe inspiring visually. However the art design and character models are generally pretty good, especially when in comes to aliens, geth, and other creatures. The animations look quite good, and generally the art design is very creative. Cutscenes look quite good, generally speaking, although the overuse of bloom sometimes is annoying.Yet the game is clearly custom tailored for the 5-year-old hardware of consoles, with irritatingly frequent load screens, jarringly low res skyboxes and other textures, and annoying amounts of loading zones masquerading as elevators.Sound- Generally speaking, the music is superb, with a electronica soundtrack that harkens back to deus ex. The voice acting is also generally good, although there are a few rough spots, and the characters are generally memorable as a result. The sounds for weapons and other effects are also quite nice, providing a space age feel to the combatGameplay- My biggest problem with this game by far is the gameplay, as Bioware seems to have taken their typical RPG formula (which I have mixed feelings about) and mated it with Gears of War's cover and combat systems ( which I hate). Bioware's formula allows for alot of choices in the story, randomized loot drops, and other RPG staples. It is also notorious for lazy level design. absolute cookie cutter carbon copies of levels litter this game, quickly draining what little flavor the side quests hold for you from the game, as there is one generic mine level, two generic settlement levels, and one generic spaceship/station level that the player encounters AGAIN AND AGAIN throughout the game. At least Bethesda knows their level design, give them credit for that. Bioware's level design flat out sucks.It doesn't end with cookie cutter levels however, for the driving sequences are equally frustrating. Exploring strange new worlds in a rover and finding hidden collectibles (tedious, but an RPG staple) along with side quests sounds fun in theory, but the Mako handles like a physics nightmare. In addition, some of the terrain is modeled with so few polygons and so extremely steeply that it is almost impossible to simply cruise around the planets. Instead the mako climbs impossible angles, flips and does barrel rolls (without taking damage of course) and gets caught on terrain. In addition, the turret has almost no traverse, and you only get half xp from kills in the mako, making the armaments almost useless. Driving quickly became on absolute nightmare for me, and I was using a mouse and keyboard. I can only imagine how those poor saps with controllers felt.Third, the cover system is awful and unnecessary. I hate gears of war, or any third person cover shooter for that matter, on principle. So seeing this system in a game made by people who used to develop RPG's for the PC first is awful. It locks you into objects unnecessarily, makes it difficult to get out, and frequently got me killed, frustrating me to no end. It also leaves levels littered with absurd amounts of cover for you and your enemies to use. Not that this unrealistic feature mattered, as the favorite maneuver of most of the AI in the game is to charge straight at your guns.Other features such as the leveling, perks and squad management worked better, but even those got clunky. For example there is no way to examine your crew member's stats while on the Normandy, so equipping them via the weapons lockers can be very confusing. Inventory management in general is clunky, and needs a menu that is actually designed for the PC. Finally, I found the fact that every member of your squad had one of each weapon, even if they weren't trained in its use, to be very odd, and the fact that armor and weapon stats were not tied to the model or skin of the item gets very confusing. The loot often felt... generic at best.Ultimately, this game has a story that will draw you in and it can be a lot of fun to play, but it is full of irritating gameplay, so much so that I would almost recommend skipping all but a select few of the side missions. It has a large amount of replay value, with many classes available to play as and many ways to resolve a situation, (although not as many as you think, 2 dialog choices often result in Shepard saying the same exact thing, a false representation of a choice), and it will keep you playing for many hours. Just take it for what it is: Consolized.

												I will give this game 7/10. The gameplay is quite decent, the difficulty seems fair MOST of the time.The things that holds me from giving it a higher score is very anoying bugs.1. You can get stuck in the elevator forcing you to reload the last save points.2. There is a part where if you are hit you get stuck and you are forced to reload a check point.3. The textures are extremly low quality and to get good quality you are forced to change the game files manualy.The auto saves are also horrible, they have made me waste probably 40 min of my life since i was forcedto go back a long time after dying.The port to Steam is so freaking bad, the DLC is forced to be manualy downloaded from EA's site and i can't even find the second DLC. The fact that Bioware just let bugs like these still be there is mind blowing, they just don't care about their game anymore and won't fix gamebreaking bugs. The fact that Steam didn't make the DLC available to the Steam client itself is also confusing.But other than that the game is fun to play, im looking forward to play the rest of the Mass Effect series.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												This is amazing! It could have been a movie because the story is awesome! Even if you don't play games you can play this one on the easiest difficulty just for it's story-- well, if you like science fiction, that is... It's very addictive. It makes you want to see what's next. There is even a ton of information that you can learn about the game's  fantastic world. Lots of new technologies and species and stuff like that. There are three main combat styles that you can use-- weapons, "tech" abilities and "biotic" abilities, which are new ways to manipulate the matter and the energy, kind of like the Force in Star Wars. There are six classes that you can play and each one has its strengths, weaknesses and unique set of skills and you have to work together with your followers to beat every kind of enemy. Each one of your followers has their own personality and story and some of them even give you a small quest to play. Many times you will be given the chance to make a choice between two or more decisions to take, usually a "good" one and a "bad" one. You can be a "good guy" or a "bad guy". Well, not really a *bad* guy... You save the galaxy either way, you can just choose to do it the right way, or any way you like. Even when talking to a character you can choose a "good" polite response or a "bad" rude one. What i didn't like is that all the weapons and any kind of equipment look and function alike. Even their names are boring (for example Lancer III, Lancer IV, Avenger VIII, Avenger IX, etc...) It would have been a lot better if there were unique items with a unique way to function and even special abilities, like for example a "Prototype Alpha Bio-Blaster". Also the planets you can explore get a little boring after a while. Another thing i didn't like is that there is no stealth, so you always have to fight your enemies. Except of course if you talk them out of it-- there is a way to persuade other characters using "charm" or "intimidation". You could also find it a bit annoying that your enemies always repeat the same thing during a battle ("Enemy is everywhere!") and there are some technical problems too, but if you can overlook that, you have a damn good game with an excellent story that will bring you many hours of fun.

The series original shows it age in its visuals and many of its gameplay systems.  The clunky inventory and RPG shooting randomization will feel very outdated by today's standards.  However, the plot holds up well mainly to the now iconic characters and quality voice acting.  The game's formidable length may stand against it at this point as a way to catch up on the 'Mass Effect' backstory.Note: EA is my current employer, but I have not worked on any 'Mass Effect' title.

Posted: August 16, 2016
												What is Mass Effect?Is it a good, combat-centered RPG, fun to play and rewarding? Can it be recommended?Certainly yes.Is it the best of best, a masterpiece of gaming, the holy grail?Sorry all you fanboys'n girls out there, it certainly is not.Pro:+ very clever level design, obviously done by some veteran console developers+ interesting combat, a little bit too arcade for my taste, but its a console game+ amazing setting, citadel station is better than anything Star Wars; the whole universe and lore is much better than Star Wars+ because of the level design and always changing approach, it doesnt get boring. just keep planetary exploring to a minumum.Contra:- characters are stereotypes and VERY superficial, I didnt care for anyone of them, hero included.- SUPER PREDICTABLE plot, outright boring, but thats some kind of trademark of Bioware games- shoddy teammate AI and pathfinding, I know a couple games that did this WAY better two years earlier- planetary exploring is very long-winded and gets boring at some point- surprisingly many glitches and gamebreaking clipping issues, I got stuck (damn you elevators!!!) or fell through the map more than a dozen times during one playthrough, so SAVE OFTEN- in more than 50% of all dialogs I disagreed with all dialog choices. guess I wouldnt make a good intergalactic soldier at all.Despite the many cons, the setting and lore is maybe the best in science-fiction gaming to date, which makes me recommend this game.It is well worth the 2,50 on sale. 10 bucks... I dunno

content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												I never really hopped onto the train of Mass Effect fans when the Mass Effect series first got popular because I couldn't really see why it had so much popularity. I feel bad for doubting this game.Gameplay in Mass Effect is typical to any sort of RPG by Bioware. The gameplay is a blend of dialogue and talking to people, third person shooting and exploring tons of different planets in tons of different galaxies. I was amazed by the shear size of Mass Effect, 8 different galaxies with around 5 or more in each and each planet feels unique and I don't think it is just a copy and paste of different planet. The character customization of Commander Sheppard, even though it's limited in some areas, I find is well done where you can customize your appearance to make him be as ugly as you want and you can even customize his backstory. What makes the character customization of backstories even better is that characters will have different dialogue responses depending on your choice of backstory. Most of the gameplay feature are good but I do have a couple of complaints. The third person shooting mechanics aren't that well done. They aren't terrible, they aren't on the scale of being unplayable but it feels like the third person shooter segments were just added in as an after thought and it took me alot of getting used to. The second and final problem I have with the gameplay is the karma system. One thing that I'm not too fond of in RPGs (despite RPGs being my favourite genre of video games) is the karma systems some off these games have) I like to build my character, now knowing if the choice that I just made was good or bad or Ilike to make a bad choice if I'm in abad or annoying situation without an affect on my karma. Because in these games I find it way too easy to be the good guy and way too easy to be the bad guy.I just like to be the character that I build my character up to be. Apart from those 2 complaints there aren't really any other complaints I have about the gameplay.The story in Mass Effect is that you play as the main character Commander Sheppard, who you can customize hisappearance and even his backstory. He joins up with a crew lead by Captain Anderson. His crew is given a task to procure a military beacon on the planet Eden Prime. However, after a disaster, involving one of the crew mates dying by the hands of a rogue spectre, who are the protectors of the council, the crew ends u failing. After providing evidence to the council that this spectre has gone rogue,it is up to Commander Sheppard and his crew to bring the rogue spectre down to justice. This general idea of a plot has been done alot but Mass Effect throws enough twists and turns in the story to make it seem unique.Graphics in Mass Effect are OK but could be better. While the game looks, in general, good, there are several graphical bugs and awful looking textures and slow loading textures which definately hold the game back. Sound is really good. There are creative sfx for sci-fi related objects that I wouldn't have even thought of which fit in excellently.This game will have you consumed for hours, I'm still busy exploring the galaxy and discovering all sorts of new stuff. There is also replay value in this. You will want to play the game again and try different dialogue choices, try and see if you can solve a problem either calmly, declaring war or see if you can find another creative way to solve a situation.Mass Effect is a gem of a game that I reccommend to litterraly anybody that enjoys either SC-FIs or RPGs and if u fit in this category, this game is a must have.Pros+ Great gameplay+ Great twists in the story+ OK graphics+ Fantastic sound+ You will be playing this for hours+ Reaplay valueCons- Third person shooter segments are clunky at times- Slow loading texturesFinal verdict: 9/10Steam Curator group: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/MellowReviews

content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												What can I say!  Hands down the best FPS/RPG ever made.  The whole series was breathtaking.  The stories were deep and immersive.  It was like playing a game and watching a great show.  The combat structure was designed very well.  It is easy to select weapons and choose your abilities without ever leaving the combat screen.  The enemy AI uses cover effectively and uses tactics to manuver and flank when possible.  This is not a rush and kill everything in sight game.  Use your squad commands and utiilze cover or you will be anihilated.  As commander you can take any path you choose in the game.  If you want to be a saint or a sinner its up to you.  Try as I might I cannot find a flaw in the game series.  I've played then for hundreds of hours and I still enjoy them.  About the only thing i can complain about is the secondary mission objective list in the third installment does not work well.  There is no way to tell if you completed the mission or not and sometime no way to know where you need to go back to to complete it.  So take lots of notes.  Other than that this is the best series I have ever played and I cry at night knowing there will be no more.  I guess 3 is the magic number.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												Let me start off by saying that if you’re a gamer, whether it'd be casual or hardcore, you're doing yourself a severe disservice by not playing the Mass Effect series. This isn’t just a game, it’s an experience.  PROS (Where do I even begin):- Excellent story. I loved every minute of it and I had trouble putting the game down.- Lovable characters. The game excels in making you really care about the characters. I haven’t found one that I haven’t liked. Excellent voice acting, for the most part.- Branching dialogue. This is easily the best part of the series as your character interactions will be unique to create a more personalized experience.- Choices matter. The choices you make in this game carry over to the next which further establishes a more personal experience.- Excellent port. While I don’t have a monster computer, I can still run the game at the highest settings with no performance issues.- Sound/Music. The music is absolutely spot on and the sound design is also top notch.- Voice acting. Easily my favorite part of this series. I downloaded a Harbinger and Sovereign soundboard, as well as a few other characters’ simply because of how much I loved the many quotable dialogue sequences.- Main character customization. While you can’t fully physically customize your character, you can definitely create his/her face and a name (which won’t be used in the game since everyone refers to you by your last name, Shepard). - Massive potential for replay. In my first playthrough, I ran the game as a female paragon (making good choices). I’m now on my second playthrough, playing as the male “bad guy,” making evil decisions and killing off characters just to see how it will affect the plot in the next games. - Freedom. You can go wherever you want and tackle the missions in any order and the plot will still make sense. It’s the furthest thing from being a linear experience.- Flexibility. The game unravels itself based on the choices you make and that’s pretty cool. For example, when I was confronted by a certain main character, I could have resolved the matter by talking to him or intimidating him, but I chose to kill him, instead. How you handle missions/situations is largely up to you.- Varied classes. You can choose which class you want to play as. You have 3 pure classes in Biotic, Combat, and Tech: Adept (handles biotic based attacks), Soldier (combat specialist), or Engineer (tech specialist). Then you have hybrid classes: Vanguard (combat/biotics), Sentinel (tech/biotics), Infiltrator (tech/combat). Choose whichever sounds interesting to you. Classes really change up the way you play the game which further adds to the replay value.CONS:- Notoriously long elevator sequences. This game is known for having elevators that take forever! The elevator in C-Sec at the Citadel (you’ll see) that takes you to your ship takes over 40 seconds. This might not seem long, but you will be paying multiple visits to the Citadel and it will get EXTREMELY annoying. While there are several more annoying elevator sequences in the game, fortunately, they aren’t as long. Still annoying enough to mention.- A lot of the guns look the same with just different colors. They also fire the same, pretty much, with the same noise. The only differences are the stats. Fortunately, the way a gun fires and handles can be customized via the many ammo/gun upgrades you’ll find.- This game also has a bad habit of throwing more guns at you than you know what to do with. You get a 150 equipment limit which racks up quickly. I end up having to keep selling the ones I find and eventually got millions in cash over time. With all this money, there's not much to spend it on, considering that majority of the loot you find in various worlds will be better than the ones available in stores.- Lack of good armors. I just didn’t like the look and feel of a lot of the armors in the game. I wish armor aesthetics were much more varied because they felt boring. Also, armors are not customizable which sucks in a game where its main strength lies in personalizing user experience.SIDE NOTES:- I recommend you to not play this game below Veteran difficulty, as the AI is not too competent below that.- Don’t pick the pure classes, as I find them boring. Play as one of the hybrids: Vanguard, Sentinel, or Infiltrator. Vanguard is my absolute favorite.- Don't save Kaiden because I REALLY don't like that guy.

												Why did I avoid playing this game for so long?  Ironically I was a huge fan of Knights of the Old Republic, and the Bioware version of it at.   The moment I jumped into this game I noticed similarities between it and KOTOR.  I fell in love with this very fast.   Gameplay works quite well, character/weapon customization is a blast.  It is a beautiful balance between 3rd Person Shooter and Bioware's KOTOR style of RPG they created so many years ago.  Outside of a few minor bugs, this game is one of the best adventures I've had in a long while.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												Mass Effect.I've played enough of this game to know that I want more.More of BioWare's epic writing. More of the deep sci-fi world the game serves up for us on a silver platter, serviette included, in butler uniform (if male). Less of the vehicle sections though; whoever thought that was a good idea might need to revisit the corkboard and check his memos.More of the characters. More of the combat. More consequential choices. More of... nearly everything.Mass Effect may be a third person shooter, but it feels like you're playing an RPG. I've heard that a lot of times; I never really believed it. Now I've gone through the gates: now I see all. And it is awe-inspiring.Yes, animation's a bit clunky, but I stopped noticing it. That didn't stop me from enjoying this epic and neither should it stop you.

												Whenever I think of epic-scale RPGs, my first thoughts turn to the Mass Effect series, and usually after that, its first title that set the stage for one of the most enveloping and immersive gaming experiences that Canada can offer. The structure of the 3 games is akin to that of the original Star Wars trilogy.Though dated and still a bit clunky, the first title in the series of Mass Effect games did a beautiful job of serving as the exposition and rising action for a seemingly limitless amount of story potential. After 3 major games, 4 handheld games, 4 novels, 10 comic books, and a feature-length film[en.wikipedia.org] in the works, BioWare claims that there is still quite a bit of this story that has been left untold. The next title in the Mass Effect series, though enigmatic at the moment, will likely reinvent and redirect the game series as a whole. This game has the player character's customized hero, Commander Shepard, embarking on a galactic quest to catch an elusive rogue agent seemingly working to further his own goals, and to uncover the true hidden meaning behind the possibility of a threat that this galaxy was in no way ready for. The combat system had certain enjoyable aspects that weren't revisited until the third game in the series, such as weapons that don't use thermal clips and the distance and speed covered whilst sprinting. Though I usually have trouble discerning which game of the trilogy is my favorite, most of my thoughts are with its first title, which has imprinted on me as well as many thousands of other players a gaming experience that will never be forgotten.Its visual style and gameplay are something that is only bettered by its successor, Mass Effect 2.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												What can I say!  Hands down the best FPS/RPG ever made.  The whole series was breathtaking.  The stories were deep and immersive.  It was like playing a game and watching a great show.  The combat structure was designed very well.  It is easy to select weapons and choose your abilities without ever leaving the combat screen.  The enemy AI uses cover effectively and uses tactics to manuver and flank when possible.  This is not a rush and kill everything in sight game.  Use your squad commands and utiilze cover or you will be anihilated.  As commander you can take any path you choose in the game.  If you want to be a saint or a sinner its up to you.  Try as I might I cannot find a flaw in the game series.  I've played then for hundreds of hours and I still enjoy them.  About the only thing i can complain about is the secondary mission objective list in the third installment does not work well.  There is no way to tell if you completed the mission or not and sometime no way to know where you need to go back to to complete it.  So take lots of notes.  Other than that this is the best series I have ever played and I cry at night knowing there will be no more.  I guess 3 is the magic number.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												The game is very important to the Mass Effect storyline and if you want to have your decisions (that you made personally) carry over this is a mandatory playthrough. However, I first played Mass Effect 2 and then Mass Effect 3, and this game isn't nearly as good as it's sequels. The people that say it is are simply judging the game off nostalgia. The graphics (even with multiple graphics mods installed) are almost unbearably bad at times. The control scheme and interface is also a mess. And there's this weird head bobbing that's intergrated into the UI that gives a lot of players motion sickness including myself. But if you buy this game you aren't buying it for any of those things I just criticized. You're buying it because you want to understand the entire story of Commander Shepard and understand more of the Mass Effect universe.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2016
												Even tho I had some technical issues related to some textures completely disappearing in certain missions of the game, i still had a lot of fun playing the game. The game is obviously pretty old and I see why certain design choices were criticized but the universe lore is deep, the story is REALLY interesting and the characters are just fantastic. This, combined to a pretty cool combat system that, even tho it doesn't really shine compared to other games of the same generation, still mantains the fights at high stakes and can be very challenging if one doesn't take the RPG part seriously. I'm convinced to buy at least the second game, if not just to know how the story continues from the choices I made. Even to today's standards, this game is basically a must play.Now I'm going to play through the game again in order to prepare a career that I actually want to import into the second chapter.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												This is a saga RPG, which means your game continuation carries over into the 2nd and third installments. Meaning you want to buy 1 2 and 3 as a package deal if you are interested in playing.ME1 is a decent game with a decent story, but it does have some issues. If you like game immersion, you will find yourself putting that on hold to complete the seemingly endless side quests. Of course like many other games of the genre, the game ends when you conqure the main quests, leaving no time to do the side quests. So you have to "pretend" like you have nothing better to do from an immersion standpoint in order to get them done. All the explorable open world planets that you encounter, need major fleshing out. They are very mountainous and annoying, and the life worlds dont have a single trace of life besides short grass. When you get to a side quest location, you will find its the exact same building over and over again, but maybe with a few different boxes in it. The various atmospheres are interesting and pretty tho. Each planet has a lore section on it thats fun to read about.The codex is pretty in depth and long and will keep you busy for a few hours if you are into that sort of thing. There is rich history and lore established in the game, and you actually feel apart of the established universe.Without spoiling much, the three alien compainions that you get at the start of the game, dont really make much sense as to why they are coming along for the long haul. You are an alliance military commander why do you need these three random aliens again? It is possible to take off with only 2 out of 3, do not do this!!!!  The games continuation in ME2 and ME3 is built around you taking them with you. So its a false choice thats actually sabatorial to you if you choose incorrectly. Now you dont need everyone to survive ME1, and you will figure out what I am talking about, but you do need 3 alien companions when you leave the citadel, and the good news is that you cannot leave without being asked about it first.But your companions are well fleshed out and have interesting stories and backgrounds for the most part..... So thats good.Even tho this is not a Romance game, the Romance is ME1 is a bit of a joke. You can only woo a total of 2 characters, depending on your sex. Not only that, but you only get 1 romance scene before the last mission if you went down that route.___________________________________________________________________________________Yes I would recommend this series. Unfortunatly ME3 is not on steam and we all know Origins is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ POS. Unfortunatly your going to need to mod ME3s ending, get MEHEM or else you will want to riot against EA. Unfortunatly its EA and ME2 and ME3 are DLC grubbing POS. But yes I recommend this game for you.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												Mass Effect.I've played enough of this game to know that I want more.More of BioWare's epic writing. More of the deep sci-fi world the game serves up for us on a silver platter, serviette included, in butler uniform (if male). Less of the vehicle sections though; whoever thought that was a good idea might need to revisit the corkboard and check his memos.More of the characters. More of the combat. More consequential choices. More of... nearly everything.Mass Effect may be a third person shooter, but it feels like you're playing an RPG. I've heard that a lot of times; I never really believed it. Now I've gone through the gates: now I see all. And it is awe-inspiring.Yes, animation's a bit clunky, but I stopped noticing it. That didn't stop me from enjoying this epic and neither should it stop you.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												A masterful mix of third person shooters and RPGs. It has my favorite sci-fi world and everything in the game supports the sci-fi theme amazingly well. It just all fits together. Although it is without a doubt a third person shooter somehow there's more to it than that. I believe it's the RPG elements that make it more than your average run-and-gun third person shooter and I love it for that.The story is really fascinating the graphics still hold up. The moral choices are a tad black and white and there's isn't an awful lot of choice in the game but it's still a great game. The game isn't all that linear either from what I remember. You can choose when to do some missions and the rest of the time you can fly around with your spaceship. Although there isn't really much to do on other planets apart from shooting randomly generated enemies to get to randomly generated materials while driving on randomly generated terrain. There are side missions but they don't have much substance at all.If you like sci-fi and shooters, it's definitely worth your money. There's a surprising amount of lore and history as well, so if that's your thing you might consider buying this game.----[Rating weighted based on the genre]----Story: 4/5Gameplay: 4/5Challenge: 3.5/5Discovery: 3.5/5Replayability: 3.5/5Aesthetics: 5/5Visuals: 4/5Atmosphere: 4.5/5Music: 3.5/5

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2011
												Mass Effect is one of THOSE GAMES that every gamer has to play at least once in their life. And for a good reason, too.As with most Western RPG's, it combines RPG with another genre; in this case, action.Mass Effect gunplay features Commander Sheapard figthing alongside two squadmates (of a choice of a total of six), using either assault rifles, shotguns, sniper rifles, or pistols. Fighting your enemies is also combined with skills. For example, a concept called "biotics." For lack of a better definition, biotics are somewhat psychic powers. you can use these powers to blast shockwaves at your foes, among other things.Mass Effect is also the kind of sci-fi game I love: it explains its concepts. From the religion of an alien species, to the average temperature of a planet, to the known history of the Citedel. Mass Effect creates its own universe, with hard sci-fi concepts.This space opera is a must play for any sci-fi fans, or RPG/ Third-Person-Shooter fans.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												Mass Effect (1 to 3) is one of the absolute best story-driven game series ever.  The whole series is an absolute gem which will make you contemplate some of the deepest philosophical questions and engage you perhaps even more than good literature would.  The depth of the story paralleled only by The Witcher series (or arguably surpassed, especially after reading the short stories and novels which inspired The Witcher game series).  I cannot recommend the Mass Effect series highly enough.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												The game is very important to the Mass Effect storyline and if you want to have your decisions (that you made personally) carry over this is a mandatory playthrough. However, I first played Mass Effect 2 and then Mass Effect 3, and this game isn't nearly as good as it's sequels. The people that say it is are simply judging the game off nostalgia. The graphics (even with multiple graphics mods installed) are almost unbearably bad at times. The control scheme and interface is also a mess. And there's this weird head bobbing that's intergrated into the UI that gives a lot of players motion sickness including myself. But if you buy this game you aren't buying it for any of those things I just criticized. You're buying it because you want to understand the entire story of Commander Shepard and understand more of the Mass Effect universe.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2011
												5/5 stars. A graphically attractive single-player game with Bioware's famous deep RP options. The overall story arc guarantees the same conclusion but offers some variety in NPC responses based on your personality and gender choice. The team combat system can be challenging to learn depending on the specialization you choose. ME1 is a good place to introduce yourself to the characters and background story if you can get it for under $10. I'm a relatively thorough player and got about 60 hours of fun from this. Driven gamers who strive to complete the main storyline will get 30-40 hours.

I remember buying ME2 on a whim because the price reached impulse buy territory. Still haven't been able to generate enough interest to play it.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												A masterful mix of third person shooters and RPGs. It has my favorite sci-fi world and everything in the game supports the sci-fi theme amazingly well. It just all fits together. Although it is without a doubt a third person shooter somehow there's more to it than that. I believe it's the RPG elements that make it more than your average run-and-gun third person shooter and I love it for that.The story is really fascinating the graphics still hold up. The moral choices are a tad black and white and there's isn't an awful lot of choice in the game but it's still a great game. The game isn't all that linear either from what I remember. You can choose when to do some missions and the rest of the time you can fly around with your spaceship. Although there isn't really much to do on other planets apart from shooting randomly generated enemies to get to randomly generated materials while driving on randomly generated terrain. There are side missions but they don't have much substance at all.If you like sci-fi and shooters, it's definitely worth your money. There's a surprising amount of lore and history as well, so if that's your thing you might consider buying this game.----[Rating weighted based on the genre]----Story: 4/5Gameplay: 4/5Challenge: 3.5/5Discovery: 3.5/5Replayability: 3.5/5Aesthetics: 5/5Visuals: 4/5Atmosphere: 4.5/5Music: 3.5/5

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												Let me start off by saying that if you’re a gamer, whether it'd be casual or hardcore, you're doing yourself a severe disservice by not playing the Mass Effect series. This isn’t just a game, it’s an experience.  PROS (Where do I even begin):- Excellent story. I loved every minute of it and I had trouble putting the game down.- Lovable characters. The game excels in making you really care about the characters. I haven’t found one that I haven’t liked. Excellent voice acting, for the most part.- Branching dialogue. This is easily the best part of the series as your character interactions will be unique to create a more personalized experience.- Choices matter. The choices you make in this game carry over to the next which further establishes a more personal experience.- Excellent port. While I don’t have a monster computer, I can still run the game at the highest settings with no performance issues.- Sound/Music. The music is absolutely spot on and the sound design is also top notch.- Voice acting. Easily my favorite part of this series. I downloaded a Harbinger and Sovereign soundboard, as well as a few other characters’ simply because of how much I loved the many quotable dialogue sequences.- Main character customization. While you can’t fully physically customize your character, you can definitely create his/her face and a name (which won’t be used in the game since everyone refers to you by your last name, Shepard). - Massive potential for replay. In my first playthrough, I ran the game as a female paragon (making good choices). I’m now on my second playthrough, playing as the male “bad guy,” making evil decisions and killing off characters just to see how it will affect the plot in the next games. - Freedom. You can go wherever you want and tackle the missions in any order and the plot will still make sense. It’s the furthest thing from being a linear experience.- Flexibility. The game unravels itself based on the choices you make and that’s pretty cool. For example, when I was confronted by a certain main character, I could have resolved the matter by talking to him or intimidating him, but I chose to kill him, instead. How you handle missions/situations is largely up to you.- Varied classes. You can choose which class you want to play as. You have 3 pure classes in Biotic, Combat, and Tech: Adept (handles biotic based attacks), Soldier (combat specialist), or Engineer (tech specialist). Then you have hybrid classes: Vanguard (combat/biotics), Sentinel (tech/biotics), Infiltrator (tech/combat). Choose whichever sounds interesting to you. Classes really change up the way you play the game which further adds to the replay value.CONS:- Notoriously long elevator sequences. This game is known for having elevators that take forever! The elevator in C-Sec at the Citadel (you’ll see) that takes you to your ship takes over 40 seconds. This might not seem long, but you will be paying multiple visits to the Citadel and it will get EXTREMELY annoying. While there are several more annoying elevator sequences in the game, fortunately, they aren’t as long. Still annoying enough to mention.- A lot of the guns look the same with just different colors. They also fire the same, pretty much, with the same noise. The only differences are the stats. Fortunately, the way a gun fires and handles can be customized via the many ammo/gun upgrades you’ll find.- This game also has a bad habit of throwing more guns at you than you know what to do with. You get a 150 equipment limit which racks up quickly. I end up having to keep selling the ones I find and eventually got millions in cash over time. With all this money, there's not much to spend it on, considering that majority of the loot you find in various worlds will be better than the ones available in stores.- Lack of good armors. I just didn’t like the look and feel of a lot of the armors in the game. I wish armor aesthetics were much more varied because they felt boring. Also, armors are not customizable which sucks in a game where its main strength lies in personalizing user experience.SIDE NOTES:- I recommend you to not play this game below Veteran difficulty, as the AI is not too competent below that.- Don’t pick the pure classes, as I find them boring. Play as one of the hybrids: Vanguard, Sentinel, or Infiltrator. Vanguard is my absolute favorite.- Don't save Kaiden because I REALLY don't like that guy.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2011
												Mass Effect is one of THOSE GAMES that every gamer has to play at least once in their life. And for a good reason, too.As with most Western RPG's, it combines RPG with another genre; in this case, action.Mass Effect gunplay features Commander Sheapard figthing alongside two squadmates (of a choice of a total of six), using either assault rifles, shotguns, sniper rifles, or pistols. Fighting your enemies is also combined with skills. For example, a concept called "biotics." For lack of a better definition, biotics are somewhat psychic powers. you can use these powers to blast shockwaves at your foes, among other things.Mass Effect is also the kind of sci-fi game I love: it explains its concepts. From the religion of an alien species, to the average temperature of a planet, to the known history of the Citedel. Mass Effect creates its own universe, with hard sci-fi concepts.This space opera is a must play for any sci-fi fans, or RPG/ Third-Person-Shooter fans.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2011
												5/5 stars. A graphically attractive single-player game with Bioware's famous deep RP options. The overall story arc guarantees the same conclusion but offers some variety in NPC responses based on your personality and gender choice. The team combat system can be challenging to learn depending on the specialization you choose. ME1 is a good place to introduce yourself to the characters and background story if you can get it for under $10. I'm a relatively thorough player and got about 60 hours of fun from this. Driven gamers who strive to complete the main storyline will get 30-40 hours.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												If you haven't played the Mass Effect series yet, and are getting back to the roots before Mass Effect: Andromeda is released next year, than you shouldn't even be wasting time reading this, however if you do, you will see the following:The Mass Effect series, beginning right here is phenomenal. The entire series asied from one or two things was downright breathtaking. I was a dumbass and went 2,1,3. Don't do as I do, do them in order. Even though in all honesty it didn't take too much away from the overall experience aside from the consequences of a few decisions in the game prior. Which by the way is awesome. Choices made in the original game can have direct affects to two and three, and I imagine to the new one as well in some small fashion since Andromeda is to be a brand new experience. This game specifically was pretty good, being as old as it is it still holds up well graphically in some aspects. I was genuinely surprised by some areas, which like I said earlier, I played two first so I knew a step down in graphics was coming, but I thought it would be much worse than it was. The story line was awesome, great introduction into a vast universe with sprawling civilzations and intergalactic affairs that pit you right in the thick of it. Loved all of the little details and dialogue and backstories. Some glitching and tearing happens here and there, as well as the fact that you have to deal with a terrible ♥♥♥♥♥♥ terrible terrible terrible ♥♥♥♥♥♥ terrible ♥♥♥♥♥♥ rover driving around♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥you off with terrible ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥♥ terrible terrible controls (Luckily that's a very brief part) and really that's it. Go buy it, it's so good, the whole series is flat out great, you'll never forget some of the moments this series gives you. If you can't afford it, I'll buy it for you lol. Probably not, but maybe.

												This is an interactive movie with some Console style duck-behind-cover shooting sequences in between. There is also an arbitrary RPG element to the game.Mass Effect does not seem to know what it wants to be. I am force fed with options constantly "Which gun do you want, the crappy one you got already, or the great one you just found?" or "Do you want to be an behind-hole to this guy or do you want to be nice?", few of them seem to have any actual baring on my situation, and the ones that do are so embarrasingly obvious that I don't feel like they had to be choices in the first place.That being said, it is a very well made game and I do enjoy playing it.

Even to today's standards, this game is basically a must play.Now I'm going to play through the game again in order to prepare a career that I actually want to import into the second chapter.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												So, I'm giving this game an overall recommendation. This is probably one of my favorite games, but I can take a step back and state that there are several reasons to recommend this game, and reommend avoiding it, and several of them are outside the game itself.Reaons to recommend:Great graphics (especially for the time of initial release), great story, and pretty good gameplay, all the while being pretty light on system requirements. The Mass Effect trilogy is one of the most ambitious multi-game projects ever, and takes into account choices made in the first game and carries out consequences as late as the third game. Many of these choices may even seem small and inconcesquential at the time, only to surprise you that they even tracked that detail by the time you get that character through to the third game. If you want to experience the full story, and the ability to make all of the minor decisions along the way then you have to start here. The gunplay changes in each one, and this one is arguably the worst, or at least slowest (most rpg-ish) of the three, but for me the finale sequence of this game is probably one of the most exciting sci-fi action sequences I've ever seen, read, or played, and that it is interactive and not just one long cinematic makes it that much better.Reasons to avoid:I'll start with the big one first. Much to everyone's dismay and chagrin, the EA decided not to release Mass Effect 3 on Steam in a move to try and convert more people to EA's own distribution platform, Origin. If you get time invested in the first two games, and want to see the end of the story, you are going to have to install another client, and start your friends lists from scratch when looking for multiplayer matches, and deal with a new overlay, ui, and library separate from Steam. There is still an odd texture problem with one of the races not having the higher resolution textures applied to them, no matter what your settings are. I've found the former only a major irritation on principal, and only a minor irritation in practicality. The latter can easily be fixed with mods that will not only fix the issue with that race, but improve the look of the whole game overall. Finally, if you are crunched for time, you can start at Mass Effect 2, and use the interactive comic to experience the basics of the story of the first game, and make most of the major decisions for your character, while immediately gatting started on the second (and in my opinion, best) of the games.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												Summary: A great sci-fi RPG with fun dialogue and action.  It's a bit rough around the edges, but does not disappoint despite its age.+It's an epic space adventure, in which you save the galaxy!+Did the above sound awfully generic?  Well, I was surprised at the effort they put into creating a whole new universe with numerous alien races and technologies.  They even put this optional but very cool information in a codex whenever you interact with objects or people.+A diverse cast of crew members with cool backstories, They even talk to each other when you ride the elevator (and thank gods for that)!+Combat is generally fun.  Mostly with guns, as well as whatever technological or biotic (mass manipulating) skills you decide to learn.  You can also pause at any time to give orders to your party members.+The "morality" tree isn't clear-cut good/evil, but renegade/paragon.  So your lawful actions don't cancel out your chaotic ones, or vice versa.  Instead each contributes to their own separate bar, which enables more dialogue options in the future should you invest the skill points.+For the most part, you're free to do missions (both the main story and side missions) in any order you choose, flying around on your awesome spaceship-The character movement can be clumsy.  I've gotten killed more than once when Shepard decides he can "take cover" behind a tiny piece of debris.-Vehicular controls are extremely clumsy.  ♥♥♥♥ driving on hilly terrain, especially.-Side missions can be pretty repetitive after a while, especially since ~70% of them involve driving around planets that are reskinned versions of each other to get to buildings whose layouts are also copies of each other.-Inventory size limit is not a huge problem, but still a hassle.  Why did they bother?-What the other reviewers said about elevators is true.  There's too many of them and take too freakin' long!

												For anyone who played a Bioware game, especially KOTOR, Mass Effect would give a sense of constant déjà vu. They just happen and their stories seem forced.Playable character? A personal biography which has no real impact on the game and a good/evil dichotomy which was OK in Star Wars but is totally out of place in any other setting.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												The first Mass Effect is the best from all three, but it doesn't mean it's actually something to write home about. Well, at least to someone who read anything in his life beyond pornographic fan-fics and pretentious novels of 2000s. Unfortunately, the big chunk of post 2000 playerbase is made of the illitarate defined by the lowest possible denominator.Mass Effect is a mediocre third person shooter with little character customization that offers 2 ways of playing the game. Shoot everything and shoot everything with space magic. Bare bones, if you add a typical HOT pop-a-mole combat philisophy implemented in this game, that doesn't even tries to cover (pathetic pun intended) itself. One thing bugs me after my second playthrough. This game looks half-baked, or aborted in an early production phaze. There are parts of the game, where it seems that there was a creative spark somewhere, someone had a vision of a great s-f/space opera game, that wouldn't just make money, but will offer all s-f tropes and classics from all over in one place for everyone to enjoy. Then the writing started, art-direction department attempted to do something with style, aaaand... few weeks later they had to say "eh - ♥♥♥♥ it". And left the game with few interesting places to visit, few Codex (in-game lore encyclopedia) entries and a whole lot of filler content probably made by unexperienced interns. I do believe that most of the content in the game is a work of unexperienced hacks, just look at the Mako part of the game. I don't believe it would be passable even for a student. It boils down to disattachment between the lore part of the game, and the actual gameplay. The lore, places and characters are giving you a premise of varied experiences, but at the end of the game it all boils down to TPS action in a terribly designed locations. C&C boil down to occasional speech check (and since no one will play without these skills maxed out, everyone will get that option) that will end all filler quests non-violently with absolutely cringe-worthy dialogue lines. Just listen to the final dialogue with Saren. I couldn't help myself but laugh while listening to it. It's like taken straight from a terrible 10 years old s-f writer on the Internet. Just terrible.For a buck it's worth checking out. Just prepare for some cringe-fest and a lot of autism-inducing activities.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2015
												CombatI know this is the first one and they were getting some ground, but this is the weakest of the mass effect series.The combat is quirky and annoying where if you get close to a  wall you automatically get suction cupped onto it, and you have to waddle your way out. It would have just been easier to have a cover button. Meanwhile shooting, it's okay but your kinda op even with the normal guns, heck you could speed run without leaving starting weapons/armor.4/10Dialogue/CharactersNow this is the main reason I was interested in the games. The dialogue is very interesting and the story is very cool (especially the last battle) and you will stay immersed the entire time, until combat. The characters you find are cool and you will actually get a connection, they put more time into dialogue and characters rather than combat and it payed off, there isn't very much fighting and more talking which is great. The decisions you make actually hurt you and when you  get one of them killed you will feel like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ for leaving them to die .9/10EnviromentsThey put a lot of detail into the landscape and it is nice, I am not fond of using the rover though it feels clunky. I don't have much to say for this one though.7/10Final VerdictThe game is alright and I can understand them not putting too much effort into it, they didn't know how good it would be. But the Dialogue is great and the story holds up. They did fix the Combat in Mass Effect 2 which is fantastic.Mass Effect 1 = 7/10Not great but need to play if you want to get settled into the universe.Though one last comment for those who played Mass Effect 2/3 what the heck happened to Ashley? She get plastic surgery and a spray tan or something?

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												Mass Effect:Positives:+ A very narrative centered game filled with decisions which impact the way your character is perceived and how the world develops around you.+ Lots of dialogue explaining the background and plot of the title, so you become immersed in the story.+ Interesting array of weapons, with modifications which can increase weapon stability, damage, heat absorption and more.+ Mass Effect combines RPG and shooter elements to make an interesting action packed game. Level up your party by gaining experience from quests, killing enemies or decrypting locked cases. You can spend talent points to upgrade your skills in firearms, combat armour, health, electronics and more.Negatives:- For an RPG it isn't the longest game, taking around 45-60 hours to finish. I explored a lot of the galaxies and the main questline is sort of short. I didn't see everything the game had to offer but for the most part I did.- Graphics are really dated for a game released in 2008. In comparison, the Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion which hit the market in 2006, looks far superior. Nevertheless, you'll get used to it the more you play.- Inventory system isn't streamlined and a bit clunky, room for improvement here.Overall Score: 8/10There's something about Mass Effect that makes it a really intriguing RPG. It's approach is fresh, it stands out from the standard medieval style RPG's due to its futurisitc sci-fi outlook. Well worth picking this one up on sale.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2012
												This game is a near-perfect fusion of third person shooter and RPG.  It somehow manages to be both the best third person shooter I've ever played and a fantastic RPG at the same time.  It controls great and looks fantastic, though the character textures could definitely use some more resolution.  If only the game was moddable, the textures would be fixed in a week.The characters are engaging and the story is great.  Some people say that Bioware only ever tells one story, but it doesn't matter when they tell it so well.  RPG elements are straightforward and work well, though you will end up with tons of useless weapons since there's always one obvious choice for the best weapon to use of each type.My main complaint with the game is driving around on the random planets you visit.  Every planet has low gravity which makes driving around a chore.  In addition, most of them have extremely steep slopes almost everywhere which makes navigating an absolute nightmare.  Luckily most of this stuff is optional, and since the optional collection missions are entirely accomplished through these sections, they're best skipped.Any RPG fan should have this in their collection.  It's one of the true greats.
