content:
Posted: May 29, 2014
												Tough review for me to write, I've tried really, really hard to like this game. I wanted to love it, but I can't. There are a lot of things I want to talk about, and I'll start with its presentation. It's horrid, the game gives you almost zero context on what's going on, and there are no tutorials whatsoever. The game simply drops you in the middle of combat after confusing conversations basically telling you "figure it out". This is an extremely bad way to introduce the game to newcomers.The dialogues and writing to me was overall impressively great to an extent. The voice acting is spot on, and the ability to choose a response in a conversation is superbly good, definitely one of the game's highlights. However, there are some significant cons to those, such as the fact that a large amount of animation hiccups occur throughout the cutscenes. Something that also bothered me is the lack of expressive faces, which in my eyes, makes some of the character lines feel awkward to look at.Speaking of which, the characters within the game are in general pretty nice. Garrus, Wrex, and Tali being the most fun, in my opinion. Though, this brings me into talking about another one of the game's issues: I couldn't find almost any of the human characters appealing, perhaps with the exception of Joker in some ways. The rest of the cast, such as the Ambassador, Kaidan, Ashley, Anderson, among others feel dull from my perspective. They have development, but there's nothing remotely interesting about any of them to me aside that Anderson was supposed to be the first human spectre.Now to talk about some of the other game's issues, perhaps one of the things that irritated me the most was the memory core sequence that the game throws at you without any explanation over how to get through it. Another thing that left me in absolute agony at times was the checkpoint/save system. The game has autosave, but the time span between the saves is flabbergasting. At one point I had gone through an entire Mako section, and after finally getting off of it and killing some Geth, I was killed and forced to repeat that whole vehicle part again.Jumping real quick on the game's writing. As I've previously stated, the presentation is terrible, but it does get better as the game progresses. That being said, I can't help but question the game's writing decisions sometimes. While I was very satisfied with the ending, and thought the story was very well written for the most part, I've stopped to ponder a little on the mentality behind the game's writing. The defining factor of Mass Effect is that you're a human. That is your race and that plays arguably the biggest role in the game's story. From start to finish you'll notice constant racist remarks, not only towards humans, but towards other races as well, such as the krogan, turians, batarians, and so on. It works, but it feels really simplistic and weak.This makes me contemplate about the game's narrative. I've enjoyed it, but something feels off, like it is too predictable at times. Politicians always being ignorant, few heroes, galaxy's fate at stake, the enemy being the strongest thing in existence... This isn't exactly a bad thing, but the game deals superficially with its themes. The undeniably strong point to the game's plot and playability is its length. It is one that will consume your time drastically, it's not something you should expect to beat fast. It will require time.Gameplay-wise, my perception is very mixed over it. I have to note that the A.I. is stupid, and the ones that do speak have some wincing lines. I gotta say that its flaws are overlooked, my guess is because of the game's story. There just isn't much value to the gameplay. The customization is good enough, but nothing really special. The game pretends to be a RPG, but there is no real exploration, the side missions are tedious, no real sense of level up, and the combat is very plain.The majority of the soundtrack is precisely well composed, despite very few annoying songs. Withal the placement of some of the songs in certain scenes and environments is strange and unfitting, to say the least, but thankfully most of the time that doesn't detract from its quality. I don't have much to say about the game's graphics, I expected better and saw some really ugly textures, but they're okay as they are.I've been told Mass Effect 2 is a lot better than the first one, I have yet to find this out. As of now all I can judge is the first game, and it wasn't as good as I wanted it to be, as I was hoping it to be. Instead I was met with disappointment, ranging from the apathetic character expressions to frustrating checkpoints. From the lack of guides to the monotonous gameplay. I just cannot personally recommend it, I believe it's a nice introduction to the series, but as a game alone it's not worth the experience to me. I hate to say this. 4.9/10.0

content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
Mass Effect--A MasterpieceIf you like Knights of the Old Republic--style games, this is it and it's great. BioWare.Command the Normandy SR1, a ship under your indirect control (you interact with NPCs to to do most functions aboard). It's awesome to command a ship that let's you pretty much free roam across the galaxy. The main quest-line is rich as hell, and extremely easy to get sucked into. My interest was to beat this game doing as few side quests as possible (mostly because I learned of an awesome *choice scene*, btw Ashley is hawt). It took a bit over 20 hours to complete the main quest-line. Alternate endings and in-game decisions are here!MINOR complaints:- The game was designed for Xbox360 play, and for an odd reason, the game only supports a keyboard and mouse. I'm not saying this makes the game any less enjoyable, but the interface is slightly clunky.- Resolution issues (no 1080) can be fixed easily by adjusting the game's configuration files--check out google, or message me if you need help :). FORGET THE COMPLAINTS!! THE GAME IS GREAT!+ Import your Mass Effect 1 save game into Mass Effect 2, and the game will know every choice you made!+ Replayability: Change your character class, choose different members to do missions with, make different decisions!+ Modded texture update--give the game the beauty it deserves with a community graphics update (google)Bought the game during weekend sale, damn glad I did. Came in a package with ME1 and ME2 (including extras) for around $5. No trading cards or steam achievements, unfortuantely, but a damn fine game that will certainly give me over 50+ hours of play. I'll be playing it again!!

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												The year was 2007. With Halo, Gears of War, the Call of Duty franchise and many others, the gaming community showed an insatiable lust for more shooter action. Gamers and critics just couldn't get enough of holding "up" and "shoot" on their computers/controllers, or joining multiplayer to spam the sniper rifle and brag about their kill count as they shot helpless victims from miles away; praising their own "skill". As you can probably guess, I LOATHED this day of gaming. For the few that agreed with me, there was hope on the horizon. A game that had some shooting in it, but mostly story telling and RPG aspects was announced: Mass Effect. The name was unique, the box art was gorgeous, all the reviews were inundated with perfect scores...and I was broke, so I got it later for PC at a discount. I couldn't imagine what I was in for. The all around plot is admittedly cliche, but the journey more than makes up for it. You play Commander (Sir, or Madam) Shepard. You are at first tasked with gathering a team of mercenaries/scientists ect to chase a rogue spec ops agent across the galaxy. The story blows up into something much more, but fans of sci-fi might have tread this ground a little too often. Though not totally original, the story telling is where the selling point is. Characters in M.E. are no doubt a high standard in RPG character design. The voice work and art style are the stuff of legends. However, I'd say ME's biggest achievement is the writing itself. They succeed in making every conversation facinating! Each party member has a past and a motivation that you want to hear all about. You care about everyone on board. The game is on an immersion overload at all times in this regard. It gives all the shooting a point. Unfortunately, the game ends on a very akward, anti-climactic note, but that doesn't halt the high replay value. Play it again as a Soldier. Play as the other gender. Be a good guy/ bad guy. There are many reasons to come back and play again. ME plays like a third person, cover shooter. There are 3 classes to play with 3 others being mixes of the previous, so 6 in total. Soldier, Adept (or "mage"), and Engineer are the main 3. Adepts introduce their own bizzare twist on magic known as biotics; a mental power of gravity and who I personally found the most fun while slinging enemies around or catapulting them to their doom. To keep it all managable, it mostly revovles around a "combat pause" where you can assign teammates to cover, use certain abilities, focus fire, and others. It works really well. What doesn't work well is when you are forced to drive the M35 Mako; an all terrain, space vehicle. Its controls are clunky and unintuitive. Aiming the turret is stressful while dodging the 100's of projectiles, and the "shields" regenerate painfully slow. I've recovered from wounds in real life faster than this thing's shields do. The other only issue I have with gameplay is the enemy Krogen. They use an appropirately named ability called Immunity; reducing damage taken significantly, becoming immune to CC effects, rapidly regenerating HP, 2 shotting you with melee, and even a self ressurection if they die. Was this even play tested? Flaws aside, I did very much enjoy my time in ME's firefights.Sound is where the game really shines, mostly due to the outstanding voice cast. They cover wide range of voices, and they all deliver their lines perfectly. Combined with the legendary writing, and interacting with your teammates is more fun than the gameplay itself. It's so easy to say things like "immersive" because they are diluted buzz words for marketing. It also doesn't help that I can't say much without spoiling any of it. If you don't believe me, youtube some of the cutscenes yourself. My favorite sounds are the guns. They have a unique mix of projectile and laser "pew" that makes them satisfying to shoot. Robot sounds rival the quality of Ben Burtt's work in Star Wars or Wall-E.The music too is always delightful. Very space-y sounding, ambiant, and relaxing. My favorite track being the title theme. It's one of those tracks you want set to loop and fall asleep to. 


wtf? EA............................. 
A Screenshot of Mass Effect
By: okeaon




Last thing I will address is the controversy over the sex scene in the end (if you so choose to "romance" one of your crew members). I'm glad we're concerned over what our kids see, but let's remember; the game is rated M 17+ for a reason. IT'S NOT A KIDS GAME. Kids cannot legally play it unless they have a legal guardian or are accompanied by a parent who must be 18yrs or older. In the current system, the responsibility lies in the right place: the parents. At least is a short segment that is a bit cryptic to find and you actually "romance" the person by getting to know them first, unlike Mass Effect 3 where it is involuntarily "Immature Facebook Teens Orgy in Space".Final verdict is a 9/10. Despite some major flaws, Mass Effect is an experience you can't miss!

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												Background: This was my first playthrough and i cleared about 95% of the sidemissions. I have not played any Mass Effect titles before. It got recommended a lot, so I bought it in summersale to finally get my hads on the legendary saga.Short review: I am not really into heavy roleplaying. Dialogue/Running around/Fighting felt about 50/40/10. Played on veteran (highest possible difficulty on 1st playthrough) and didn't feel challenged by any fight. Game is as old as it is so a lot of gameplay mechanics felt outdated. Story is okay, characters well-written. Beware of elevators and lightning bugs.For everyone stil reading on:Welcome to the longer abstract on "Elevator Simulator Effect 1". (You really spend a long time in elevators in this game so excuse the joke)Mass Effect is a game that recieved a lot of recommendations so i finally got around to try it out and play it through. I can't say that I would recommend it. The game is quite old and i don't feel that it aged well. Slight shader-bugs where my party turned into black blobs were quite offputting aswell (didn't happen too often fortunately and could be fixed with some console-tempering). I understand that Mass Effect is mostly a storydriven game and storywise it felt slightly better than average. It didn't really catch me. You can blame that on me not being the type of player who enjoys standing around for 15 minutes and listening to dialogue. I relied heavily on reading subtitles as fast as i can and getting back into action.Speaking of action: Fights make about 10% or less of the gameplay. The fight system felt clunky, party management outside of "go there and fire away" wasn't really needed. There were occasions where i got oneshot by me being a dunce and stepping into enemy rockets but aside of that, combat didn't feel challenging or tactical at all. I mostly let my party hack enemies and make them float through the air while shooting them with pistols (heatsink upgrades for unlimited bulletstorm). Maybe Liara and Talia are op, but the last fight was over in about 15-20 seconds without me really doing anything (some bug prevented me from firing my guns there). I played on veteran and understand that there are higher difficulties available on 2nd playthrough. I don't see the point in that. Why not enable them upfront?Side Missions feel mostly like chores. Planets and structures on it get repetitive really quickly and pay out well. Stores barely have anything worth to buy so i was walking around with 999 omnigel and 9999999 credits during the two/three final missions.Main Missions are interesting and Character development is a plus. The dialogues were all around well written.I think i would have enjoyed the game more if it cut all the walking around, fighting and boring riding-around-in-your-gummyball-vehicle-on-planet-surfaces sequences (i despise this vehicle after using it that much). As it is, the gameplay feels too old and drags down the overall enjoyment of the game too much.EDIT: corrected some spelling mistakes//2016-07-04

content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
												I tried to play this. I have a stomach for old clunky games. I love rich story games, and I enjoy shooters. So of course I loved this classic, right?Nope. Not even close.The slog was too much. And the dialogue was.... well it was okay, but not enough to keep me playing. The choices were rarely interesting, (I stopped before finishing chapter 3) I've heard the romance is laughably bad, and the rest was patchy. I enjoyed the one-off humorous lines. I enjoyed meeting interesting individuals in an interesting world. I was really intrigued and talking to lots of npcs when I started. I met all of the squad members. I remember the Hanar and the Elcor races fondly. It was a cool introduction to the Asari and Quarians. But the large percentage time spent in tedious combat, and the times it was unclear where I was supposed to go or who I was supposed to talk to, overshadow that. Mass Effect 2 and 3 do everything better. A best case scenario might be playing ME1 for an hour or four, until you explore the Citadel and are able to leave on the Normandy. Then stop.The story is Mass Effect 1 is easily passed up, I hardly remember the parts I played. I made it to half of chapter 3. (meaning I missed the critical, possibly interesting conclusions, for this chapter and beyond.) The choices were interesting in principle, but dadadadun! You can play the Mass Effect 2 comic! It'll take about 15 minutes, none of the headache, and 50% of the story goodness. You'll miss making full sets of choices, and all of the fun dialogue is gone, but, yes. It is worth the trade. Whiiiich appears to cost way more than it should. (it was given to me) I hear there is a save editor "Gibbed's ME2 Save Editor."Mass Effect 2 is so much better. It fills you in just fine. Go forward from there. (you can still make your own choices a bit in the comic/save editor) Mass Effect 3 is yet another exponential leap improved beyond 2. Don't miss those games because this one is so hard to enjoy.

number of helpful: 0 of 6 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2016
												As other reviews have said the strongest elements of the game might be the story and over all atmosphere of the game. But I got very bored with all the dialogue and  traveling around, and seemingly small amount of action. And then when you did have some action the controls felt very clunky. I'm not a huge fan of cover based fps games, but have played some before that I still managed to enjoy for example Deus Ex Human Revolution. The biggest negative for me is I am not terribly entertained by story driven games where the story / cutscenes / dialogue / traveling take up most of your time, and there is very little action. There are other games that still have a very strong story, but still give you plenty of action where you can feel like a badass, for example Skyrim. Which brings up another huge negative for me: a very linear map system. I can see from a developer's standpoint making a huge open world ala Skyrim is much much more time consuming. Making a simple linear map system is quick and easy and works well with a heavily story driven game. But it makes for much less interesting gameplay as you are forced down a very narrow path every where you go. The final nail in the coffin is that I decided to come back to ME and attempt to finish my game that I started I guess a couple years ago, and now the game doesn't even run anymore and crashes within 10 seconds of doing anything. But maybe the last bit is my PC's fault since it is way over due for a hard drive wipe and fresh install of the OS.

content:
Posted: March 1
												I just played Mass Effect for the first time in Dec. 2016. I'm able to over look the dated graphics of 2008. The diverse set of alien species is very cool. I appreciate the character models and how character class is set up.  My favorite part is searching through the galaxy on the star map? <-- this shouldnt be my favorite peice of the game.I cannot recommend this game. The controls and combat is clunky. Having to choose the appropriate team (3 including commander shepard) to go on a mission makes no sense considering the games provides no information as to what you will encounter on the mission. Too often you will find something that is hackable, but you have the wrong squad for it. (HOW THE F*** are you suppose to know that?).  This leads to save and reload which completely destroys immersion and flow of the game.Worst of all is the constant cinematics.. I don't mind it occasionaly, but when the entire plot is shown through cinematics, as is with ME, what's the point of playing a game? After a scene or a dialogue you may be immediately thrown into combat with no chance to prepare (why does it automatically switch to my pistol every time when I had shotgun in hand?). Thus leading to one of your squad mates killed and you cannot prevent it.. ooop forgot to save now have to reload from a save from 1 hour ago.Squad AI is bad. Too often commands do not function as they should.I thought I would give ME a try being the 4th installment is coming out soon. The frustration with this game is not worth it to learn the history and lore of the game beforehand.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2016
												For quite a few years I kept hearing how great Mass Effect is. Recently I picked it up on a deep discount and thought I'd give it a shot in large part due to the massive positive reviews and the fact that I am a big sci-fi game fiend. I'm close to 20 hours into the game so far. One of the recurring themes in overwhelmingly positive reviews for Mass Effect concerns the story and plot. Most of them read something like this "OMG OMG OMG THE STORY!" I'm sure for the junior high school Console Cadet Crew sitting on the living room couch munching fruit roll-ups and guzzling juice boxes while binge playing Mass Effect back in 2008 the story was/is epic. To me, not so much. Mass Effect's story line is really generic and predictable. Insert a generic interstellar alien alliance, a basic ancient alien super race that vanished without a trace (Precursors from Star Control or the Martians in Altered Carbon). Include a generic agent that for reasons only known to him goes rogue, a half dozen or so goofy alien species to interact with, and then mix thoroughly for a generic set of game missions and plot. There's nothing new here folks.Players start the game learning basic controls at the alien super race mega space station called the Citadel and will spend a majority of the time engaging in character dialogue sessions. The character interaction is limited and predictable as far as the outcome goes. It's a lot like those old 1970's choose your own path novels and that equals boredom. When you do finally get past all the introductory character chatty Kathy sessions and are free to start a combat mission you'll be presented with a lackluster experience. The gameplay is repetative. The ship you command will drop you onto a planet surface in a six-wheeled truck with a sloth of a tank cannon. Exploring each planet surface feels the same- each one is void of any detail and the only thing that will change is the color of the dirt and/or the sky. Roll up to a base, exit the truck and take your three character team into harm's way. You'll know you are about to get shot at inside each base as soon as you see the one room full of crates. It's always those damned crates that gives away the surprise you're about to get jumped by a bunch of bad guys. After rinse and repeating a few planets worth of missions I found I didn't really care what was going on anymore. It's noise.As far as the combat controls are concerned they are a clunkfest straight out of Sanford and Son's salvage yard- it's pure junk. I think the main problem here is playing Mass Effect with a mouse and keyboard. The game probably was not meant for that kind of precise setup and best suited to a console gamepad. As a result playing it on a PC can be wildly jittery and sloppy when it comes to the combat portions. I'm sure the gamepad funky bunch like it just fine...To sum up Mass Effect quickly, it is a wildly overrated game that I will finish but I don't need to follow it up with Mass Effect 2 or 3. Mass Effect simply is not that good. It's past it's prime and probably should have stayed on consoles where it could have been remembered fondly by those who loved it. On the PC platform it is a dated game that will rapidly be forgotten. It doesn't work well or at all on Windows 7/8/10 machines so that could be another major reason to skip Mass Effect. It is stable on XP with only minor glitches/bugs.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												This game is a 3 hour interactive movie with 12 hours of subpar corridor shooting.+ There are a few goods side quests and some good dialogs- Big step back from KOTOR in many areas.- Very poor fighting mechanics, the RPG elements are almost non existent- Zero AI, both the party and the enemies are increadibly dull. There is always some enemy who comes close and backs out, there is one who stands still without doing anything, and the rest just goes pewpew without any tactics.- The level design is incredibly boring. Mostly the only thing to do is go straight in a corridor. The mission to finding Liara T'Soni is literrally about going straight with the maco, and killing a few enemies on the way, then get off the maco, walk a few yards, another few kill, and so on. Then there is an increadibly small dungeon with nothing to explore. - Another annoying thing, how everything is static in the world. There are people standing or sitting straight and basically not moving, not doing anything. The Witcher was released around the same time and that game had way more detailed rutines for the world.- Space exploration is about clicking on planets and read a card, sometimes it is possible to click on survey and collect some gas or something. At least a few worlds can be visited and a few minor things looted, like some tags, or there is a fight with some lame♥♥♥♥♥enemy. There is no depth in space exploration.

number of helpful: 2 of 12 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28
												When I first purchased this, I had very immense interest in this, as my play hour count indicates.I've had a little time to think since then, however, and now... Honestly, I can't much recommend this.Now, mind you, when the game is fun, it's *very* fun, at least in my opinion. The choice systems are also very empowering. I also like the realistic political and power play sub-plots.However, the main reason I don't recommend this is the event prioritization. Note: Spoiler-bearing Examples will be entailed.At first, I *like* how the events flow; they do so smoothly, seamlessly carrying the story and intrigue. This carries on for the earliest part of the game....Then, it gets to where you're supposed to go to the different planets- and that's when the deal-breaking (for me) downsides kick in.For one, the sense of direction is rather poor. Perhaps this is only an issue for a moron like me, but getting lost is very easy in this game. I can't tell you how many times I lost my way in a ruin or even an office building in this game, and eventually had to just stick to taking every right turn to wind up where I'd started. The mini-map can help in understanding the landscape, which actually makes it fantastic for the derelict planet exploration missions, but it offers no help in finding the actual objectives.This isn't just limited to complex indoor structures, either. I recall at least several times trying to play the game through, I just zipped from one end of a long vehicle-entailing track to another, and wound up going back to the starting point several times. the Scenery is seldom well-distinguished enough to facilitate differentiation of direction. If you're an intelligent sort like most people, this shouldn't be a problem. However, for a moron like myself, this means having no choice but to just keep holding the drive button, never stopping, and hoping that I don't get flipped. When there are foes ahead who want to blow me and my buggy to hell and back, I must stop well ahead of the threat to get out and shoot them; otherwise I risk losing direction if I try to fight them via tank, or getting killed if I press on to avoid losing track.Additionally, the flow of events on individual planets is absurdly disorganized. Things seem to happen in a strange sequence that makes the visits seem more like fever dreams than missions. Perhaps Bioware assumed that we were going to follow a specific sequence ourselves, and programmed the events likewise?Anyway, scenes themselves also seem to introduce characters and factors more quickly than I for one can take them in, and seldom (although thankfully not never) provides a means to clarify who someone or what something is. This often entails characters and objects that are very important to story and, in fact, to gameplay.Even when I manage to make it through the assorted missions, I often find myself coming out- and this is even after repeated playthroughs- wondering what just happened.This might only be an issue for my own inferior mind. Even so, I don't think I can recommend this game.

number of helpful: 1 of 12 people (8%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
												Pros:Interesting Sci-Fi universeCons:Inconsistent gameplay across the length of the series.Obnoxious DLC pricing by BiowareLocked into Origin if you want to see the third episode.Absolute Do-Not-Buy:A branching, multi-game plot that culminates in "Press X for the Blue ending".  Bioware didn't just drop the ball in the end, they fumbled it so hard it sank to the core the core of the planet and nearly set off the China Syndrome (old-timey movie reference for you kids).  There's wrapping things up with a tawdry deus ex machina, and then there's absolutely squandering any potential built up over dozens of different of different choices by deliberately managing giant plotholes so that we all end up with essentially one ending movie anyhow.  All those characters and races and intergalactic politics don't matter one whit once the ending turns out to be some spurious blech pseudo-religious mumbo jumbo just thrown at us out of the blue.  No matter how interesting the series was overall, every action turned out to ultimately irrelevant because the so-called "writers" behind the plot turned out to be intellectually dishonest and creatively bankrupt.  These developers copped out so hard they should get into politics. Final verdict:Never ever buy any Bioware product again; honestly, i wish i could block specific developers from my Steam so i never even hear about this company again.  Probably should avoid EA Games as well.

number of helpful: 19 of 55 people (35%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												I want to like this game. I really do. But so much stands in the way.Let's just lay it out as people do around here:+ Beautifully detailed world-building with lots of lore; the Citadel is great for this. The interesting alien races and their histories and personalities are a godsend for sci-fi fans, finally realised in full video game form for the first time. Cute additions, such as the lounge versions of the themes in the lifts, are particularly nice.+ Certainly cinematic, not lacking in scale, and visually impressive in terms of design+ High-quality voice acting+ Believable sci-fi characters and good dialogue, particularly your party members.+ Combat and upgrade mechanics are solid. Biotic moves are fun. + The decisions you make (negotiate or fight, be noble or be a♥♥♥♥♥♥ how to go about missions) help to personalise the experience.But all those treats are held back by a myriad of negatives:- The amount of time-filler and loading screens (stated or otherwise i.e. lifts and unskippable cutscenes) is frankly inexcusable. - Painfully slow movement. Shepard runs so slow it's like his thighs are bolted on.- The game delights in spacing its objectives between the longest corridors and open spaces possible, to obscure the fact that there are only about six or seven main levels in this whole game.- Despite its solid upgrade mechanics, half of the action takes place in the unupgradable, unwieldy Mako; a tank that is powerful enough to defeat any enemy in its path with ease. Of course, that's after you've rolled the Mako down the long empty corridor between those enemies.- Through the galaxy map and the large quest journal, the game provides the illusion of having a whole galaxy to explore, with lots of quests to invest in. However most of the planets you can't go to (some you can 'survey' which basically means clicking a button to gain experience). This would be fine and quite reasonable if those you could go to were good fun, but sadly every explorable area outside of the main quest is a large, empty world with a few objectives widely spaced apart, often with awkward hills placed to make getting there (in the Mako, of course) as lengthy (but not difficult) as possible. The main objectives are repetitive; find some enemies you've encountered before and defeat them. There's little payoff for doing quests outside the Citadel relative to the amount of time you invest; the most you recieve is a short prompt of text saying basically "there's no need to remain here any longer". In short, why bother?- Boring, inconvenient loot and inventory system. Yes, the PC version is an improvement over the 360 version, but that doesn't stop most of what you find from being unidentifiable and worthless. - Dumb, boring, repetitive enemies and encounters. The amount of times I spent potshotting at a completely static Geth Armature...- Combat is rather dull; aside from a few quirks, its a clumsy, clunky cover shooter.- For all the effort gone into the presentation, there are some frustrating flaws; characters can teleport out of scene during in-game dialogue, and texture pop and artifacting is frequent. Character models look good and realistic but have robotic movements, particularly head turning, leading to uncanny valley moments.- Mass Effect's greatest strength, its characters, is never fully exploited. For example I fell in love with Tali as a character as soon as I met her, but my desire to find out more about her and befriend her was frustratingly unfulfilled.- The story is decent as sci-fi goes, but not great. There's nothing revolutionary here; it's a trope-tastic, deadly serious, high-fantasy sci-fi story about soldiers. There's little to nothing emotional or moving here. It's a plot that in a film would require a lot of pace and action to keep it interesting. Mass Effect has no pace, and underwhelms signficantly on action.I gave Mass Effect two chances. I wanted to come back and be pleasantly surprised when I played the game for a second time on the PC, but now I'm more convinced than ever that it's one of the most overrated games of all time. It doesn't lack for ambition, but for the most part Mass Effect is dry, dull, and arbitrary.

number of helpful: 4 of 22 people (18%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												While I can see why people like this game, I'd like to warn against the hype.  Not because of the things everyone is saying are bad about this game, (the MAKO, crappy RPG/shooter hybrid combat) but because of what people like - the story.  This is a game that promises great story and characters, but delivers on neither.  The developers do a superb job building anticipation, giving a sense of a wider world, but do absolutely nothing with it - just a by the numbers "save the galaxy from evil invaders" plot that could have been copy-pasted from a Michael Bay movie.  Make no mistake, this is not Planescape: Torment or Fallout 2, but a game whose story, although carefully polished, says absolutely nothing.  The characters in your party are sometimes interesting (the tech-alien girl is decent) but are mostly flat, having nothing much in the way of a character arc and only a single motivation.  This is exacerbated by the clumsy dialogue system; not being able to see what you're going to say is crippling on its own, but restricting to four options removes all subtlety from interactions.If you compare it to the likes of Skyrim, sure, the story looks pretty good.  But that game has vast, open landscapes to explore, a reasonably deep customisation system, and more importantly a mod community that can make the game whatever you want it to.  Mass Effect (and its sequels) really have nothing but their story (and some pretty graphics) and there's just not enough there to justify the time you'll spend on this, let alone the money.  If you want to play a modern story-based RPG, the Witcher series is superior in story, character depth, story interaction, *and* has decent combat.  Alternatively Alpha Protocol has a similar style to Mass Effect, but characters you will take more than thirty seconds to figure out.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												As much story as this game has to offer, realistically speaking that's the full extent of the "game." I'm not sure I've played a game with a worse combat system and the inventory / squad management system is more of a detriment to the game than an asset. Coupled with the fact that the basic pacing of the game's levels is poor, balance of early game enemies poor, and a squad AI that makes the Destiny AI look good, I would say this game is a 6/10 at best, purely due to the writing. I understand that looking back at older games can be hard to justify with some of the features that are presented in modern games, but this game brings little to the table that justifies a full - playthrough. I would recommend just watching all of the cutscenes on YouTube so you don't have to pull yourself through the pitiful mechanics that would make an otherwise great game extremely mediocre.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2016
												It may be over the top to say this is one of the worst games ever made. . . but it is pretty terrible.  Yes, yes, there's a decent story.  Unfortunately, this is mired down by some of the worst gameplay features I've ever come across in such a popular title.  The shooting mechanics in Mass Effect are past the point of bad, past the point of laughable, and right back around to anneurism inducing.  There is no story that has ever been crafted by man that would make up for the gameplay in this *game*.  I'm not going to turn this into a huge hate rant, and to be fair, this is the only game in the series I have played.  I have heard the gameplay in ME2 and 3 are not just better, but actually very fun.  Hopefuly I will find time to force myself to choke down this bitter pill so that I can play the fun titles in the series, some day.  After all these years, and five or six tries with this title, I am not sure that will ever happen.As an afterthought, I feel it necessary to point out that I am a huge Bioware fan.  Loved the KoTOR series, Jade Empire, pretty much anything they've ever done.  This would have been so much better as a turn-based d20 game than a bad shooter, and I love shooters.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												My play time in Mass Effect is 158 hours. In total I've spent over 500 hours across the series. I've read every novel and every comic. It is without a doubt the best space opera of the past decade, in any medium.But as a game, this does not hold up. The inventory system is both cumbersome and shallow. The shooting is unsatisfying. The powers are meaningless. The cover system is just... bad.The dialogue system, while unique at the time, is riddled with problems. Many of the paraphrased choices are wholly inaccurate. Some dialogue choices aren't even choices at all, and end up with Shepard saying the same thing no matter what you choose. And perhaps worst of all, Renegade Shepard in this game isn't a pragmatic "win-at-any-cost" anti-hero, she's just a jerk.All of these problems are addressed and fixed in Mass Effect 2. My recommendation? Buy Mass Effect 2. Buy the Genesis DLC which gives a rundown of the events of this game and allows you to make the major choices. Have fun playing a good video game.

number of helpful: 16 of 50 people (32%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												I'd avoided this game for 7 years because it looked like Bioware had lost the rights to do another Kotor but still wanted to do more Sci-Fi, so filed off the serial numbers and filled the void left by fun Star Wars lore with generic Sci-Fi garbage. I picked it up in a sale not long ago, and the very worst part about my experience with the game is that it was exactly what it looked like. I know that standards have improved from 7 years ago, and I know this is a port, but I never have trouble with old ("old") games if they're well designed. This one was not. It's a Story-based RPG, and the two worst things about it are the Story and the RPG.The Story is essentially a chase-this-one-guy quest, in which you spend most of the game getting information on where he is or knocking off a major minion. Eventually you catch up to him, and there's a big reveal about an even worse bad guy with no personality besides omnicidal smugness. Whee. I could forgive a boring overarching plot if the companions and sidequests were interesting, but unfortunately neither of these are true either.Of the 6 selectable companions, only Wrex and Garrus have any personality, and even then it's just "Let's fight everything" and "Let's ignore the law" respectively. Tali and Liara (barely remembered her name) have almost no personality, and the two human companions Kaiden ("Kaiden", really?) and Ashley (really? x 2) are less interesting than even the worst Kotor had to offer. When it came time to choose which human to kill, I really wished it could have been both.The world is boring; you have space-elves, space-orcs, etcetera, none of which are memorable. The environments are all   squeaky-clean to the point of sterility, even on planets that are implied to be dirty. Kotor's graphics left room for the imagination, but Mass Effect's are just good enough that there are no blanks to fill in. This ultimately harms the atmosphere, as the game fills these blanks with empty rooms. It doesn't help that sidequests recycle the same 4 or so rooms (yes, literally; only 4 or 5 generic rooms used for every single sidequest mini-dungeon).The RPG elements are hopeless; the equipment is actively frustrating to manage, because you get 5 items for every cleared room on top of containers, etc, all of which is generally worse than what you use (but not always, and you have to check every single time you open the menu; the game literally doesn't let you access your gear until you either accept or discard new items one by one). The weapons are uncreative; of the four gun types, each has 4 or 5 different models each with a version I-VIII with minor differences. Even the different models are just reskins (a blue skin, a red skin, etc). The result is that you never get attached to your gear. It doesn't matter, and it's actively easier not to try to keep it up to date.The dialogue, the best part of Kotor, is boring here. The Light/Dark options (sorry, Paragon/Renegade) lead to the exact same results most of the time, in the few instances they show up or actually affect the story at all. I never thought I'd say it, but I miss the extremes of Star Wars morality, as here there are only three ways to say the same thing.The least worst part of the game is the combat, which is passable despite being full of infinite-ammo-overheating guns and only half a dozen basic enemy types. Still, the difficulty is hopeless; the game is a cakewalk with occasional extreme spikes of difficulty. My favourite moment was getting one-shot killed by a sniper coming out of a cut-scene with no chance to take cover or even move.The game is undercooked, or worse, unfinished. I won't say I didn't have a single moment of fun with this Sci-Fi romp, and the climactic chapter was a nice set-piece. The primary voice acting from some reliable talent was great, too. But take away the voice acting, take away the spit-shine, and what's left is a game that plays like an Early Access title.

												the story seems decent and all, i want to recommend it. but i can't.i didn't even finish the game. i am not an fps guy, i mainly wanted to taste this "amazing" game everyone told me about and was very disappointed.the balancing of enemies is just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, you get shot down in 1-2 shots while they may need ♥♥♥♥tons to kill, companions mostly die and you have to manage everything they do (even if you have set the "power use" on active). in the end i even managed to die even with a cheat for lots of shields (which brings me back to questionable balancing).i'd be more inclined to play "normaly" but guess what. you have to manually save EVERY TIME. last time i forgot about it, i was set back by 2 tedius hours of fighting and talking and♥♥♥♥♥♥ No. just no. for 2016 this is just not what i look for.Most of your time in the game is just in some corridor, or an elevator (and there are hell of a lot of them).performance is hurting. (i read somewhere that computers can be "too good" for this game and it slows it down O.o)it has its merits. i guess if you don't suck at fps combat and if you remember to save every second step you would be probably fine and if you manage to bypass the performance issues.me? i can't recommend this. just watch a playthrough on youtube.TL;DR: if you get it you will get frustrated till it plays decently.you will die and remember the last save was yesterday.not recommended. watch playthrough on youtube.PS. don't get me wrong. it is not like i want my game to be easy. i just don't want it to be frustrating. this is frustrating.

Posted: December 29, 2014
												I could only go through about 8 hours of this game because of the absolutely terrible porting of the combat.Your squad mates AI is horrifyingly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, will not follow your orders, can't navigate to a waypoint WITH NO OBSTACLES between the character and the waypoint.Shooting somebody who's behind cover, but you can clearly see stick up from their cover, does nothing.Combat is very VERY buggy, sometimes oponents will stand right up in your face and do nothing. sometimes they shoot you without damaging you, and sometimes you shoot them without dealing any damage to them.on top of that if you do not mod in proper texture packs even the "ultra high" texture is ridiculously pixelated, cs source had higher pixel density on the character models.It's a shame because the conversation component, the loot system, atmosphere and story is very compelling, unfortunately I can't really see any way of avoiding combat, and the combat really makes the game unplayable on pc.Since this was released 6 years ago these issues will not be fixed. I heard it was pretty good on console though so if you're a peasant you might not experience these combat issues and have a playable game.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												Friends are in love with it. I can't stand it after trying it now.The menu layout is just horrible. You're not told any information. Want to know how much health you have wthout pausing to go to the main menu? Too bad. It's just a cryptic healthbar that goes to 0 in a few shots it seems. And you're in the middle of both of your squad members' health bars. Really bad place and the italics are just bleh.The item menu is even worse though. Switching weapons is almost impossible to notice. None of the stats seem to do anything. Maybe they do, but it doesn't seem like it. And having to constantly upgrade your squad's items isn't fun. Especially when they each have 4 weapons even though they only ever use one. And if you bench one for a mission you better take their items off or probably forget who has the good weapons and upgrades.The quest system is badly done too. The map is absolutely no help. These free roam type of games are fun, I love Skyrim. But you're barely pointed in the right direction for the quests. On the wrong level of an area? Too bad, the map won't tell you which of the 6 doors to take to get close to the quest. You just have to stumble around. I love exploring, but there's nothing interesting to find. The best I found were a few side quests that were pick this up and find the person to turn it into eventually.The gameplay is annoying to. Amazing Spectre recruit meant to be a protector of the universe? Can't jump over a 1ft wall. Seriously, no jumping??? Gotta walk all the way around that wall. The aiming system is also meh. For pistols and shotguns it's fine, but for the sniper it feels like you've taken several shots before you went sniping.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												If you are looking for a game that lets you roam in space and discover new things and has massive quest and some RPG elements etc. like a "space-elder-scrolls" you gonna have a bad time. Thats what i expected.There is the main story; quite linear (after you finished the main story you are not able to go on). The story is good, tense and inspires you to think about the universe. The dialogues are good and the few people you can speak are very interesting, the music is adequate, so you can get that immersive feel. But that's all.The side quests are pretty lame, the maps on the side quest are repitive and lame. Generally there is not much room to explore in any map except for the main quest maps. They are talking about how big this planet is or how big this space ship is and you can only run in some linear tubes, where scripted events will trigger and only a hand full of people and aliens are. The Items are pretty lame, there is nearly no crafting. You just play the same mini game over and over to open a chest, loot it all and swap if there is something with a higher level than your current item. And repeat.... boring. Everybody has so much to say, i nearly spend half of the game (maybe more) time hearing people talk, although i even skipped some stuff.The RPG system is quite lame and not really vital for your progress as the combat system (combat is lame because there are items missing). There are just 4 different gun types and a grenade. Of course you can upgrade them, but it nearly doesn't matter or adds some kind of weapon diversity.I'm pretty disappointed, but i just paid 2$, so it's okay.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Let me preface this by saying: I love Mass Effect.  I've spent hundreds of hours on the 360 version.  I had gotten this one hoping to get a superior version of the game I've been playing for so long, but I was pretty disappointed.Depending on graphics/sound card set ups that may or may not agree with the game's coding, you'll run into ALL SORTS of lovely glitches.  First: the classic--Garrus's face textures look like crap.  I've tried everything and there's no easy fix that I can find that will elevate those textures beyond a glaring medium.  Second...a more serious issue, you have to go through some hoops just to get the game started.  It involves compatibility modes and running certain files as administrator...they don't warn you anywhere that this game is almost as hard to start correctly as Dark Souls and GFWL...  Third: sound.  Just sound.  It's a disaster.  Popping at the end of every line of dialog.  Advancing dialog before the line is finished.  It completely decimates what is arguably the point of the whole game: the dialog system.  Don't buy.  Save the money.  Buy a freaking 360 (I can't believe I just said that) on ebay for $50 and grab a trilogy package of the game used and go to town.  Or buy Mass Effect 2 on PC with the Genesis DLC.

												Enjoyed my first 5 hours of gameplay, turned the game back on and my saves appear to be gone. That is weird because I know I saved them. I made sure to get to a checkpoint and save manually before I quit.Tried to give it another chance and started playing a save set 2 hours prior. About 1 hour later the game starts becoming unresponsive after I exit a dialogue, so I have no choice but to exit. Reopen game, all saves are gone back to that original point again despite me saving the game multiple times after that point to make sure it didn't happen again.Not sure if this issue is specific to Windows 10 or something but it is a serious annoyance and for now I can't recommend the game, even though I enjoyed it the time I spent on it.Specs: OS win10 with gtx780 gpu with i5-4670 cpu

content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												Terrible pc port, controls are unbearable, abysmal visual performance,z-fighting,screen tearing, huge nasty LoD pop,textures and colors seems to be coming from a 1995 pc game,overall this is a♥♥♥♥♥♥ass looking game(Half-Life looked better and came in 1998 ...). Could be a fun game but the combat mechanics is so unbelievably crappy,archaic,frustrating having to pause the game every single time you want to give simple commands to your crew(no brain non-using by themselves skills crew...  or missing the target or using them in useless moment) is slowing down the pace of the game so much you wonder what else did the developper made to extend the game,Oh wait maybe something like the "You can't run except in combat otherwise you'll be forced to walk so slow that you'll wonder if you're moving at all" or "everlasting boring and not relevant to the story dialog". At first I liked the idea to be able to my make own "build" but then you notice that there is only 1 way of playing each character class... Most of the skills or guns are totally useless or some skills are so good that you cannot go without them. This game turns to be yet another raildroad game with fake character skills development and poorly handicapped combat style.This could have been great, but no, it is not, in fact one of the worse game I ever played. DO NOT BUY.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												Heard so much about Mass Effect, how brilliant plot it has, and what a great game it is. Ridiculusly high scores pretty much everywhere you will look. It raised the bar pretty high.And it's not that great. Sure, it has world with some history and♥♥♥♥♥♥ but what is a RPG without that? Plot itself? Meh. "Making decisions"? Didn't feel like I had any impact on events. Spared some queen of some race and it should be something big. No mention throughout the rest of the game. Wanted to talk with Wrex not to be stupid♥♥♥♥♥♥ Bam, the lady that ♥♥♥♥ed me later killed him. IT WAS ONLY CHARACTER I LIKED, YOU ♥♥♥♥♥, THANK YOU VERY MUCH. Well, Joker was OK too. But the rest? Ultra serious saviors of the galaxy. Mechanics really boring. Doing same stuff same way all time. And if someone kills you and you forgot how rare autosaves are. Well, there's more of the same stuff. Steering Mako is a nightmare. Inventory. Well, you don't notice it until you hit almost 150 items, and you have to do some cleanup. If the game contained dialogs only I might have enjoyed it more, but the mechanics spoiled it.Also I don't like watching black blocks instead of characters or if I don't like them turning "viewmode unlit" because my hardware is too new. WTF?Was playing game hurtful? It may seem so, but no, it wasn't. I'ts negative review because it doesn't meet my exceptations considered all hype it got. I finished the game so it couldn't have been THAT boring. It was OK, maybe even good, but really far from excelent.

												The only reason to play ME1 is to make a character to carry on to ME2. The autosave feature is terrible but the lethality of the game is high. If you forget to quick save you will regret it. I just lost 45 mins of work, cutscenes and quest turn ins.There are skills in this game you cannot level up, you simply have them innately if you picked the right options at the beginning. The game uses both a charm/intimidate and a Paragon/renegade stat in order to keep you from doing any of the optional or useful dialogues. choose one or the other. It is also very vague about what to do, where youre going (no thanks to a crpapy map)I uninstalled it. Never again.

content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												You know, I have loved this game for a long time...  ME and ME2 were awesome, I had originally played both on the XBox 360 and saw ME and ME2 as a bundle.  So I couldn't resist...  The issue that I had wasn't with Steam but with the games themselves on the PC.  No matter how I tried to set up my controller it didn't work.  Windows reads my controller, it registers on other games on the PC but for some reason even having tried numberous mods, the games didn't read it.  Finally, out of frustration I pretty much gave up.  Granted will it stop me from playing?  Probably not.  But will it make me think twice before purchasing games again on the PC?  Most definitely.  I like playing with a controller.  It enhances the experience for me without having to relearn hand placement on a keyboard and mouse.  I'm not saying the game is unplayable, but it's extremely disappointing having to go through relearning hand placement.  It takes away a LOT from gameplay.  Had I known that this were going to be the case I wouldn't have spent the money at all.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2012
												Though it feels stupid in comparison to other great Bioware titles, the game's got potential.If you like games that can be taken as art (as do I), then I'd probably not recommend this. Even though it *is* a good although cheesy space opera.Just that the clunky and unsurprising gameplay, the cliche narrative of the story and the watered-down rpg elements amount to zero merit in my view.Characters are what holds the whole thing together. Even if I don't like Shepard and what he stands for, he (or she) is mostly neutral enough in his attitude, so that even the tad boring paragon/renegade dichotomy can sometimes be shaped by character creation customization and imaginative role-play. Tho one really has little room for the latter. But overall, others are fleshed out enough to be believable even in this too-good-to-be-true setting where most every team-mate is a hero and a (potential) lover.A solid 5/10.Actually, in hindsight, I'd like to change the review to reflect what I think is central to the Mass Effect series: that it killed off a legendary game developing company, by becoming what EA sees and wants to see as a sort of standard or staple in gaming. And it's a streamlined and boring staple at that. I'll allow myself a small rant on ME in general, after seeing what potential Bioware has wasted (played through both the classics and the new, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ones - they don't compare in quality, the new ones are frankly an insult to the player and its expectations).ME takes away all player agency, just letting the player click on inconsequential stuff and run through halls, doing tedious tasks, only to shoehorn in some superficial sex scenes with space jocks and space cheerleaders. Characters are not smart (even "scientists" are just appropriated and shallow image of the real thing here, they actually make no sense at all), the plot is not at all plausible nor involving, making the whole thing not believable in any way. No need to use logic by the user or find meaning in anything, just need to run through corridors and fantasize over appropriated alien species, buff Mexicans etc. No limited resources, or risk, everything is handed to the player for visual stimuli and the comfort of clicking mindlessly. As long as the player can envision themselves as a stupid yet happy and successful (well-endowed) space-Jesus wannabe without whom everything would be annihilated and whom everyone needs and loves.Truth be told, that's the gist of the ME series. Shame they destroyed DA so easily after Origins, just to make all their games "like ME". I'd be surprised if anything half-decent comes from EAoware in the future.Go play DA:O or the Witcher series instead. Those are games made out of love, not for easy money in the short term granted by appeal to some low low denominators.Traditional scoring systems fail here.Make it rather a negative five.

number of helpful: 5 of 26 people (19%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												Would you read or watch a trilogy and then stop right before the end? Do you like cliffhangers that will never be resolved? Do you like to having the feeling you are in control while playing a game, only to be railroaded into doing something stupid later on? No? Then this game is not for you. Mass Effect and Mass Effect 2 are solid, if not excellent games. They have their flaws, but I can live with them. But it is a continuous storyline that runs across three games, not two. Mass Effect 3, the third installment, not available on Steam, but only on Origin, has a very controversial ending that ends the trilogy on a sour note. If you've somehow missed the controversy, just google Mass Effect 3 ending, read some of the many things that have already been said about it, and weep. Weep for the loss of something that could have been epic. Weep for the hurt feelings of countless gamers. Weep for the sorry fate of a couple of epic fictional characters, that felt like friends to so many of us.If you think you will be able to live with the above and also love RPGs, then by all means, buy this game now, no hesitation, or just keep reading and then make up your mind.Mass Effect is a great game. It is a game in which you are faced with a threat to the entire Galaxy and your character, Shepard, is the only one who can do something about it. The graphics may be a bit dated by now, the minigames may be more distracting than fun, the Mako may be near impossible to steer and eager to slide into the nearest ravine, the side missions may look like they were thrown together during a crunch time weekend, fueled by energy drinks and cheetos, and there may be some other minor problems, but, and this is a BIG but, the main storylines are excellent, the voice acting is close to perfection, the universe is vast and compelling. The greatest thing about this game is how engaging it is. You get a feeling for your character, always with the last name Shepard, but other than that, you can mold him or her any way you choose. You can choose a backstory, a look down to the gender, have intimate relations with humans and aliens alike, although there are no actual sex scenes, despite the uproar some people have tried to create. The average movie has way more skin than these games.You get to know your squadmate pretty well, can even enter a relationship with at least one of them, and although your mileage may vary and may not like each and every one of them, you will probably find at least one or a few you will end up caring for. They can feel pretty real. They can't hit the broad side of a barn and are sometimes pretty useless in a fight, not hitting anything while one enemy is stomping your face and another is shooting you for good measure, but you take all that in stride because they feel and sound like actual people. The only written dialog is when you are presented with a choice. But that choice, once made, is then voiced marvelously, with depth and feeling, adding to the immersion. The choices make you feel in control, allow you to chart a course for your character, being a good person or a troublemaker or something in between, decide the fate of humanity or even the Galaxy, or on a smaller scale, who lives and who dies. Then it makes you feel sorry about that choice and perhaps restart from a savegame, or even create a new Shepard and do everything all over again, starting from scratch, rewriting history. Despite it all, it doesn't get boring. I played this game for over 120 hours, not just one playthrough, but many, with different variants of Shepards. Or with the same, trying to get better stats, righting wrongs, making left turns where earlier I had taken a right, just to see where it would lead. Or just play the game again on another difficulty level. Or using different powers or weapons. In and of itself, stand alone, ignoring, no, denying the great injustice that was Mass Effect 3, Mass Effect is a terrific game, and judged in that way, I would wholeheartedly recommend it.In Mass Effect 2, more of the same, with better graphics. In Mass Effect 3, more of the same and then, right at the end.. They dropped the ball so hard, it made its way to the center of the Earth. I guess they ran out of ideas, out of time, out of money or out of writers or something. Maybe they just painted themselves into a corner, realised they couldn't live up to the hype they had created, couldn't realistically create several different endings without ending up shortchanging us anyway. Whatever the cause, it saddens me that I will never, ever get to see what happened to 'my' Shepards. That is the problem with Mass Effect as well. You are pulled into this universe, made to care about your Shepard and about your squadmates, come to regard them as friends. You do your best to keep them alive, try to work around their defects in targeting skills, despite their reputation, and love them for who they are. But you will never, ever get to see what became of them and are forced to make do with an ending that feels tacked on, even with the expansions. Even now I sometimes feel like I am grieving for these characters. Shame on you EA! Shame on you Bioware! I will never forgive you for this! Unless you belatedly release modding tools for ME3 allowing the communicty to finally fix this, or better yet, finally come up with a true ending, that lives up to all the pre-launch hype and really gives us different options and shows us what became of our Shepard and its squadmates. I would be desperate enough to pay for that too, just to heal this hole in my heart. *snif* If you're thinking: surely the ending to Mass Effect 3 can't be that bad? Then again, just google it. Then make your own decision. But don't say I didn't warn you. At least now you know what you are getting into.If you do buy the game, it is useful to know that on Windows 7 the game won't run at all unless you run Steam as an administrator, that there is a guide to tweak the settings to prevent horrible audio stuttering, that you upon request you may be able to get the Mass Effect Bring Down The Sky DLC for free from EA and that you need to hang on to your final savegames for each character if you ever purchase Mass Effect 2. You can also buy all games together, but in that version the original game is completely unchanged, so other than it maybe being cheaper, there is no advantage. There are mods that allow you to play with better textures however.

												TL;DR: Could not even launch after install, had to go find a patch; no controller support; random crashes. A lazy, lazy port.Played this game on the ol' 360 religiously. My prefernces are moving toward PC more and more, but this is an awful port. Firstly, it would crash on startup. Steam isn't updating this game anymore, so I had to go and dig around for the latest patch from bioware (1.02) which fixed the issue. No 360 controller support (the studio that ported the game went out of their way to remove any files related to the 360 in order to save time and cut costs rather then adding controller supprt) so the only fix completely destroy any keyboard and mouse support. Do not get this game, it is just another half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥port. Also, it tends to crash randomly. Hooray!

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												With all the praise backed behind it I bought this game, expecting something wonderful. What came out of it however, is a game focused on so much dialogue and story that I could not keep up. The story is great, dont get me wrong, but its lack of telling me exactly where I wanted to go for the main missions made me frustrated, and the horrible AI who barely kill anything and make me do all the work. I may come back to this game in the future but for now it remains a game focused with too much dialogue, and little gameplay elements to keep me entertained.A game with a great setting and story, should not be this boring and tedious as it is. It is not a great port though, with constant glitches and poor saving. I lost an hours' worth of content due to the autosave feature not working properly, you have to constantly save in order for it to work.However, if you are a person who enjoys an experience of story and a RPG or whatever this is, then I would recommend this. If however you like a good balance between gameplay and story, try something else, like Portal or Middle earth:SOW.Score: 6.5/10

number of helpful: 4 of 24 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												-------------------WARNING: SOME SPOILERS FOR THE 3RD GAME AHEAD-------------------Note: My full playthroughs were on the Xbox 360 versions.I cannot recommend anyone begin the Mass Effect franchise after experiencing the 3rd one.At one point I loved Mass Effect 1 and 2, for a time I thought Mass Effect 2 might have been my favorite game of all time.From a gameplay standpoint the first one was pretty bad, honestly. The 3rd person shooter mechanics we clunky, the inventory and equipment system was one of the worst I've ever seen, the environments were mostly barren landscapes or generic corridors full of waist high boxes to let you know a firefight was about to break out. Don't even get me started on the Mako. But really, none of that mattered, the game was fantastic due to it's great dialog and story telling. These games are all about the story, and the first and second game succeeded in ways very few games have. It introduced a world full of characters and sub-plots that I cared about, and it was all building towards the conclusion with the promise that you had helped to shape it, complete with diverging story and consequences tied to your actions. I played the first 2 games over and over again just to have multiple outcomes ready to advance through the story. That build up ended up being the franchises greatest weakness, because the 3rd game did not deliver.The power of choice, this franchises greatest strength that carried them despite their weak gameplay elements, ended up being an illusion, and what I was left with was unwavering disappointment and a new contextual perspective on the quality of the franchise.The illusion that your choices mattered was completely destroyed in the 3rd game, with everything either being undone (Rachni), or made irrelevant by substituting different characters in place of others with different attitudes (Councillors, Wrex) with the exact same outcome. The cutscenes toward the end didn't even account for who you had rallied in the final battle. And then to top it all off you're given a Deus Ex Machina plot device who presents you 3 choices in order to save the universe, and not a single one of them had anything to do with anything over the course of the franchise.With the illusion of choice and consequence shattered, Mass Effect 1, 2 AND 3 are weak 3rd person shooters, with fantastic dialoge, score and a couple exciting cinematic moments. The story is a rollercoaster full of promise that collapses under it's own weight, and crashes and burns in a way I never want to experience again. As a standalone game, the first is the strongest as far as story goes, though it absolutely can not stand on it's own in that regard, and has to be evaluated in the context of the 3rd game. Mass Effect could not have ended at the end of either Mass Effect 1 or 2 and been a decent story, each game is incomplete on it's own, and that is why they all fail as one.Imagine if at end of the Lord of the Rings Trilogy, a literally-no-name 'mysterious' Wizard appeared during the final assault on the Black Gate of Mordor, and offered Aragorn 3 (color-coded) ways to defeat Sauron and his forces at the snap of a finger, each as convoluted and arbitrary as the next, Aragorn picks one and it had just ended there. And you're left wondering "What was all that♥♥♥♥♥♥about the ring then?", Mass Effect was a lot like that.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												First, let me say that this review is saying I disliked the "Mass Effect" OR series.  I'm one of the few that has played the series from start to finish on Xbox and loved it and actually did NOT have a conniption fit over the ending of "Mass Effect 3".  This said, I DO NOT recommend the PC version!  Here's why:1) No controller support.  Not even if you have a xbox remote on a windows environment.  You need xpadder or the like in order to use a controller and even then there's a glitch somewhere that makes the camera bug out easy when turning.  There's also a bug that causes the rumbler of the controller to start going for no reason and will NOT stop.  There are work arounds, but it makes for an unbelievably annoying experience.2) The game is unstable as hell.  I'm serious.  Look it up in steam community forums, online in google or wherever you like.  "Mass Effect" and in some cases "Mass Effect 2" are PLAGUED with crashes and lockups.  Completely at random.  ALOT of users are getting this.  There is very little you can do about this as well and the 'hotfix patch' that Bioware released DOES NOTHING.  If you want to play this, my recommendation is save EVERY 5 minutes... and even then, you'll end up backtracking from time to time.3) NO DLC AVAILABLE IN STEAM.  For a franchise that has tons of DLC, the ONLY WAY to get any DLC is to go directly to Bioware and pay full price... which will have you paying the cost of the game several times over again.So yeah.  I recommend the game series only on console.  NOT on PC.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2012
												Okay BioWare. Here we go again. Mass Effect is Essentially Baldur's Gate 7. Where I will give BW credit is that Mass Effect is a bit (just a bit) of a departure from they're usual hack 'n' slash RPG. ME is a shoot-em-up RPG. That being said, it still has the same conversation system, and the same  inventory system that has made me claw my teeth out since Baldur's Gate.The bad about Mass Effect is that it's just so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ long. You spend so much time exploring and doing side missions that you forget about the main storyline. That's something new for BioWare.Having said all that, I've played most of the way through ME and enjoyed it. But I would have enjoyed it a lot more if they had fixed the inventory system that has been broken since 1998. Yes, it's interesting to customize your armor upgrades. No, it's not fun to keep track of them all. I always had a notebook on my desk when I played ME to keep track of my inventory, because the inventory system in-game scrolled so slow and was just so clunky.Any game that requires the use of an actual notepad gets a C. Honestly, I don't understand why this game ever got a sequel. It's BioWare, so the story is just awesome. But it's BioWare, so the actual "game" is fairly ♥♥♥♥♥♥.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												Here is a game which features probably one of the best female characters of all video game time (Please choose a female lead character. It's so much better. trust me!) , which is a nice thing off the bat and a rarity. Great writing, decent story, and in some respects a worthy succesor to the Knights of the old Republic games, but there's no other aspect of the game that sticks with me, and if I wanted a decent Sci-Fi story with excellent female protagonists, then I would read some Peter Hamilton instead. Unlike, for example, Half Life 2 and Bioshock which use the game medium to allow your actions and immersion to portray the story, you instead simply get to experience it as you move through the game, and it suffers because of this.It's still a good pointy-clicky rpg type of space game, but I do not think it deserves the accolades it has had over the years and I would only recommend it to followers of the genre.

												What is a good game at its core is ultimately bad as a finished, AAA product. There isn't a big flaw that breaks it, it is in fact multiple smaller issues that, when combined, make this a rather poor experience. Here are my main issues with Mass Effect : Clunky UIAbysmal tutorial (pages and pages of text, really?)Bad balance in terms of weaponryA horrible texture, that seems to affect AMD CPU systems mostlyUnskippable cutscenes and dialogSome people might not have a big of a problem as I have found, and if that's the case then by all means, go for it. But otherwise, this is just frustration interspersed with decent shootouts

content:
Posted: December 5, 2010
												This modern day remake of Moon Patrol contains everything that made the original such a classic back in 1982 including the lesbian sex scene with the mono gendered blue alien crewmember, but I really can't reccomend people play this having played the entire trilogy, it will only end in tears.You may be decived by the RPG elements, or the decent storyline, the endearing characters and you may think to yourself you want to keep going, but not only will you have to get Origin to get the final game in the series, but then you too will join us foolish foolish people who clang to the hope that Bioware had somehow not been courrupted and then it will be too late.This is a warning, don't buy it, don't start down this path, don't don't don't DON'T!!

number of helpful: 7 of 34 people (21%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Don’t get me wrong, it’s not a bad game.  It’s a good game, maybe a very good game; it’s just not a 10 of 10 best game of the year ever.The mechanics are good, but I though using your team mates skills was awkward (maybe I just suck, either way, didn’t care for it.)  The skill tree imposes ridiculous prerequisites (why do I need to learn shoot a pistol before using a shot gun?)  The space tank (Mako, was it?) missions seem forced on you, until you're forced out of it by large rocks that no force in the universe can break.  The only stealth system is on your ship and it only works as a plot device.As for the story, in true RPG fashion, it starts in the middle of the action and then drops you into cut scene and dialogue hell.  Then a running gun fight though the intergalactic equivalent of U.N. headquarter, which draw the attention of…pretty much no one.  More dialogue hell and then you have a whole galaxy to explore.  There are several collectables to scour the galaxy for (because you’re not a time critical mission to save humanity.) in addition to the story missions.In conclusion (do I hear a catch phrase?), it’s not a bad game.  I would recommend it, just not on Steam, because they’ll never get ME3.  I’ll be buying a gently used copy of the trilogy for PS3.
